review_headline: Second hand copy of the worst kind.
review_body: Very disappointing. Second hand copy of the worst kind.

I think we're all mature enough to agree that while JD Salinger's life and mind are their own 'things', you can't let those interfere with his excellent execution of describing a teenager's isolated feelings and struggling to understand 'the real world' amidst an unplanned trip to New York City.

This novel makes me feel 15 again. It makes me laugh: the way Holden orders his drinks, the way he talks to 'adults', the way he so viciously filters the world through that special idealism only a teenager can have.

review_headline: 'Comin' Thro the Rye' in Fine Style
review_body: I hardly know where to start in writing a 'review' for Catcher in the Rye.  Never read it as a young man, but here, as a Senior citizen  thought it might be an about-time read, especially when one of my favorite books is a teen-angst book called Temple of Gold.  At this stage of my life, I am more into figuring out why the author wrote it and wanted his readers to get out of it.  At first I was more or less disappointed because some of the characters and situations were overkill on awkwardness of Holden Caulfield's acquaintances and his analyzing of the everything in the minutae most all the time. Temple of Gold had much more realistic and a not-so much of a candy-ass of a protagonist.  I'm not going to go into all the nuances of the characters as you can read reviews here for that, but would like to think the reason the writer, J.D. Salinger hoped to get across, was after the writer who is basically writing an autobiography of himself, 'progressed' on after the story/life of a 17-year old, ended.  I think that came in the revelation of the Psychoanalysit Wilhelm Sketel whose quote which was a dichotomy of what Holden was and what Holden (as J.D. Salinger) became.---- "The mark of the immature man is that he wants to die nobly for a cause, while the mark of the mature man is that he wants to live humbly for one."  Holden through his relationships and over-analyzing of absurd behaviours of himself and others was also this immature man who was battling his environment and status as a teenager.  His mature part was getting his readership to see this immaturity and see where it took him into a more noble calling of a mature person and writer.  Holden's only seeming hope as a redeeming value came in his passion in English and the only thing that kept him above a total, helpless, on-the-road-to-being, failure state.  Comin' Thro the Rye was a children's portrayed song highlighted in his book and on into the theme title of his book.  While somewhat noble in not having the children go through his immaturity by saving them from falling off the cliff into that vortex and poked at by his young sister, Phoebe toward the end; he starts to understand in the latter part of the book, the saving grace, where he actually 'misses' his phony/antagonistic people, and sees a window in setting goals as advice into not 'falling' to where he was at or heading; signifying the maturity to be had as future, mature writer, using his deficiencies as a revelatory understanding that would catapult into a career he could hang his hunting cap on, so to speak.  Page 150 is is important as this song from a young boy, a children's version of 'Comin' Thro the Rye' is symbolic for the theme and title.  It's about sexual wonderment at a young age which is about the immature aspect of growing up, and not especially the thought of leading the children, later, about leading them, especially, and protecting them from the phoniness or shallowness of adulthood.  Holden displayed what awkwardness relationships and sex are for all of us readers in their growing up.
Excellent product and price, super fast delivery.  Thanks!
I read this book like many others in high school. I misplaced my original copy so bought this to replace it.

review_headline: Move over Hamlet, Holden caulfield is my favorite protagonist in world literature
review_body:
It does help that I share a few things with Holden Caulfied:

- A fondness for my little sister
- I am male
- I was Holden's age 16 years ago
- I got close to flunking out of school all those years ago
- English/writing was my favorite subject
- Didn't really fit in at High school or at College
- I've been suicidal
- I've been diagnosed with depression
- I'm agnostic
- etc
I stared reading literature in my mid twenties and this was one of the first books I read, it was easily the best entertainment per page of any book I had ever read by then. Recently, I've been reading a lot of pop fiction and underwhelmed by most( *cough cough* Hunger Games, Harry Potter); so I opted to reread something I really enjoyed awhile ago.. I borrowed it from my school library and reread it again and it's just as fresh, illuminating and laugh out loud funny as my first read was. No other book written by mortal man captures and expresses so eloquently my early adulthood disillusionment with life in general. A great book doesn't need to have any uplifting message or moral undertones to merit being called a masterpiece. But if there were any lessons I'll take from this book it would be to strive to be/remain my authentic self, not expect too much from myself or anyone and not to be overly cynical either, whatever that means(something Holden would probably shrug off as phony)
A must read.
This book is really captivating. The language is not too advanced and it is a pleasure to read. The story is an emotional thrill ride.

review_headline: Will linger in your mind and heart forever.
review_body:
I'm so glad I finally got around to reading this fabulous book. It's a quick read yet characters and situations linger. I'll never forget Holden Caulfield.
He's brilliant with a partially educated mind. He's naive yet recognizes perversion. He has big ideas, the ideas of a man, yet he is still partially, a child. He talks tough. Hearing his empathy, caring and sensitivity and bewilderment through that tough sounding language is both heartbreaking and endearing.

Reading it seemed natural, personal and gripping. Only after I completed reading the last page and went on about my day for a few hours did I realize I had just finished reading a masterpiece that would stay with me always.

I recommend that you get on Netflix and see the documentary about J. D. Salinger. It will enrich your experience whether you see it before or after you read the book.

Joanna Poppink, MFT
Los Angeles psychotherapist
author: Healing Your Hungry Heart: recovering from your eating disorder
required for high school reading

The Catcher in the Rye was a very bizarre read. I caught that the main idea was to convey the hardships experienced by most adolescent boys when coming of age, but I found nothing more significant than that. I kept searching for a more important lesson but all I found were complaints about "phonies" and eccentric anecdotes describing the tough life of a semi-rebellious teen. The writing style was choppy, erratic, and simple to convey that the ideas are coming from Holden's juvenile mind, but rather than entertain me, the style (and constant "goddams") annoyed me. The book is considered a classic, but I don't see any reason why it should be. It's a bizarre and simple story written in an obnoxious way with no underlying important theme other than the already obvious.
This is the most over rated book i have EVER read.

I read like 60% of it as I kept waiting for the catch, I can not believe that I paid for this book. I think I was betrayed by the ones reviewing this book, those that say it is amazing. review_headline: Classic Novel Of Teen Angst & Depression
review_body: This is probably one of the best classic novels that I have read in my life that portrays teen angst and depression in such a realistic manner and it still seems to be relevant in many aspects today. While this was originally published in the 50's and for some of those readers who say this book seems outdated, there are many boys just like Holden Caulfield in todays world that can still relate to his character. This novel is an excellent character study and deserves the praise it has received all these years since it's publication. I really do not want to give away much of the books premise for those who have not read this classic but I would definitely recommend this to those with open minds who are not offended easily.
Great
Had no plot

In the mind of a depressed young boy in new york city. I felt connected as he journeyed for companionship and was figuring out his path. I think reading this in your teenage years is wise and maybe comforting.

*** some spoilers ***

A stream of consciousness narration in the first person about a young man who has failed at a prep school and is thrown out. He leaves peremptorily and heads off to his hometown, New York City. We are lead through a series of his misadventures.

On the positive side the story is very readable and the author portrays well the different characters he encounters.

But about mid-way through the story I found his nihilism and misanthropy tiresome. It became redundant – as in are we going anywhere with all this? There was a conversation between our main character and his sister (the only person he felt positively about) where she pointedly asks him: “What, my brother, do you like?” This is the crux and the major relationship in the story – and I felt it was left dangling.

Call me old-fashioned but I do like some form of conclusion – whether it’s an epiphany, a revelation or even a step to the next stage of life.

All-in-all I felt let down at the end, and the book left me uninspired.

review_headline: Brilliant and all, it killed me, really it did
review_body:
This novel is brilliant. This is the second time I've read it, having read it for the first time about twenty years ago. I loved it then and I loved it this time around too.

J.D. Salinger, then in his 30s, magnificently succeeded in writing in the voice of a 17-year-old boy.

Do read this novel whether you are a teenager or adult.

Also, if you want to read (or indeed write) you have to read this novel in order to see what can be done with the written word.
great

review_headline: The cover shown isn't what I got.
review_body: The cover shown isn't what I got. The entire purpose of my order was to have the red cover in my library again

A book review by Holden Caulfield:
This phony book killed me!

Without having studied this in school, or really knowing much about it before reading it, I have to admit to being at a loss to understand the point of Catcher in the Rye. The plot can be easily summarized: a young man of about 17 years flunks out of his prestigious private school. It is not the first time he's flunked out, so he is understandably reluctant to tell his parents. Instead, he decides to use the 5-day examination period to wander about New York City (where he lives) to.... do stuff. His plan is nebulous, even in his own mind, and at times ho ends up in a hotel bar, in his sister's room (he sneaks in without his parents seeing him), Central Park, etc. However, the plot points are clearly not important because nothing much happens, and certainly the story is left unresolved, only covering Friday night to Sunday morning, so we never even get to the point of his parents finding out about his expulsion.

Rather, the book is not what it is about, but rather how it is about it (to use one of Roger Ebert's pet phrases). Written in a conversational style, with plenty of non-sequitors and copious swearing, it is meant to be more of a train-of-thought process as the young man goes about his days. Unfortunately, I have always found this style hard to read, with its extra words, repetitions, and contextual slang. For example, he will say things like, "Boy, you should have been there. You really should." - the entire prose is written in this style, and it is wearing to read. Similarly, although there is swearing on every page, I think there is not a single F-word, the go-to choice of modern youth. Instead, the book sounds (to a modern ear) very dated, or as if it was written by someone who is just imagining what youth talk like without actually speaking to any.... although, to be fair, linguists apparently agree that the slang is accurate for the age and time of the main character. Perhaps it is inevitable that a book written in 1949 - one that was edgy and modern at the time - would feel more dated than "classical" literature. For example, the language feels far more dated than in, say, The Great Gatsby, Dracula or even Jane Austin. Along the same lines, even for the late 40's, the things that the main character disparages sound more like things someone the author's age, rather than the character's age, would hate. For, me, it breaks the illusion to have the author speaking for the character rather than the character speaking.

Returning to the original question: what is the book about? Is it meant to be a gritty, realistic portrayal of a young man in his quest to find himself? - if so, he never progresses in his self-awareness. Is it a polemic on the nature of man? - one of his primary trains of thought is that most people are "phonies", i.e. we only do things to make ourselves happy, and if we do something "charitable" it's not through love of our neighbour but because it makes us feel better about ourselves. So ultimately, I don't know what the book is about. I suppose it's is interesting enough, and it doesn't outlast its welcome (at a mere 200 pages), but the narrator is somewhat unpleasant (as his sister points out, he hates everything) so we're once again left wondering why we have gone on this journey with him. Perhaps it's just that the character doesn't speak to me. Perhaps I've read enough teen angst books and seen enough teen angst movies that the subject no longer interests me. Perhaps something that was "edgy" in 1949 is simply "old-fashioned" in 2015. Whatever the case, for a book that is regularly listed as one of the 100 best in the English language, I would not recommend this book when there are many other classics more deserving (in my opinion) of your time.

review_headline: Easy read but same theme all over
review_body: It is an easy read.  The depiction of the main character Holden, a 17 yr old boy, looking for directions, a mentor and female companion is very accurate n impressive.  He thinks every one is a phoney while he himself is one.  This is what every teenager's problem ~ hoping to identify with others yet trying to be cool or unique.  The lack of epiphany/enlightenment till the end is rather disappointing.  I was hoping Holden would change or find a direction.

review_headline: Ever Wonder What Kind of Book Gets Banned?!
review_body:
Review Originally Posted At: www.FictionForesight.com

Here, There Be Phonies – 4 Stars!

The Catcher In The Rye is a brilliantly executed take on teenage life written over 60 years ago, that still holds true today.

A Quick Summary:

Essentially, The Catcher In The Rye is a book about a few days in the life of a teenager named Holden Caulfield. The entire story is narrated by Caulfield as he reflects back on a recent time in his life; taking place just after he is expelled from yet another prep school. It details his misadventures and observations of life from his outcast, and emotionally charged, perspective.

The Good:

First of all I just wanted to say this book is a classic written over 60 years ago with over 1.5 million ratings and nearly 35,000 reviews; and that’s just on Goodreads. In other words, I more than likely won’t say anything that someone hasn’t already said hundreds, if not thousands, of times. In light of this, I’m going to keep my review relatively short and to the point.

First, to point out the elephant in the room, I love how relatable this book is, even 60+ years later. Teenage angst, in all it’s many forms, is pretty much timeless. The Catcher In The Rye does a fantastic job at showing just how emotional and overwhelming that time of life can be. It’s not prettied up to make it look like everything will be all right; it’s raw and realistic. The issues are presented just as they feel to Holden, just as they feel to many teenagers. And even if you’re not a teenager, and not able to relate to the book in the moment, you can reflect back and understand where he is coming from. For those who say “I never felt like that”, I get that, but I’m sure you knew someone who did. It’s not exclusive to how all people everywhere felt when they were Holden’s age, but it is a good representation.

I keep bringing this up, but this book was written over60 years ago. To me, that’s amazing. This is one of those books that, aside from a few words and phrases, doesn’t feel like it was written more than 10 years ago. The Catcher In The Rye read like just about everything else nowadays, and I loved that. One of the reasons I don’t read as many classics as I should is that I hate Shakespearean lingo, and stuff like it. For me, it takes away from the story. If I have to spend time trying to understand what’s being said, as opposed to absorbing what’s happening, it wouldn’t be a book I’d tend to lean towards. In my opinion, this is one of the reasons that story is as timeless as it is. Anybody could pick it up and understand what’s going on.

I thoroughly enjoyed the refreshingly raw look into a characters mind. Holden was troubled; he had his emotional demons. The fact that you’re able to read his train of thought, to have such a vivid look at his mindset, that’s what made it so special to me. One scene he’s going along happy and go-lucky, and the next he’s broken to the emotional core. That’s life. When things get Holden down, J.D. Salinger shows us the effect, he doesn’t just gloss over it. The emotional internal and spiritual struggles are real. The vulnerability is real.

Finally, for all that this book is, I found it to be quite funny. Sure it was dry humor, but it still made me laugh out loud on a number of occasions. That’s what keeps it from being too emotional, too heavy.

The Bad:

This is tough, because I really didn’t see anything particularly wrong with this book. In fact the only reason I didn’t give it 5 stars is because it didn’t feel 5 star worthy to me. It’s not one of those things where I could tell you what went wrong.

I know some people have a problem with it because they find the character too negative, and too unrealistic. That’s not an issue for me. I understand Holden as a character, even if I never really felt the way he did.

I know people also disliked the fact that this book really didn’t have a beginning or ending; but that’s the point isn’t it? It’s a book that centers on the life of a teenager, for only a brief period of time. It really couldn’t have a true beginning or ending. It’s all about the there and now. Sure it points to the future, but only in regards to the feelings it brings up at that moment.

Other:

While I was reading this book, all I kept thinking about was that it’s a book about nothing. I mean yes at its core it’s about all the things I’ve mentioned above and many others, but generally speaking it’s about nothing in particular. And yet it’s so incredibly successful. Now why is that familiar? Oh yes, there was a little show about nothing; Seinfeld ring any bells? That was just a little successful too. In fact, if you look at it, you could say that Seinfeld is an adult version of this book, without as much emotional investment and more comedic value.

I find quite humorous how ironic this book is. The thought of Holden being “the catcher in the rye”, wanting to save children’s innocence, save them from adulthood, all the while he’s the one with Peter Pan syndrome. He’s the one who wants to be a child.

Overall:

What can you say, The Catcher in the Rye is a classic any way you swing it. Love it or hate it, it’s been around for over 60 years and I don’t see that changing any time soon. It’s won an insane amount of awards, been on almost every top 100 must-read list and is relatable through the generations. At this point, if you haven’t already read it, just do it. You’ll either love it, or you won’t. I loved it, and can’t recommend it enough. Would I say it changed my life? No, but I understand how it could. They don’t call em classics for nothing.

(www.FictionForesight.com)

review_headline: Growing Up Is Hard To Do
review_body:
In the 1950s America had just won The War and our economy was set to take off like a rocket. A tall, white, wealthy male would be the apex of power and prestige in that world. And yet we have a teenage Holden Caulfield who is depressed and disappointed by the phoniness and ugliness of his surroundings. If nothing else this novel reminds us that even those at the pinnacle of privilege have death and loss to deal with. Being sensitive and alienated can happen to anyone.

But it seems Holden takes things too far by flunking out of every school he is sent to and by failing to actually connect with anyone. Only his ten-year old sister is able to charm him out of his self-destructive moods.

Holden is a teen who sees grace and nobility in his younger sister, and in the memory of a younger brother who has recently died. At the previous boarding schools, a tormented student fell to his death, while wearing Holden's borrowed sweater. It's a graphic depiction of the thing Holden seems to want to do--catch children who are falling over the precipice from childhood to adulthood and save them--and therefore himself, before it is too late. Holden can't seem to find a worthwhile adult to emulate anywhere.

The language and the storytelling in this novel are brilliant. Old Caulfield is not really a phony. He smoked and drank, stayed up all night and traveled alone in ways contemporary teens raised by helicopter parents could never imagine. It was fun to hang out with him and try to understand.

review_headline: Where do the ducks go when the lagoon freezes over in the winter?
review_body:
The Catcher in the Rye is a novel about a man named Holden Caulfield who struggles to find his place in life. The story is about how Holden gets kicked out of prep school for the millionth time and must go home to New York and tell his parents. He doesn't know what to do because his brother Allie recently passed away, and he can't put his trust in anyone except for his sister Phoebe, who is barely a kid. He doesn't know what to do with his life, and the only thing he does want to do seems like an ideal that can never be realized. It is a very immersive and powerful novel, one that can open your insight to the cruel and overwhelming world around us.

Note: If you are annotating this novel it is Definitely worth it to get the Paperback version instead of the Mass Market Paperback.

This novel examines various themes that are critically important problems in society. One of my favorite themes in the novel is the idea of being "phony" or in other words being honest and sincere (or not). Holden always calls out others for being phony and can't stand them. However he himself is phony at times when he plays off these huge lies to people he doesn't even know.
Another huge theme that I love in this novel is the idea of being lonely, standing out, and not fitting in. Throughout the novel, Holden wonders where the ducks in Central Park go when the lake freezes over. This is beautiful, because it reflects Holden's own isolated image. He doesn't know where to go, because he doesn't belong in school, he has no work, and his parents don't want him home either.

One of the most precious parts about this book, I think, are the moments when I read a sentence -Just one sentence- and I just sit there for a while reflecting on the true meaning of what Salinger's words and what he truly wants to tell us. One example of this is when Holden talks about the phrase "Good luck". Read the novel to find out more!

review_headline: "Don't ever tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody."
review_body: The issue most readers will take with this book is that Holden is not entirely a likable character. However the outstanding feature of this book to me personally has always been its ability to take the whole concept of 'coming of age' and present it as a caricature by using extreme situations. Holden's thoughts flounder as he takes irresponsible decisions and revisits his previous life to find solace and direction. The lines from which the book takes its title are very beautiful and perhaps pregnant with meaning. This is an absolute classic and a joy to read time and again.

review_headline: he managed to do the Worst Possible Thing
review_body: It's not that it's not well-written, but it's so incredibly frustrating. I spent the whole book wanting to strangle Holden Caulfield. Every time he had a decision to make, no matter how many options he had, he managed to do the Worst Possible Thing. Every. Single. Time. I didn't understand how anyone actually could be so much of an idiot.

review_body:
This is another "classic" that didn't impress me that much. It's well written, but I just can't get over what a spoiled jerk Holden Caulfield is.

Some of the descriptions of New York were very good, and the dialogue with his sister was well done. I have many friends who love this book and really identify with it, but personally it didn't connect. Maybe if I were an angst-filled teen I would have enjoyed it more.

I have always loved this book. I have my students reading it and even the reluctant readers can relate to this book and enjoy it. Be prepared to explain some real life issues to your students. I always pre read a book before having a student read it. It's important to be aware of its content and language.

“The Catcher in the Rye” is the seminal and controversial novel by author JD Salinger (published 1951). It follows 16 year-old protagonist Holden Caulfield’s, experiences in New York having been expelled from an elite college preparatory school. The books theme deals with feelings of adolescent alienation. Holden speaks out multiple times in the book against what he perceives as the “phoniness” of other, and expresses a desire to either opt-out of modernity, to instead live as a recluse in a cabin in the woods, or to immaturely die for a noble cause. Rebelling against our parents and/or society’s preconceived ideas of ‘the norm’ or success is not exactly a new idea in literature but perhaps no-one has done it quite so well as Salinger does here. Salinger belongs to the “stream of consciousness” school of writers and so his prose are marvelously fluid like the inner most thoughts of his character. A curious side-effect of Salinger’s style is that it almost gives the reader the impression that all is happening in real time. It is a warts-and-all approach to first person narrative complete with 1950’s slang (eg. Flit, Crumbum, Shoot the bull) and repetition; the former works to accentuate Holden’s troubled conscience or madness. The whole effect to me comes across like Jazz. I was reminded while reading of Kerouac’s quote “the only people for me are the mad ones, the ones who are mad to live...” The books title is taken from the Robbie Burns poem “Comin thro the rye” (sung to the tune of ‘Auld Lang Syne’) as Holden misinterprets the lyric as "if a body catch a body" rather than "if a body meet a body," (he keeps picturing children playing in a field of rye near the edge of a cliff, and him catching them when they start to fall off). They haven’t made any film adaptions of the book to date (at the time of this review)…But I couldn’t help, while reading, making parallels between this book and a film called “Igby Goes Down” and was pleased to see, when reading other reviews, that I wasn’t the only person to draw the comparison. The plot was fairly eventless for my taste (and I suspect most modern readers would agree) unless you consider run-ins with prostitute, pimps, and scoring whiskey at late night wine bars as story worthy. BUT without doubt this is a beautifully written novel – a must-read. I had a chuckle to myself more than once while reading this book and appreciating Holden’s slightly slanted (yet familiar) adolescent view point of the world.
a must read every 30 years
quite possibly the worst book I've ever read.

When I realize that it's been about 20 years since I read this book and even then, it was considered old, one can only imagine if he were real, Holden would be about 80 years old. But the genius of this read is the sheer palpably real and convincing and charming as heck teen that he is--even in 2015. That's talent and Salinger really knocked it out of the proverbial park with this one. So it is no surprise that after so many years, I re-read this book (my nephew is now reading for the first time) and laughed and shook my head with sheer delight. The only downside is there really isn't a strong narrative here--just a day in the life of a teenager in the late 1940's. A real charmer, nonetheless.

I really cannot make out how I feel about this book. I thought it was really good and felt like by the end of it, my answers to life just should have been solved. I do not know if Salinger just wants the reader to adopt their own thoughts on it and determine how they feel about life.

As Holden said, there are so many "phonies" in life, yet isn't he really practically a "phony" himself? He constantly lies to himself and although he is mature in his ways, he constantly isolates himself from others.

The moral to the story, I think, is that you cannot change anything. You have to accept things for what they are, regardless of how much you want aspects of life to turn around.

I had a terrible time reading this novel. It was 277 pages of pure annoyance. I would have considered it engaging, however, I wanted to close the book every time I opened it. I decided to read the novel, because my mother recommended it, telling me she found it “funny”. She did fail to inform me that it would be the worst novel I would ever read. Fahrenheit 451 was not as bad as this. The novel was about as relatable as a chair.
This novel has no plot and no character development. Holden, the main character, has gotten kicked out of yet another school, Pencey, for failing every class, except English. This is ironic because his English made me want to tear my eyes out of my head.
From a literature perspective, this novel is appalling because there is very minimal use of literary devices, though when they are existent, it is extremely obvious. J.D. Salinger also does an amazing job at confusing the audience with terms that could mean anything or nothing at all.
If you are a person who enjoys listening to people go on and on about how much they hate almost everyone over and over again, this is definitely the novel for you!
I honestly wish I could unread this.

review_headline: (This same teacher also had us read Billy Budd by Herman Melville which we all pretty much hated back then
review_body:
I no longer remember my feelings about Holden Caulfield from (way) back in the late 1960s when I first read Catcher in the Rye for a high school English class. What I do remember is the controversy about this book in my home where my father deemed it NOT suitable for me to be reading. It was full of curse words, none of which I had ever heard in our home. There was mention of sex which was another taboo subject. But our teacher was fairly fresh out of college and she was looking to teach at least one au courant book from a touted living writer. I don’t actually remember how I got around reading it for my class....but I do recall the strife. (This same teacher also had us read Billy Budd by Herman Melville which we all pretty much hated back then. Perhaps that is due a reread also!)

So now here I am many decades later, having raised four children through high school and college myself, and here still is Holden Caulfield cursing away and deploring all the “phony” people in his life. And now my heart goes out to this confused and lonely fellow as he tries to deal with the disillusions in his life. This book no longer has anything remotely shocking in it for me...only now I can truly see the anguish of this youngster trying to handle adolescence. Holden is a sweet kid whose character J.D. Salinger has totally nailed in this book and I can see why it garnered the attention it did. I often found the intensity of emotion and Holden’s blunt analyses quite funny in the way that extreme exaggeration often is when it is meant in all seriousness at the moment it is being mouthed. Teenage angst and confusion lives on and, sad to say, has taken on much scarier forms than in this 1960s novel.

review_headline: overwhelming problems like getting expelled from his private school and horrible sexual ...
review_body:
In the book The Catcher in the Rye, written by J.D. Salinger, a high school challenged student Holden Caulfield talks about his difficult day while he stays in New York City. While he is there he experiences the phoniness of the society trying to deal with the death of his younger brother, overwhelming problems like getting expelled from his private school and horrible sexual experiences. The book is very easy to understand if you are a teenager because they are real life experiences. The book was over all an interesting book.

Salinger's writing in this book is excellent, he has real life characters, that don’t really need to be explained. This book is basically about the struggles that young adults have. The Catcher in the Rye is a straightforward and easy to understand. It is anything but difficult. The Catcher in the Rye is a book that can be loved and but then again misunderstood on many different levels. The book The Catcher in the Rye was wrote with great detail and explains good imagery throughout the whole book. Towards the end of the book Holden describes him walking down the streets and talking to his dead brother and it was just great imagery.
The plot of the book was great. Even though the setting was for one or two days it was very detailed. The narrator is the main character himself and it makes the book very interesting from telling it from that view. Throughout the book Holden goes through hard obstacles. He has a lot of flashbacks in the book which sort of explains why he does the things he does. In the book it does get a little confusing with the flashbacks but for the most part you can tell where and what Holden is doing. It is kind of difficult trying to figure out when the climax is but the important parts are self-explanatory.
The book is an over all interesting book. There are lessons you can learn. The Catcher in the Rye explains how you’re not really alone even when you shut someone out. In the book multiple people try to reach out to Holden but he rejects it. The book is also interesting because of the point of view it’s told. Salinger uses the slang that a teenager would use in the 50’s, in the book and it’s but different. Salinger kind of made is character contradicting because throughout the whole book Holden says the society is phony but, multiple times in the book. One time in the book Holden says, “I am always saying "Glad to've met you" to somebody I'm not at all glad I met. If you want to stay alive, you have to say that stuff, though,” But things like that make the book something you want to read.
Overall you should really read this book. Even though in the beginning the book was designed for adults but later on young adults cached on. The book was rejected and banned because of the actions Holden does in the book like, skip school, drink, smoke, sexual activities and profanity. You could understand why adults didn’t want teenagers to read this because teenagers could idolize Holden and want to be like him because teenagers are still trying to figure out who they are. This book should definitely be read and especially by teenagers because the book teaches you a lot.
Small ass book

review_headline: Not a masterpiece, but can be appreciated
review_body:
Recently, our Junior class read The Catcher and the Rye for a school project. Our teacher could not seem to stress enough that this book is renowned as a masterpiece of American Literature. As we read the book many of us could not figure out why anybody could read this book, as it has an odd dialogue beings that it was written in the 1950’s. But as the teacher said, the book would eventually come together, just at the very end. After finally finishing it, I cannot personally say that is should be recognized as a “masterpiece” but it does teacher a valuable lesson that everyone can relate to, and for that reason, I can somewhat understand its importance.

The first thing about his book that you’re going to notice is the writing style of J.D. Salinger writing from the point of view of a teenager. Since the book is kind of dated, there are words and phrases that are presented to the reader that show its age. For instance, the very loose vocabulary of each characters speech are spelled out in such a way that the reader can easily imagine the exact way a character says it in their mind. Things such as “wuddayacallit” and “chrissake” and “helluva” can be seen throughout the book. Though this book is easy to read and even easier to follow, there are some phrases that are repetitive as Holden is often seen trying to emphasize what ever he is saying quite frequently. An example of this is “I really do” or “I really this” and “I really that" can be seen on nearly every other page and gets old very fast.

As for the book itself, it is written as a first person account of past events that have taken place in the narrator’s life. At the very beginning Holden says that he is 17 years old explaining events that happened when he was 16. Reading through this book you will find that at each ending of each chapter there is no real personal reflection of the narrator until the very end of the book. It also does not attempt to wrap itself up to move on to the next set of events as most book seems to do. The story just seems to go continue on until the very end, as Holden just recollects each event in incredible detail. In my opinion, that was the hardest thing about reading this book, as there is nothing really spectacular or too interesting that seems to happen.

Despite this, there is a lot of controversy that surrounds this book for many reasons. Because of the content in this book, for a long time it was on the “banned book” list for school readings. A somewhat amusing thing about Holden is how much he curses. I am not over exaggerating when I say that there is a cursing on every single page of this book. If I could make a rough estimate of how much cursing there is in this book, I would say that at least 5% percent of every word in this book is bad. If you do the math, thats kind of a lot. But thats not the only reason that this book is surrounded with controversy. There have been a handful of murders associated or influenced with this book. Perhaps the most famous would be Mark David Chapman who patiently awaited for police to arrive after killing John Lennon, reading the Catcher and The Rye over his corpse. For some reason the influence of Holden Caulfield and his “everyone is a phony” mindset have inspired killer to try and assassinate other “phonies”

Regardless of what everybody is going to say, you are either going to love or hate this book. Me personally, I don’t like the story as much as I like the how it wraps itself at the very end. I cannot say without spoiling it, but the very last two sentences on the very last page is a truth that can be easily applied to Holden’s experiences as well as life. It can be perceived as both a happy and a sad ending and for that reason I think that The Catcher and The Rye deserves some recognition. I would not recommend this book to everybody, as some may not appreciate the point at the end as much as others would.

review_headline: Many of us have had that stage and we know what it’s like to act this way
review_body: The book, The Catcher in the Rye, is about a 17-year-old boy named Holden reflecting upon what happened a year ago when he was 16. Holden has gone to stay with his brother, D.B., after everything that has happened to him when he was kicked out of Pency Prep High School a year ago. Throughout the entire book, Holden is reflecting on himself, the things that he did and the person that he was one year ago.    Many people who read this book thinks it doesn’t have any rising action/climax or that it’s plane Jane. Holden isn’t meant to be likable. Holden is a character that is being consumed by him coming of age and it’s a time in his life that he is not very likable. Many of us have had that stage and we know what it’s like to act this way. The Catcher in the Rye isn’t a book about someone you want to be like or someone you want to be with, it’s about who you once were. It’s about protecting ourselves from the unstoppable march into adulthood.    It takes a lot for Holden to sit down and write us everything he went through at the time. He went through things with a prostitute Sunny, the questions he asks the cab driver, the fact that when he goes to “give someone a buzz” he looks through his phone book hand has no one to call and his relationship with his family. These are emotional things that Holden shares and that takes guts to just share with anyone.  I think it was easy for me to relate to Holden. It’s easy to focus on how he is feeling and the way he explains everything. I find that it is interesting to think the way someone else does, that’s probably why I enjoyed it so much.    Overall, this book was interesting and I liked it. I do recommend it to those that are sick of reading the same thing all of the time. The Catcher in the Rye may not have many ups as it has downs but it gives an insight on what it’s like when you’re young.  To deal with many “phonies” and influences around you when you are young.
I'm not really crazy about the main character. It is just ok

First off this is a review for my high school English class so yeah…Holden Caulfield is a teenage boy going to through many problems in his life and he sees the world in an extremely different way then a lot of people. He plays a character that is relatable to many teens which maybe why it appeals to many, but it did not appeal to me. Holden is a very mature teenager but has some issues mentally and with society and in this book I think he found his issues with society through his mental sorrow and expressed them to us which gave us the whole point of the book even though it wasn’t a very fast moving book.
This book did not catch my interest very well. In the beginning the book had some interest and some pace to it. I enjoyed hearing what Holden had to say about people and the world. Then about a fourth of the way through the book it flattened out and nothing happened that much. It was a very bland and monotonous book, and when I say monotonous I mean it felt like nothing happened or moved and it felt repetitive like just the same thing continuously.
What also didn’t help put the book into my list of favored, is I didn’t really connect with the main character (Holden). For me connecting is what makes the book. Holden had many problems throughout the book, and not just the book; his whole life seemed to have been surrounded with many conflicts. The conflict that he has gone through in life has made him the person he is today, and I haven’t gone through any of those problems so we aren’t the same kind of character.
The one thing that I liked about this book is the point of the book. I may have found a different point than what others may have but my point piggybacks off of the cover. In the book he sees himself as the catcher in the rye on the side of a cliff catching kids as they fall hence the name of the book The Catcher in The Rye.
I think the cliff symbolizes the “phoniness” of society and conformity. I feel like it also symbolizes the cliff of adulthood and he is saving the children from falling into the conformity and adulthood and phoniness of society.
My end review of this book is yes it is a good book, I would recommend you to read it if you can connect with the book. If you are like me and enjoy a book with some sort of pace and interesting parts then this book is defiantly not for you.

review_headline: This piece of literature held the resonance of symbolism
review_body:
This piece of literature held the resonance of symbolism. From an outside view without the use of symbolism this book would have literally nothing. The novel uses a sense of mystery and letdown to provoke thoughts. The thoughts on this are all trying to decipher the mind of a teenage boy trying to cope with his life and the things in it. This could really had been an intense novel but, in my opinion, something outside of his own mind would have had to happen for that to occur for me.
Holden’s thoughts and feelings reign over this novel and there is nothing else in him, but views and beliefs. Holden’s actions are far from reality and a lot of crucial details I believe are hidden or discarded because of this being written by “Holden.” I feel as though any embarrassment or actual travesties in the life of the character could have easily been removed for sake of feeling ashamed. At the same time, this piques my interest slightly at all of the things that could be hidden under the shell.
We know that Holden does not like the though of change because nobody was there to guide him through his life except for Allie. But, within this novel Holden undergoes plenty of experiences and memories that will change him through his life. The life style that Holden choses to live also turns me off of this novel because there are some choices that he makes that aren’t the wisest. I don’t think that I really appreciate unwise people as for much more than just entertainment. But, this wasn’t meant to be entertainment
This book was meant to have an impact on some people and the only impact that I can see from it is co-dependence on people, which isn’t exactly a good thing sometimes. If you depend on someone your entire life, what are you going to do when they’re gone? But, I also admire this book for protesting both sides. Because it also promotes independence in Holden’s ongoing battle with his own mind and finding his way after Allie left.
I thinkthis book is a “literature masterpiece” because it’s not specifically about a turn of event or anything like that. It’s about an internal struggle and nothing else. This book is raw, it shows exactly the things that nobody wants to say that they’re thinking and some of them I am one to agree with. This novel comes across in a variant of different ways and I respect it for that. In the grand scheme, I believe it deserves to be noticed but not nearly to the power that it is. I believe this isn’t a book for the commoner because they’re not able to process most of the information in this novel.
The “Catcher in the Rye” could possibly be one of the longest lasting tales considering it’s meaningful and will always have an impact on young readers. The novel expresses powerful views such as independence that young people need so young people will continue to respect and view this novel as great and should generally be handed out in schools by the stacks. While the story isn’t the greatest, the symbolism behind this story is wonderful.
IMO modern day coming of age books derived from the brilliance of this timeless novel. It's no wonder why it's resonated with so many readers.

review_headline: Some people rave about this book, but it is hard to see why. Maybe it was more interesting 50 years ago.
review_body: This book seems to be one you love or hate. In my case I found it stultifying, many years ago, but many people - mainly English teachers I suspect - seem to love it. In the US it is imposed on schoolchildren as a mandatory read, which is what brought it to my attention again. Poor kids.

review_headline: I don't get it, and probably never will.
review_body: I read this book \\"at the right time\\" as so many people say is a requirement to enjoying this meretricious \\"classic.\\" I was, in many ways, dissafected with the world at the time but this book spoke to no part of me. As I sit here now, the word \\"phony\\" is still ruined for me after more than a decade after reading this book.    I have tried, on and off, for several years to try to understand what I missed in this book that others seem to have found. I have even subjected myself to near torture by rereading it, but to no avail. I can see no value in this paperweight that fails at even that mediocre task.    Holden just seems to miss the point of everything. He doesn't grow or adapt or even learn from anything he has experienced. He isn't disaffected, he's a rich little s*** who thinks that anyone who doesn't meet his standards or do as he wishes them to is a (to use one of my least favorite words after this book) phony. He is spoiled and to try to impress another meaning on his actions and thoughts seems to be more than a bit of a stretch.    He doesn't ever realize anything. This book goes nowhere. There is no catharsis. There is barely even a conflict.    If you can get something, anything out of this book, then good for you. All I get was annoyed.
There wasn't even a rip or anything written in book and the shipping was fast!
Classic

review_headline: I was bored with the book
review_body: Even though a student of literature, somehow escaped reading at an early age.  Perhaps if I had, I might have related more closely to the character.  I was bored with the book.

I did not realize until I had finished my own coming of age novel (Bougainvillea Blues) that the voice of Holden Caulfield was the kind of voice I wanted for my first-person narrator. I had written my novel over a 20-year period and just decided to reread The Catcher in the Rye a few months ago and was surprised how much it had influenced my feel for the narrator's voice. I remember that Salinger's dialogue in his short stories was so admired by my acting teacher that we used to perform scenes from them with almost no editing, but I had forgotten how much I revered the writing of his novel. His is the gold standard. What was even more surprising is that I don't much like Holden Caulfield and yet Salinger managed to make me care what happened to him.

This is one of the most beloved books of the 20th century.  I really don't feel qualified to review a classic like this.  It is a great coming of age novel.  I had read it when I was probably in high school; but my husband never has, so I ordered this copy for him.  I'm 60 and this was pretty much a must read for my generation, the one before it and the one after me.  The author, J.D. Salinger (now deceased) was considered one of the great novelists of his era.  This book is very ingrained in American culture - there are many references to it in everyday life.  A good thing for everyone high school age and over to have read.
Gee.  I have had many copies of "Catcher" over the years and end up giving them away so the others can enjoy it as well.
good reading.

In all honesty, "The Catcher in the Rye" is not that great of a book. It was not absolutely unbearable, but in my opinion is a bit overrated. It drags on and on, but it does have some deep meaning to it. It is one of those books you either like or don't. There are better books out there. I strongly recommend "The Kite Runner" and "A Thousand Splendid Suns" by Khaled Hosseini.

review_headline: Pure Torture. A Colossal Waste of Time!
review_body: I had to struggle to give that one star. Salinger is, perhaps one of the most overrated authors I've ever read. The Catcher in the Rye is THE most dull, boring, cringe-worthy books I've ever had to force myself to read. I'd rather be locked into a school room with dozens of students raking their nails against a chalkboard hours upon hours. How this book could inspire someone to murder anyone is beyond me. The only person I wanted to murder was J.D. Salinger for the hours of my life I will never get back!  Honestly, I'd rather die than read this book again. Pure torture & a massive waste of time.

review_body: I didn't want to kill John Lennon when I finished reading it!!! It is really sad Chapman had it on him when he killed the most talented,enlightened humanitarian  of our generation because I was prejudice against the book due to that fact.  I finally read it and enjoyed it. I think the critics made too much of the so-called symbolism.  I think he was writing a story and wasn't trying to make symbols out of anything.  The story stands on its on merit.  I especially liked when he said the richer the students are the more they steal.  It was a good read and an easy style of writing which the reader won't get bored reading it.

To write yet another review on this book would be absolutely absurd. This story entered the consciousness of a generation on a grand scale. And sadly, used as an excuse for murder, not once but three times. A novel to be read, put back on the shelf, and picked up again, to reveal yet another interpretation. Truly a force in modern, American literature. HoeThere has been and continues to be so much praise for this story, that reading it again as an adult, some thirty years later, I wonder why it reached such literary- cult- status. True, Salinger is a master of characterization, as Holden speaks personally to the reader, whining, speculating and lost in an adolescent phantasmagoria, wanting to make good on his narcissistic delusions of saving the innocent. Tell me about an adolescent male who hasn't had fantasies of being a hero and protecting the innocent.

Catcher in the Rye is well written in the American Realist style, following Hemingway and perhaps, London or Fitzgerald. Similar to these popular American writers, they have universalized the zeitgeist of their particular generation. Salinger captured the voice of doubt, the angst of the American Sixties, that wanted to change the world, but ended up in the suburbs, raising kids and paying mortgages. More to the label of "baby boomers", ex- hippies turned liberal democrat.

Nothing really changed, civil rights and feminism yes, to a point, but fighting against the "establishment" brought nothing but violence, and now, post 9/11, we have come full circle, fascism in the guise of true freedom has arrived. Can Holden save us from the "PATRIOT ACT"? the "HOME SECURITY' fellows, making true agitators disappear; running a Goebbels style propaganda campaign, promoting Torture as a legitimate tool in War? No, Holden's concerns are real, in the historical context in which Salinger wrote it. Today, though, it reminds us only about the innocence of the time, flowers, free love and hazy pot. We have all lost loved ones, this does not make us want to kill, yet Holden's perverse view of the world, made him want to murder. Unfortunately, too, this story has been the motivation or excuse for not one but three assassinations, a deluded one man's attempt at "changing the world".

As an idealistic teenager, living in a perceived perverse society, Catcher in the Rye made me feel a notion of connectedness. The books relevance now is fog-like at best.

That said, a true representation of American realist literature at its peak in the sixties, and new writer's attempting to emulate it, ad infinitum.

If you love a good story, well written literature, and you have not read Catcher in the Rye, read it. Then again, if you have read it, particularly during the "Gory Days", read it again, you might be surprised.and hazy pot. Unfortunately, too, this story has been the motivation or excuse for not one but three assassinations, a deluded one man's attempt at "changing the world".

As an idealistic teenager, living in a perceived perverse society, Catcher in the Rye made me feel a notion of connectedness. The books relevance now is fog-like at best.

That said, a true representation of American realist literature at its peak in the sixties, and new writer's attempting to emulate it, ad infinitum.

If you love a good story, well written literature, and you have not read Catcher in the Rye, read it. Then again, if you have read it, particularly during the "Gory Days", read it again, you might be surprised.

Completely ridiculous that this book is banned for sexual content. There is hardly any. Yes it has a casual attitude towards sex yet it is such a great piece of teenage angst and so necessary for making that connection to how displaced young people really feel. This book SHOULD be read by everyone. And on top of that it's a quick read.

review_headline: Salinger and Caulfield: Icons for Adolescent Angst
review_body:
After being sucked into Holden's stream of consciousness for the last two days and just now making it out the other side, I suppose there are two or three things I'd like to mention.

First, the ducks, obviously. The cab driver had it all wrong, and all Holden wanted was a straightforward answer. The mallards that fleck the North American landscape are sensitive to changes in the food supply and model their migratory patterns accordingly, not unlike Homo sapiens prior to the advent of agriculture. For most of their history, humans have hunted and gathered where there was food to hunt and gather, schlepping off to new haunts as the seasons and weather dictated.

It's not that ducks don't have the ability to withstand the wintry conditions. Indeed, their thick feather coats serve as nature's perfect insulators. Rather, they follow the food. During the northeast winter, insects, fish and aquatic plants like duckweed become scarce as cold temperatures transform the local ecology.

Annual changes in duck concentrations can also provide clues as to the cold conditions from which they flew. A harsher winter will bring more birds south to the Mississippi River Valley, for example, to feed on plants and grass not covered by snow and in open waters not glazed over with ice. Due to the weakening of the polar jet stream brought about by changes in the global climate, we've been seeing more ducks nestled along the southern locales of North America in recent years.

That was all probably more than you wanted to know, but if someone had explained this to Holden in grade school it would have been one less thing bouncing around his busily eccentric mind.

Troubled Youth

Which brings us to Holden Caulfield himself and the man who created him. What strikes me about this novel is the nagging question of whether we are glimpsing inside the mind of Salinger or whether Holden is a cold-cloth fabrication. I suppose anything a person writes is a glimpse into their mind in a way, but we are always left to wonder how closely a book's characters resemble their creator. Is Holden's brooding disaffectedness a reflection of a lifelong angst and alienation suffered by Salinger?

Salinger was of course the quintessential enigmatic recluse, but that hasn't stopped commentators from speculating. We know he was born and raised in New York City, that he performed poorly in school—so much so that his father sent him to military academy in Pennsylvania as a last resort—and that he later joined the Army during World War II. Like so many others, the war seems to have had a profound and lasting influence on Salinger, who was hospitalized for nearly a year in Nuremberg. The unauthorized biographer Ian Hamilton suggests Salinger suffered a nervous breakdown in July 1945, which may explain Salinger's letter to friend Ernest Hemingway in which he mentioned almost being discharged from the Army on psychiatric grounds.

Autobiographical or not, Salinger's Caulfield is among those rarefied characters who have managed to compel readers for generations. Even those who don't necessarily connect with Holden tend to find his angst-ridden mirror on society irresistible. I don't see much of myself in his chronic repining over things big and small, and still I was drawn to him, like a car crash from which you can't quite look away. The "plot", if we can call it that, hardly extends beyond the inner recesses of Holden's mind. Indeed, his vortex of dread and relentlessly wry running commentary *is* the plot. He's the directionless teenager we all love to hate, and I think it's because wrapped up in Holden's embittered, existentialist essence is a version of our past or present selves we can't help but identify with.

I sincerely wanted Holden to course-correct and not let his overpowering discontent get the better of him. Maybe he would have been better off with a healthy dose of SSRIs and some counseling, or perhaps—given the subversionary role reversal in which he and his sister Phoebe are engaged in the closing section—he just needed to see himself from the outside looking in.

The Streisand Effect

I dug around a bit trying to find out why I didn't read this book in high school like everyone else. As it turns out, The Catcher in the Rye is one of the most censored books in U.S. history, which would certainly explain its absence on the reading list at the ultraconservative Christian school I attended. Apparently Holden's rebellious nature was (and still is) thought to be too infectious, his vocabulary too potty-mouthed and the sexual references too saucy. Atheism also pops up sparingly, with Holden self-identifying as an atheist and attributing the label to his brothers as well. Alas, it's safe to assume this numbered among the reasons many a school board fought for its proscription.

Of course, the Streisand effect all but guarantees that banning a work of art will only catapult its status far higher than it may otherwise have achieved. In any case, Salinger's best-known work is no worse for the wear, and excels in its own right. The frosty Holden is as captivating as he is cynical, and his penchant for slang and low-brow humor make for easy reading. It might have taken me longer than most to read this literary classic, but it was well worth the wait.his sister Phoebe are engaged in the closing section—he just needed to see himself from the outside looking in. I love this book, and here's one of the reason's why:
Holden is initially an extremely obnoxious and whiny character. Then he keeps slipping things from his past into his narrative: Oh, by the way, this horrible thing happened to me once. *story story story* Oh, and yeah, this one time, this OTHER horrible thing happened to me...
Until finally, you're thinking to yourself, "Why the heck did I judge him so harshly before?" and you want to go out and hug everyone who has ever annoyed you ever.
It's pretty heavy and depressing, but it's really beautiful and relevant and true. Love it.

review_headline: Another off my "Life List of Reading"
review_body:
I picked up this book for the Eclectic Reader Challenge and it ended up doing double duty as a read for a module on censorship and banning in a lit class I am taking this semester. It is one of those "Life List" books that I never read in high school but felt like I should.

The novel is a Holden Caulfield’s narrative of two days that he spends on his own in New York City. He has been expelled from yet another prep school, failing every subject but one. After a fight with his roommate, he leaves school a few days early and goes back to New York City. However, he knows that his parents will be furious about what happened and he chooses to spend a few days alone in a hotel before presenting himself at home for the holidays. His two-day rebellion is spent going to nightclubs and getting drunk or wandering the city, continually bemoaning the lack of intellectual companionship. He has a date with Sally, a girl from his past, and alternately falls in love with her and hates her… all on the same date. He is a boy who is clearly never satisfied with anyone or anything, continually in a state of discontent. His short time of rebellion has brought him no answers and no relief.

I really wanted to love this book, or at least appreciate it, but I just couldn't. It wasn't the dated language or ideas, but the complete lack of a character arc for Holden. With most protagonists, there is a certain arc of growth that takes place as the character goes through different experiences and situations and becomes changed as a person by the story's end. This really didn't happen with Holden and that lack of character growth is something that I came to realize I really appreciate in a novel and really missed in this one. Holden is intelligent, but comes across as a bit arrogant, perhaps a little too obsessed with himself as a barometer of intellect. For most of the book, Holden dismisses others as "phony" and casts aspersions on their worth if they don't live up to the personal standards he expects, standards that generally seem not to apply to himself. Instead of relating to Holden's character, I found myself continually annoyed by him and his seemingly complete lack of self-awareness. There was just no growth for Holden over the course of the novel, no change in behavior or thinking, no development. Other than his little sister, Holden seems to struggle to truly connect with anyone on any level. He spends most of the book whining about the fact that pretty much every person he meets is unintelligent and/or phony. He sees himself as intellectually superior to most people, judging others as phony for their interest in things he sees as inconsequential.

There is also much about his burgeoning sexuality and how that manifests itself, but there is never any development or resolution to that theme either. It seems as if he is not entirely comfortable with his own sexual awakening, often commenting about his myriad of chances to lose his virginity that are foiled by himself. He often objectifies women, but it is also clear that there is little behind it, more of an effort to fit in with the other guys in his school, rather than an accurate representation of his true feelings. This is seen in his almost obsessive anger towards his roommate when he finds out that Stradlater’s date is Jane, a girl from Holden’s past. He cannot stand the idea that Stradlater, a guy with a somewhat sketchy sexual history with women, would be with Jane, whom Holden seems to see as some sort of “above it all” standard of perfection. His thoughts on sexuality seem to be rather disjointed, one moment bemoaning his lack of experience and the next almost frightened by it. He does not push the issue with his dates and even during an encounter with a prostitute, he rebuffs the idea of intimacy, instead wanting simply to talk. In keeping with his rather disjointed ideas are his judgments on others’ sexuality, often seeing others “perverted.” There are also many moments when he questions the sexual orientation of those around him, showing a certain discomfort with the entire topic of sexuality.

In some ways, though, iit was an interesting read. The story is told as it flows from Holden's mind, at times very much of a stream of consciousness feel to it. The flow was often a bit disjointed and almost reminded me of the flow of Anthony Swofford's Jarhead book. But it is through this perspective and style of writing that we become privvy to the inner workings of Holden's mind. Yet, as the story unfolded, I still liked it less and less.

My Recommendation: Classic literature or not, it just didn't appeal to me. But I also think that is a matter of "to each his own." From a analytical standpoint, it was an interesting read, but it just didnt touch me in any way.ality, often seeing others “perverted.” There are also many moments when he questions the sexual orientation of those around him, showing a certain discomfort with the entire topic of sexuality.

In some ways, though, iit was an interesting read. The story is told as it flows from Holden's mind, at times very much of a stream of consciousness feel to it. The flow was often a bit disjointed and almost reminded me of the flow of Anthony Swofford's Jarhead book. But it is through this perspective and style of writing that we become privvy to the inner workings of Holden's mind. Yet, as the story unfolded, I still liked it less and less.

My Recommendation: Classic literature or not, it just didn't appeal to me. But I also think that is a matter of "to each his own." From a analytical standpoint, it was an interesting read, but it just didnt touch me in any way.

review_headline: All I want to know is if she still keeps her kings in the back row
review_body: This is a book about nothing. And I loved it.  Well, not strictly nothing. I guess it’d be better to say that it isn’t a book about anything in particular. Not anything except Holden Caulfield, our teenaged protagonist, who spends quite a bit of time in his own head and not very much time actually going out and doing the things he thinks about. Holden pretty much IS the book. If you like him, you’ll enjoy “The Catcher in the Rye,” but if you hate him, you’re not going to have a very fun time.  Fortunately, I liked him.  Let me tell you a little bit about what Holden’s like. He attends a fancy prep school in Pennsylvania that he’s just been kicked out of – he’s a smart kid but not really up to things like doing his schoolwork or turning it in. Plus he’s got a little brother who died of leukemia, a big brother who’s off in Hollywood writing for film (much to Holden’s disgust), and a little sister who he loves to pieces. However, Holden doesn’t have an equally strong relationship with his parents, so he decides to leave school a few days before his eviction date and hang out in his hometown, New York, for a while. Anything’s better than where he is, right?  Not really. Holden thinks about calling up some girls he used to know. He thinks about hiring a prostitute, just to keep him company. He even thinks about going to live in the wilderness, because anything’s better than New York (except school, of course). But guess how many of those things he does? You’ll have to read the book for the exact answers, though. Some of them may surprise you.  Here’s what surprised me: liking Holden. If you don’t read this and think, “This kid needs some help,” you might need a little help yourself. But even psychologically messed-up people can be good and kind, and Holden’s got more than a little kindness in him. You can see it in the little sister he adores (I happen to be a huge sucker for guys who love their little sisters, or their mothers, or even their dogs). You can see it in the way he wants to punch the heck out of anyone who tries to mess with Jane Gallagher. And you can even see it in the way he talks to people he meets on the street – well, some of them. Like I said, the guy needs help. A lot of it.  But then again, so do most teenagers, whether it’s Holden’s kind of help or something a little more subtle. And really, anyone who recognizes that Romeo and Juliet are in lust, not love (as Holden does) is a lot better off than a lot of so-called “normal” people anyway.

review_headline: The Catcher in The Rye Book Review
review_body: The Catcher in The Rye was written by J.D. Salinger and was published on July 16th, 1951, by Little Brown in New York, NY. Holden Caulfield is the protagonist of The Catcher In The Rye. He is portrayed by Salinger as a boy who is lazy and uncertain about his future. The story begins at Pencey Preparatory school, where Holden attends. In this first-person narrative, Holden describes life at this preparatory school as phoney, artificial, and dreary. After receiving yet another set of failing grades, he is expelled from the school. In an effort to 'find himself', Holden decides to head to New York City. He narrates his adventures there in a 3-day flashback, which forms the basis of Salinger's story.  I would recommend this book to people in high school and older. The book is sometimes hard to follow and can sometimes get slightly boring. The book can be inappropriate at times, which makes me think that the book would be better for an older crowd.   The story is about a 16 year old boy named Holden Caulfield.  His story starts from a mental institution where he is currently undergoing treatment for a nervous breakdown which he suffered after being kicked out of Pencey Prep, the high school he recently failed out of.  He had been kicked out of other schools before this, he continuously fails time after time. He is suffering from deep grief over the death of his younger brother, Allie, who died from Leukemia three years ago.  He cannot connect with his peers, he has no real friends at school, he fights with or criticizes everyone around him. He runs away from school and heads to New York City. He sneaks into his own apartment when his parents are out, he enjoys seeing his little sister, Phoebe, the only person in the book who he really trusts. He is afraid to grow up, he does not want to be an adult.  He would rather remain a child.  He dreams of being a catcher in the rye, literally catching children as they fall off  a cliff that is a symbol for childhood.  Holden wantsto keep children in the innocence of childhood.   The writer, Salinger, has a very unique writing style that I enjoyed. He gave Holden a very dry sense of humor that most teenagers can relate too. \\"And I have one of those very loud, stupid laughs. I mean if I ever sat behind myself in a movie or something, I'd probably lean over and tell myself to please shut up.\\" ― J.D. Salinger, The Catcher in the Rye. I find Holden to be a very realistic character that I think most people will like. As previously mentioned, Holden, the main character, is a 16 year old boy who dreads the reality of becoming an adult. He finds himself being depressed and lacking enjoyment in his life. Holden has never planned for his future and is now being forced to face it. He handles it by binge drinking and smoking, doing whatever he can to forget about his current problems.   Being the same age as Holden I found this book to be very relatable, with feeling the pressure of the future, dealing with our peers, and overcoming challenges from the past. His character changes drastically over the time period of the three days he writes about. Holden goes from a struggling teen in school, to a depressed, dependent almost adult like person. The book taught valuable life lessons and opens the eyes of the reader. Because of this, I think the book would make a great independent read for people my age.   Overall the ending of the book is somewhat predictable as you keep reading. I have an audience I would recommend the book too but I am worried that some may get bored by the book and not continue until the end, but the ending is what makes the book more memorable. That being said, the book is a classic that I feel everyone should read at some time in their life.

review_headline: Not worth it any more, surprisingly
review_body: This didn't hold up over time, ergo, not a classic. When I read it back in the early 60s, it seemed edgy and rather exciting. Now it's entirely dated. Holden Caulfield's use of "Old" to preface absolutely everyone's name gets tiresome, as does the use of "and all" at the end of every sentence. Rather like "y'know" in so many young people's speech these days, it simply shows a lack of vocabulary and imagination on the part of the speaker or, in this case, the writer. I'm sure Salinger was imitating what he heard on the street from teenagers but it's no more entertaining to read than dropping "y'know" and "like" every other sentence in a novel would be today. It took away from the story, too, which might otherwise have kept my attention. I couldn't finish the book, which really surprised me.

review_headline: Painful to have to read it a second time
review_body: I could honestly write pages and pages about how much I hate this book! I was forced to read this in a high school English class years ago, and I was utterly devastated I had to read it again for a college English class that focuses on YA fiction. I honestly don't know how I stayed relatively composed the second time around. I think my eyes are screwed up from the constant rolling.    I'm happy to see that there are enough people who stand with me in saying how horrible this book is. I reiterate their message in saying that it has no plot. Instead it is nothing but a rambling account of a teenage boy's stay in New York City after flunking out of his third or fourth prep school. Holden Caulfield is an immature, thoughtless, oxymoron of a human being that obviously is suffering from bipolar disorder. It's his constant mood swings that are the majority of filler for this so called classic. And I say he is an oxymoron because he hates everything in this world that he does himself. For example, he hates liars and calls them bastards, but I eventually lost count on how many lies he told to people. Also, he is shocked and offended when he sees the phrase \\"F@%* you\\" scribbled on walls in his sisters school, when it was his sister who told him to quit swearing when he was with her hours earlier. If this is the quintessential coming of age novel that everyone is calling it, then I'm terrified that there are teenagers out there that are just like Holden.    Salinger's style of writing for this novel is too repetitive and lazy. It may be impossible to count how many times something \\"killed\\" Holden or drove him crazy. The word \\"really\\" was constant as well, like \\"I hated it. I really did\\" or \\"it really was\\" or \\"I really do\\".    Thankfully, our professor has already expressed her desire to hear the negative feelings students may have about a book, along with the positive ones. We'll be talking about it later this week, and I can't wait to express my opinion.    I really hate thisbook. I REALLY do!

My initial reaction is that this book is the goddam phoniest book I've ever read.
My comparatively more objective reaction is that yes, this book is a breakthrough in that it brings to light the harsh realities, and hypocrisies, of adolescence, but in no way is this an example of literary genius, simply because it only shows the realities of adolescence, but doesn't seem to provide deeper analysis to these realities or hypocrisies. And, yes, there are some who will say that because J.D. Salinger purposely left the analysis of these realities to the reader, but I think that is not a valid excuse--especially if this is to be considered a "classic". All in all, this novel seems to be mostly surface-level, with few opportunities for much deeper analysis.
