review_headline: Universally relatable to adults and teens alike
review_body: The Catcher in the Rye is a perfect example of an American classic because J.D. Salinger creates a narrator who is universally relatable to adults as well as adolescents; Holden Caulfield is an emotionally damaged teen who is struggling to come to terms with his younger brother's death. While he is recovering, he loses his ability to connect to others emotionally, and his academics have suffered because of this. After being expelled from yet another boarding school, Holden brings the reader on a journey through Manhattan while he attempts to connect with women sexually, and to create friendships.  Holden purposely isolates himself from others because he is afraid to make an emotional connection; his method f protecting himself quickly creates a cynical outlook of the world, which is how he pushes people away so effectively. However, Holden's main emotion in the novel is loneliness. This emotion drives him to connect with others, but his fear of connection prevents him, causing him more pain.  This novel is an accurate account of how emotional pain can lead to isolation and depression. Many people, adults and adolescents alike, suffer because of the loss of a loved one. Because Holden exhibits these qualities, people can relate to his struggle on a personal level. Even if a person does not have emotional pain, they will be able to relate to Holden's bipolar mood swings because most teenagers have experienced those emotions. All in all, the Catcher in the Rye is a novel that anyone who reads it can relate to, and recites an intriguing journey of a teenager attempting to obtain a meaningful connection with a person .  I strongly recommend that everyone read this novel because it can be an inspiration and comfort to anyone undergoing personal troubles and grief.

review_headline: Good writing, but I cannot stand the main character
review_body: Good writing, but I cannot stand the main character. He's really awful. I dunno. Read it so you can have your own opinion on the classic.

This book is the classic story of a lonely man looking for love and company in a harsh world. The protagonist, Holden Caulfield, is a man whom no one understands and who feels isolated inside his own world. This character is very similar to Christopher McCandless from the novel Into the Wild. The book is easy to read and understand, with not too complicated vocabulary. There is a lot of dialogue which is refreshing and interesting, more so than reading inner thoughts pages at a time.

Before I started reading this novel, I wish I knew what time period the novel was set in. The only indication is in the quote: "He got leukemia and died when we were up in Maine, on July 18, 1946." This sentence would be easy to look over and not think about the significance. Other than this, there is no clear indication of the time period as the details of time are very vague. However, the time period is not extremely important to the story.

This book would be good for someone who is interested in stories in which the protagonist has a major inner conflict with himself in a completely realistic story that could happen to anybody. If one was a fan of the book Into the Wild, then The Catcher in the Rye would be a good choice. However, there is some harsh and inappropriate language so I do not recommend this novel for young children.

I gave The Catcher in the Rye 4 out of 5 stars because knowing the time period of the story is very important to me so I can be completely immersed in the novel. I glazed over the one mention of the time period so I was left in the dark for the entire novel. However, everything else in the novel was done spectacularly to make you feel like you are living as Holden Caulfield in his world.

review_headline: Personally, I Don't Want to be Anywhere Near the Likes of Holden Caulfield.
review_body:
Stop me if this sounds familiar to you: Across Five Aprils, The Great Gatsby, Romeo and Juliet, Lord of the Flies, A Wrinkle in Time, The Catcher in the Rye, To Kill a Mockingbird, Animal Farm, ...

Yep, it's a staple of books required by middle and high schools across the country. One thing they all have in common is how overrated these books are. The Catcher in the Rye might be the most pointless book I've ever read.

When I was 15 and a freshman, I was like, "What the hell is this?"

Basically, the story is about a 16 year old loser who is such a phony pathological liar that complains about everything he sees and embellishes what he is experiencing or has experienced. A sign of mental illness, he goes on and on in a rambling voice laced with lots of profanity remembering about past worthless events and acquaintances he's had by using the same poorly written sentence structure repeatedly. Also, he is so obsessed with his 10 year old sister like I can't believe.

At first, the reading is bearable, but, by page 150, I just get mad and want to chuck it out of the window because he says NOTHING useful or relevant. The only thing I can say is, "Who the F cares, Holden?" He pathetically tries to act like a young adult who is all of a sudden so worldly and know-it-all.

When I was at his age, I had accomplished a lot of things in my life and saw life differently in a positive way, knowing I had more left to go. But it's so damn stupid to read about this spoiled, privileged, and idiotic boy criticizing everything because they don't meet his BS standards. Pretty much, I want to grab Holden by his labels and encourage him to get a gun and have an accident with it.

All in all, I wish The Catcher in the Rye was a baseball book that many thought it was.

It took me a few decades to get around to reading this classic, but it was well worth it.  Very insightful, very realistic portrayal of teenage angst.  It is effectively written - one gets a feeling for Salinger, as much as for Holden Caulfield, with some insight into what was going on in Salinger's head.

This winter the ducks were there!
I wonder if "The Catcher in the Rye" will have the same impact on the current generation of high school students.

Catcher in the Rye
When books are placed on a banned list in many states it is usually for a lot factors adding up, such as inappropriate language or actions, themes highlighting problems and issues that teenagers could face or even exposure to the harsh realities of life. To many that spells trouble but to me it sounds like the perfect recipe for a captivating book. Most think it is a good idea to sugarcoat books but I like the honesty and themes that are portrayed in the stories like Catcher in the Rye. It doesn’t shy away from realistic scenarios like under aged drinking, troubled school dropouts, or insane asylums. The story’s New York in the 1950’s setting paints the scene for Holden Caulfield and his troubles. His first person flashback narrating gives us an in depth look at his personality and reasoning for things but even with the narration type we are still left with questions and curiosity about Holden because of things he does not reveal to us or things he doesn’t even understand himself. Even with this book’s edgy atmosphere many of the themes displayed throughout the story are types of innocence that Holden shows whenever faced with a strange or different situation he isn’t familiar with. At one point Holden is in his hotel room in New York and pays a prostitute, she doesn’t appear to be any older than him and sge refuses things like a cigarette and informs Holden she doesn’t smoke “It was a funny thing to say. It sounded like a real kid. You'd think a prostitute and all would say ‘Like hell you are’ or ‘Cut the crap’ instead of ‘Like fun you are.’” Another theme that arises is the theme of love or lust when Holden is constantly thinking about an ex-girlfriend of his and he is constantly faced with situations that force him between the two. All together I thought the book was a fantastic story that let the character fully develop and showed us his angel and devil on the shoulder type of personality.

review_body: When I was 16, this book was banned from my high school. Being a closeted rebel (it was the 60's then), I covered my copy in a brown grocery bag and took it to school. This book changed my life at 16. Many, many years later, I reread Rye. At that point in my life, I didn't get much out of it and was so disappointed. However, at a reading literature conference, the presenter reminded me that I was in a different place in my life and I didn't need Holden's wisdom. That made me feel so much better about recommending Rye to teens.

review_headline: Thou Shalt not be Corny or Phony
review_body: This classic turned my life upside down in changing everything I knew about New York and America. Granted, I had been jaded and disillusioned for a while, and hopelessly skeptical even longer. Now I simply walk around introducing myself as Holden, and qualify my impression on everything as corny, phony, or both corny and phony.

The Short:
To sum up my feelings about this book in three words: I loved it. This is one of the best books I have ever read, and I was so entertained by Holden, and his mentality. So good.

The Good:

Like I said before, Holden was absolutely hilarious. Whenever he said that he was doing something, "like a bastard" I died laughing. His overall outlook on things is very negative, and I really found it entertaining. Also, I think I am Holden Caulfield, so I can't really say anything bad about him without insulting myself too. And honestly, that would be pretty phony of me.
The book was so fast. It literally took place over like two or three days, but it felt like it was a month. I loved it.
I'm just going to be vain for a second, and say that I LOVED HOLDEN'S HAT!
I just loved the direction that the story moved in. It was really what I wanted to happen, and honestly for Holden's development as a character and as a person, it needed to take that direction.
All the symbols, and themes, and metaphors, and all the other literally devices really killed me.

The Bad:

That ending really killed me. It wasn't satisfying enough for me. He is happy, then boom its over. And he mentions that stuff went down, but he doesn't explain, and I'm like "BB Plz gimme moar."
Phoebe was so annoying. I just couldn't handle when she was around, and I just thought her overall demeanor, while she was somewhat close to Holden, was annoying.

To sum this review up, I wish I would have bought the trade paperback rather than the mass market one because I just love this book so much that I think that I should have the nicest copy possible.

review_headline: I would recommend this book to anyone who is looking for something ...
review_body:
There are few books which are able to grasp the true nature of our human behavior. Salinger had the ability, through the eyes of a rebellious teenager, Holden Caulfield, to show the pains of alienation, loneliness and internal struggles. This book seemed to grasp me and speak to me as if it was intended for that sole purpose. The vulgarity of language used, I suppose, could be considered offensive to some. Be aware. However, I found the timing, meaning and angst in which is was used painted the picture of the story a little more vividly for me.

I would recommend this book to anyone who is looking for something more in their life and don't quite know what it is. To anyone who wants to find "themselves" they may just find parts of it in The Catcher in the Rye.

review_headline: An overrated and seldom questioned part of the American canon
review_body: This book is not great literature, but rather it is a gift to English teachers because it has all the elements of a book that is easy to teach.  1) its protagonist is a teenager like the students assigned to read it  2) the stream of consciousness style makes it easy to read  3) the musings of the protagonist range widely giving the teacher a great deal of easily accessible material for discussions, and likewise students are presented with much low hanging fruit for their papers. For these reason Catcher will always be taught and introduced to new generations  of high school students ( Middle Schools teach The Outsiders for the same reasons) At this point it has attainted an "emperor's new clothes" status where its worth is almost never questioned.  But thankfully a few are brave enough to ask what the book is really about. The New Yorker article Holden at 50 (October , 2001 )  pointed out that the thoughts of Holden , closely considered, are not those of a teenager at all, but of a middle-aged novelist.

review_headline: Author of a coming of age story gives this book a thumbs up.
review_body: I read this book once and then read it again a few months later. The first time I read it I couldn't understand what all the hype was about and why or how this book became so popular. I did some research on the author and then realized what the book was about. Authors write with the idea of conveying a message, but sometimes the complexities of the writing process along with subconscious inputs makes it hard to grasp by a new reader. Understanding the writer makes it easier to know what he/she is trying to communicate. To be an adult and write like a depressed teenager is truly a tough job. With that known, I think J.D Salinger did an amazing piece of writing.

review_headline: Catcher in the Rye BOOK REVIEW!
review_body:
This is a short book about a teenage rebel named Holden Caulfield who is getting expelled from yet another school. The story spans in just a few days and follows Holden as she talks with with a wide choice of characters. After getting expelled from school some drama ensues which made hold leave school earlier than he was supposed to after his expulsion. He ends up getting a crappy hotel room before going out on the town to drink, smoke, and he even ordered a hooker. As the story goes on you learn more and more about Holden and what makes him tick.

My Thoughts: I enjoyed this story even though nothing really exciting happened the whole time. I however found the main character Holden very funny and found myself laughing at the trouble he seemed to get himself into. The whole book was full of teenage angst and I felt like I understood Holden.

My Favorite Quotes from the book:

" The mark of the immature man is that he wants to die nobly for a cause, while the mark of the mature man is that he wants to live humbly for one."

" If you want to, and if you look for it and wait for it-to the kind of information that will be very, very dear to your heart. Among other things, you'll find that you're not the first person who was ever confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior."

Teenage years kind of suck in a way, but if you get out of your head and just live...it's the best time of your life, I promise!

review_headline: The most misunderstood book in all of literature...
review_body:
There is a literary critic named Robert Paul Lamb who wrote two superb books on Ernest Hemingway (you can find them [[ASIN:B0043M5RPY here]] and [[ASIN:B00AMM5OB6 here]] ). In the introduction to the first book, Art Matters, Lamb tells a story: when he was young he loved the writing of Ernest Hemingway but, when he got to graduate school, he began to read more \\"sophisticated\\" writers - or writers who were deemed more sophisticated by the academy - authors like William Faulkner and James Joyce. Lamb still cherished Hemingway but he began to look down on him to some degree as less sophisticated or as less of an artist. Lamb wound up rereading Hemingway later in life, rediscovered his artistry, and he wrote two books analyzing Hemingway's craft - and I think they are two of the best books of literary criticism I have ever read (and I have never liked Hemingway all that much).

I had a similar experience with The Catcher in the Rye. I read it as a teenager and I loved it. I then read it again in my early twenties and I still loved it. For a long time I would have considered it my favorite work of fiction. Then I went to school for philosophy and I also began to read \\"more sophisticated\\" writers like William Faulkner and James Joyce. I still held a special place in my heart for The Catcher in the Rye but I also felt as if I had outgrown it to some degree. I think that is the image that a lot of people have of this book: that it is a book for angsty teenagers and, once you are past that stage, it no longer has the same impact. I think that is totally wrong - I think this book has as much substance as any work of fiction ever written - and, strangely enough, it was William Faulkner himself who convinced me of that.

I was browsing through a volume of William Faulkner's lectures [[ASIN:0813916127 Faulkner in the University]] and I noticed that Salinger was mentioned in the index, and I found this quote, \\"I have not read all the work of this present generation of writing...So I must speak only of the ones I do know. I am thinking now of what I rate the best one: Salinger's Catcher in the Rye, perhaps because this one expresses so completely what I have tried to say: a youth...must someday be a man, more intelligent than some and more sensitive than most, who...because God perhaps had put it there, loved man and wished to be a part of mankind, humanity, who tried to join the human race and failed. To me, his tragedy was not that he was, as he perhaps thought, not tough enough or brave enough or deserving enough to be accepted into humanity. His tragedy was that when he attempted to enter the human race, there was no human race there\\" (244).

And, speaking about Holden Caulfield, Faulkner said \\"his story was an intelligent, very sensitive young man who was - in this day and time was an anachronism, was almost an obsolescence, trying to cope with a struggle with the present-day world which he was not fitted for, when he didn't want money, he didn't want position, anything, he just wanted to find man and wanted something to love and he couldn't. There was nothing there. The nearest he came to it was his sister who was a child and though she tried to love him she couldn't understand his problem\\" (246-247). I think Faulkner's comments on the book are quite insightful - they completely contradict all the negative reviews of this book that label Holden Caulfield a \\"spoiled brat\\", etc. - and they convinced me to reread the book and, far from finding that I had \\"outgrown\\" it, I found that many of its profoundest and most beautiful aspects had escaped me in my first two readings. I would like to share some of them.

The story is obviously about Holden Caulfield. Holden is obviously a depressed and lonely teenager. Many people who read the book feel Holden's loneliness is a result of a kind of misanthropy - he hates people, he finds them all \\"phony\\", and he cannot stand to be around them. This is why, I think, some people seem to have such a negative reaction to the book and wind up dismissing Holden as just a spoiled brat. I am not a developmental psychologist but, at least in popular consciousness, we all seem to believe that teenagers go through a phase where they hate everyone and think they are smarter than everyone. This book is often dismissed as being nothing other than an expression of that attitude, but I think that is a total misreading of the book. People who read the book in that way never stop to ask \\"What is it that Holden \\"hates\\" about humanity?\\"

Well, Holden hates \\"phoniness\\". But what does he mean by phoniness and why does he hate it? He hates that, in all of his social interactions, people are always putting on airs, trying to impress. What Holden craves is some kind of genuine human interaction, something beyond showing off. He is looking for the genuinely human which is why I think what Faulkner has to say about the novel is spot on. He loves that his old girlfriend Jane used to refuse to move the kings in the back row when she played checkers. The fact that Jane refused to move her kings is something that makes her unique, but no one else seems to care about it or find it interesting. For Holden, other people's values are misaligned: people are impressed by someone who is strong, excels at academics, can throw a touchdown pass, but they ignore and find no value in our shared humanity, in our shared weaknesses and idiosyncrasies. Stradlater does not care that Jane does not move the kings in the back row, he just wants to sleep with her, and in order to do so he plays a game, puts on a facade, etc. It does not matter to him that there is no genuine connection as long as he gets what he wants.

That is what Holden hates, and it is why he gets in a fight with Stradlater. Far from being a sign of Holden's \\"hate for humanity\\" it is a sign of his \\"love for humanity\\". He loves all the things about people that everyone else finds worthless. He loves their eccentricities, their vulnerabilities, their weakness. He does not care about all the things that people like to brag about. He cares about what makes us human and unique. The reason he is disgusted by humanity is because he cannot find anyone else in the world who values those things. Society destroys the weak. He tells a story about a fellow student in his speech class The student was a nervous, shy type, but when he would go off on tangents about his uncle he would get excited and animated - he was talking about what he loved. Rather than encourage that, the students were taught to yell \\"digression\\" whenever the speaker went off topic. The process of socializing a human being into a productive member of society - someone who stays on topic - is deemed more important than encouraging an individual's unique humanity. That is what Holden finds disgusting.

All through the book, Holden is desperately trying to find some genuine connection with someone, to have a social interaction that is not based purely on trying to impress or outdo one another - and he fails. He attempts to express his despair, but no one is capable of reading the subtext of what he is saying - it all just leads to more misunderstanding. He is talking with Sally Hayes and he starts to form all these plans about running away to the wilderness with her. The subtext of what he is saying is, \\"I am miserable! I need to get away from this suffocating atmosphere!\\" but Sally does not hear any of that. All she can think of are all the practical problems with Holden's plan. Instead of trying to comfort him or telling him things will be okay - which is what he really needs to hear - she starts to poke holes in Holden's plan, which only increases his despair. The book is full of poignant and beautiful moments - glimpses of our shared humanity, which is usually hidden behind the masks that we put on. Holden is like someone searching for a flower in an industrial wasteland and, whenever he thinks he sees one, someone comes along and stomps on it out of carelessness, or rips it up by its roots, or simply ignores it. This book is NOT a denunciation of humanity - it is a cry for humanity, and a very moving (and funny) one.less. He loves their eccentricities, their vulnerabilities, their weakness. I admit, the book is dated. It is. It was written in the '50s. Holden uses outdated slang, which may be semi-confusing to the modern teenager.
And yeah, Holden does whine. To be short, the book isn't very modern, and it may be hard to see how it could be useful today.
However, Holden is very well written. In most books, I have a hard time feeling like the character is real, and they usually feel sort of... fake, as if they don't have a voice. Holden has a very strong voice. He curses a lot, complains about things, makes random observations, etc. I mean, the first page has him complaining about things he hates. The book does a good job of making him feel real, of giving him a voice. The way the story is told makes you feel like your Holden's friend, and he's talking directly with you. The first sentence in the book goes, "“If you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably want to know is where I was born, and what my lousy childhood was like, and how my parents were occupied and all before they had me, and all that David Copperfield kind of crap, but I don't feel like going into it, if you want to know the truth.”
And yes, although it is a very outdated sort of novel, the character of Holden, his way of thinking, his voice, how he does things, are VERY modern and relevant, and could very easily apply to today's teenagers. I know. I'm currently 15, and I can honestly say, some things Holden says sounds creepily like something kids in my high school, or my friends, or even myself may say or think. Trust me, I'm almost 16, I can truly vouch that this is some of the things we think.
Holden speaks to issues relevant to my generation; fear, anger, sexuality, smoking, drinking, depression, loneliness, hating yourself and most things, loss of innocence, love, relationships, etc.
This is probably one of my favorite books, as he's a character I believe we all can relate to, at some point in our lives. I will be the first to say that, no, it's no longer modern or controversial. Part of the problem is time. Much more relevant books (like 'Perks of being a wallflower", for instance) are out there, with modern slang, and a relatable setting (unlike in New York, where the story takes place.) Another is acceptance by adults. Part of what made "Catcher" great is that no adult liked it, back then. It was rude, had copious amounts of smoking, drinking, cursing, etc. Now that we're in a slightly more liberal age, this is less shocking, and unfortunately it's become a "classic", aka a book no kid will like. By assigning it, teachers took away its power and message.
It's still an amazing book, tho. Read it. Try to get past the datedness, and focus on Holden's message. You probably won't, tho. "People never notice anything."

LOVE IT!

I can best describe this novel as a two-day Forrest Gump, because the protagonist (Holden Caulfield) relates to the reader multiple experiences he has, both real and imaginary (or recalls them from his past) over a two-day period as he packs up and heads home to NYC after being expelled from an all-boys prep school. Caulfield expresses both contempt and admiration for people and situations he encounters, and describes his annoyances, bewilderment, insecurities, frustrations, sadness, and pleasures in infinite and exhaustive detail. At various times throughout the novel, Caulfield dons a red hunting hat, positioned in such way to reflect and assert his state of mind at any given time.

Very easy reading, albeit tedious at times. When Salinger eludes to something, you know exactly what he is talking about, from your own life’s experiences, perceptions, attitudes, and personal biases. Needless to say, I highly recommend this book. It’s most unfortunate that those who gave the book only one star “just don’t get it.”

It’s a book about kindness. Missing kindness. Looking for it, stumbling over it, clamoring for it. Wanting it. Wanting to give it. At that age when everything is so scary and confusing. It seems easy, and it isn’t. it isn’t easy, yet it is. And there is nothing much to go off of, but you and your own thoughts and fears and longings and terrible terrible doubts. So much sensitivity, and nobody to share it with. So much loneliness. Didn’t we all have it when we were 18? Didn’t we all go through it?

I felt for Holden, and that catcher in the rye poem, that catcher in the rye image, that thing he wanted to do, catching, it made me cry. It makes me cry even now. Holden Caulfield, 18, flanks out of Pencey Prep, a private school full of dolts and morons. Of course he does. Nothing makes sense. Nothing has any purpose. Everything is boring. Nobody understands him. So he sets off to go home, scared of what his parents will think, him flanking out of school again. Good parents. Good home in New York. How he gets there, what happens when he does, all around Christmas time, through the snow and cold and the Central Park with a frozen pond, that’s where you’ll go reading this book. I’ll leave you here. It’s a beautiful journey. And the ducks? I’m still wondering about the ducks. You’ll know what I mean once you read it.

review_headline: This Book Made Me a Madman.  It really did.
review_body:
I knew when I started "The Catcher in the Rye" that I might miss some of the meaning given that I was probably reading it 15 years too late. However, I soon found out that I might have completely given up on the book during high school because Holden Caulfield is so annoying that I cheered when first his roommate and then the pimp beat him up. Getting through this book wasn't a chore, but having waited for over a year with this book on my shelf I felt the need to finish just to see what all the hype was about. Frankly by the end, the only character in the book I had any sympathy for was Phoebe given that she had no clue that her brother was nuts.

I attempted to think deeply about various symbols or themes in the book, but I soon found myself with a headache trying to figuring how critics could think anything of importance was being written. After 214 pages, I can say without a doubt this book is all hype and will soon be sold to my local used book store.
Great reading for kids and beyond.

review_headline: This book is perfection! Kudos, Salinger!
review_body: I read this book for the first time when I was sixteen and there's just no going back once you've been introduced to a world of literature where you can relate to a character on such a personal level, like I had Holden Cauldfeild. I couldn't allow myself to become too obsessed with this book because I had heard that many serial killers like this book a lot and another one of my favorite singers who was obsessed with suicide would bring it with him on all his tours. But I think that fact just further proves that there is something so much deeper to this story than just a seventeen year old spending a few days in New York. Holden Cauldfeild can be described as nothing less than captivating. His thoughts are the same kind of thoughts that go through every matured teenagers mind before getting sucked into the inevitable black hole that is adult-hood. Before mindlessly giving into the the nine to five. Holden had a clear perspective on things as far as a was concerned in my adolescent days. Now I'm twenty-one and I go back and realize...well, he was probably missing out on a lot of relationships and experiences by being so judgmental and cynical. But in the end, he was perfect and I wouldn't change him. My favorite fictional character in the world. JD Salinger spent 10 years writing this book and it is an absolute masterpiece. I Have yet to read a book that inspires me in the way that this book did!

I’m really not sure how I managed to live almost half a century without reading this classic. But, I’m glad I finally gave it my time and not just to say “Catcher in the Rye, of course I’ve read it” with that phony tone of voice that Holden Caulfield would’ve g*dd@m hated.

I admit that early on I really didn’t understand all the accolades that surrounded Salinger’s most popular novel. Holden appeared to be a whiny, judgmental, young man who swore too much, smoked too much, drank too much, and needed a serious come to Jesus talk, yet the adults in his life that seemed to care were dismissed as soon as they tried to do so.

Then Holden makes an impulsive decision that eventually sends him spiraling, revealing a sensitive young man crying out desperately for help. Salinger carefully sets up Holden, and the readers, to finally acknowledge that this soulful boy is broken.

Catcher in the Rye tore at my heart, making me ache for this child, that tragedy seemed to follow like a shadow.

Somehow, unlike everyone else in America, I never read this book in high school.  I'm glad I waited until now, at the age of 54, because if I had read it in high school, I would have absolutely and unreservedly detested it --- in fact, I would have simply refused to continue reading it after the first few pages, so rife it is with profanity, dumbness, laziness, meanness, and tons and tons and TONS of teenage angst.  For some bizarre reason, however, reading it at age 54, I couldn't put it down.  For one thing, it was just darned funny in spots.  It is difficult to make me laugh, but this book actually had me laughing out loud.  Yeah, the main character is repetitive and annoying and utterly unjustified in his general contempt for virtually everyone and everything in the world, but he is extremely insightful in his own way, and I just had to keep reading, to find out what the next insightful or bizarre thought would be going through his head.  Plus, I really wanted to find out what happened to Jane.  The 16-year-old me gives the book zero stars, the 54-year-old me gives it four.

review_headline: Still speaks to the reader, even the middle-aged...
review_body: though time and age give me a much different perspective of young Holden Caulfield.  In my opinion, the \\"story\\" presented in the novel is not particularly enthralling, but the development of young Holden is genius - and I really don't intend that as hyperbole.  Salinger masterfully presents the reader with the ever-present teen angst and uncertainty in Holden, which for me became the essence of the story.  I was amazed at how - even as those years of teen angst are long behind me - I was able to sympathize with Holden as he grappled with his sense of frustration with his world.  Even as an adult this is a story worth reading, or re-reading as it were.  Makes me wonder, maybe the perspectives of the middle-aged male aren't so different from his 16 year old counterpart after all...?

review_headline: One of my favorite books of all time
review_body: A true classic. One of my favorite books of all time!

“Undead. There’s a word I really hate,” I sighed. “It’s phony. I could puke every time I hear it. And furthermore, what’s with all these vampires?”

“I like them,” said Phoebe.

“Vampires are alright, I guess — but they don’t appeal to me,” I said. “I mean they’re alright if they go around flying off with lonely girls all the time, and like that, but you don’t do that kind of stuff if you’re a vampire. All you do is stay in your mansion and buy cars and drink blood and look like a hot-shot. And besides, even if you fly around with girls and all, how would you know if you did it because you really loved them, or because you really wanted to drink some girl’s blood, the way it is in horror movies?”

“Daddy’s going to kill you. He’s going to kill you,” she said.

“Well, of course he is. I mean, that’s pretty much his prerogative, isn’t it? Since he got bitten and all. Here I am, fresh meat, just waiting for him to deliver the kiss of undeath and turn me into him. Vampires are the worst. Sometimes, I imagine all these little kids playing some game in this big field of vampires. What I have to do, I have to chuck garlic at the vampires. That’s all I’d do. Vampire balloon darts, all day long. I know it’s crazy, but that’s the ... http://the-toast.net/2014/05/30/holden-caulfield-the-vampire-chronicles/

review_headline: this is a very famous book, banned in libraries/schools.  MUST READ!
review_body:
NOTE: I will give a very mild rundown of the book but wont give details. SO you can read my review and still read book. I won't "Spoil" it for you, lol and wont tell you in order the events take place.

What can you say about the #1 banned book in public school libraries and maybe even libraries period. You can say this---even after all these years, it still sells millions of copies all over the world. Rather than ban the book, and pretend life is not difficult sometimes, I think schools should read and discuss, and maybe talk about ways various things could be handled, how to get help, who to turn to, etc. In a nutshell, the reason its banned isn't because of language, sex, drugs, rock and roll, its banned because its about a teen age boy who is expelled from school (numerous times) and doesn't seem to like anyone or anything. He is very critical and very disillusioned with life and how "phony" people become. He leaves the school a few days early and its Christmas time in NY so its cold. He left impulsively and doesn't know what or where to go. He goes to a teacher he liked and who he trusts only to find a strange situation that scares him so he leaves. goes to a hotel and has a hooker come to room, and he realizes he is afraid of (he is a virgin) sex, and decides he just wants to talk. She is angry about the time he is taking, (she has customers waiting) so he pays her the agreed upon money and she is angry and sends her pimp up to get more. Calls an old girlfriend, but that doesn't work out too well, so He goes home and sneaks in the house (mom and dad cannot know he is home because they will wonder WHY==and sees his sister. She knows immediately and says "dad will kill you", (figuratively not literally) and they come home, so he hides and then sneaks out. He is so negative about life, but he loves his family and he has dreams for the future. Some are unrealistic, but he dreams. The title came from a song he heard children singing and the answer to a question a date asked him after she said you don't like anything and want to be nothing , and he said yes I do, so she said, "name one thing" so he expalins. You have to read for yourself.

So far I don't understand why. But the book tells the story of a teenager much like my own, I can recognize both characters, thoughts, events and reactions from my own youth having passed 5 years in a boarding school in Finland during the 1940-ies.

review_headline: Holden : Great friend and lover of us all
review_body: "Holden" was trying to share with us through a small glimpse in time of his own life that life is a journey to be enjoyed and celebrated with those you care about. And that caring about people is not that challenging when you are able to see people as perfectly imperfect. That is that their "flaws" increase their likeableness because they are what makes them who they are. Holden teaches us how to have the ability to adore everyone even in the midst of them being on the surface as potentially unlikeable. Holden teaches us the golden value of having a passion for the truth as he takes us on a journey of honest to goodness truthful conversations. He teaches us how refreshing conversations can be when both parties are willing and able to be honest with one another and how unenjoyable conversations can be when one or another in the conversation speaks pretentiously and how that type of attitude can really deflate the potential joy of that opportunity within those brief moments that those people have to celebrate being in the company of one another. Through honesty, adoration, a celebration of his own perfect imperfections and a deep desire to take care of all human beings as if they all have something important to contribute to the world (When asked by his sister Phoebe what he would most like to do in life Holden answered about people playing in a rye field near a cliff.. "I'd have to catch everbody if they started going over the cliff...That's all I'd do all day. I'd just be the catcher in the rye and all. I know it's crazy, but that's the only thing I'd really like to be.") Holden teaches us how to more greatly enjoy our journey of life with one another and how to be passionate about being a great friend. It is additionally amusing to me that Holden at times seems to have little reverence toward religion itself yet at the same time is very Christlike in his adoration and appreciation in his hindsight of all of the people in his life. In a way this "qualifies" Holden as a lover of us all and makes him an excellent candidate to be "The Catcher in the Rye".his "qualifies" Holden as a lover of us all and makes him an excellent candidate to be "The Catcher in the Rye".

You will either love this book or hate it. Holden Caulfield is an immature high school student that gets kicked out of his private prep school for the nteenth time. I definitely recommend this book to anyone looking for a good read.

J.D. Salinger was a young man when he wrote The Catcher in the Rye. I remember reading it in school many years ago, but this time I read his work for my own pleasure. I found out that when he wrote his book, he was a soldier during WWII. He carried around scraps of paper with him and he wrote as he experienced the horrors of war. Told in the first person, his book is a work that is a classic and should be in every library.

review_headline: I can relate to the main character, to some degree
review_body:
I have heard this interpretation before: "as he experiences the phoniness of the adult world," but I didn't see it in the book. I first read Catcher in the Rye a few years ago, in my late thirties. From what I remember, Holden thought everyone was phony, but there wasn't really any indication people were acting as a "phony" toward hm. In the beginning his roommate was friendly toward him, and though Holden believed he was a phony, didn't give any solid examples. The same with the Professor in the beginning of the book. Holden believed the Professor wasn't sincere, but Holden doesn't provide any instances when the Professor actually acted in a two-faced manner. It appeared to me that Holden was the phony, never expressing how he felt about them, and always assuming people were two-faced, when in reality, Holden was the one being two-faced by hiding his negativity and true feelings about the people he was interacting with.

Regardless of the interpretation, I did enjoy the book. I don't know what I got out of it, but it was interesting reading. I probably related to Holden. Sometimes I reflexively make assumptions about people's motives without thinking of the many times I was treated kindly and fairly by them.

review_headline: Ages more quicky than you do
review_body:
I first read this book when I was 15. I thought it was hysterical. Oh, sure, the main character was immature and whiny, and the constant expletives got old fast, but it was generally enjoyable.

Having recently found my old copy, I tried to reread it at age 50. I found it unbearable. I guess 'literature' is very much a function of time and place; unfortunately, I no longer have the time or place for this paperweight.

review_headline: Something for both the young and mature
review_body:
‘The Catcher in the Rye’ was for me, one of those books that both intrigues you and worries you at the same, but 'does', or should I say 'can' leave you refreshingly happy and sentimental in a somewhat pleasing way. During this book, I felt that the reader gradually uncovers the ‘human’ beauty that lies deep within the protagonist Holden Caulfield’s nature -Holden being a seemingly troubled and somewhat unstable youth at initial introduction. As I progressed through The Catcher in the Rye, I found Holden Caulfield gradually become quite endearing, my perhaps initial concern for the boy being thwarted over time as he became more and more likeable to me – perhaps in a similar way to Holden’s own mentality as he described in the book being simply that coming to like others seems to just be a progressive thing. But more so, I feel the gradual likeability of the guy is relatable to the way that he engages in seemingly reckless behaviours but always shows a degree of integrity in each situation. E.g calling up a female friend drunk and offering to help her cut her Christmas tree, or soliciting a prostitute but wanting no more than to just have a chat.
I would relate the feeling throughout this book as bittersweet, but I'd have to say that the feeling you are left with after reading the final chapters of this book is sentimental warmth, drawn personally by uncovering along the way, the sympathetic and warm-hearted nature of the lad. Holden may drink, he may smoke, he may take things to extremes, he may at times show complete disregard for others, and he may have no idea about his life's direction – in modern context it’s troubling that he is doing this and is only 17 - but deep down in there, these acts don’t seemingly demean his character whatsoever as his men’s-rea is integrity and of definite conviction. Holden is also quite intelligent and is capable of intellectual interaction as illustrated when he seems to grasp philosophical concepts andcontribute to the discussion he has with Mr. Antolini – a teacher he previously admired and finds himself with one evening.
Holden overall displays a human; loving and somewhat compassionate character and spirit. It's the recognition of this; of the little sparkling gems that shine through in Holden's character as you get to know him along the way, that is reassuring, pleasing and simply lovely. It was a good book suited for young and old - disclaimer: above the age of 16 perhaps.

review_headline: The story reads well, but it is not worth reading.
review_body: Salinger can write, but the story is a first person pointless rant as told from the point of view of a teenager who ends up in a mental institution temporarily.  This is an old school book, from a time when novels were considered art more so than entertainment.  It belongs in the same pile as Moby Dick:  books that do not entertain, but do excite those who look to art to challenge conventional thinking.  Time has erased the controversy that this book originally fostered back in the early 50's, but it has no message for today.  Both women's liberation and homosexuality are accepted within our society, but when this book was written they were distant hurdles to be mastered.

review_headline: Like or Hate it, It's a Classic
review_body: My favorite book of all time. Salinger really portrays the mind of the depressed and angsty adolescent. I think in one way or another we can all relate to Holden Caulfield. A great book for an adolescent. I feel like you're either going to like or hate this book. Reasons for hating it would probably be because it's mostly dialogue and not much action. You may also feel like he is complaining about one thing or another throughout most of the book. You may like the dialogue, due to how well one can relate to Holden. An absolute classic I would suggest reading for anyone, like it or hate it.

review_headline: Through the eyes of a senior.
review_body:
Rereading Catcher has been a wonderful experiment.
I am a senior. I had of course, read this book before.
I had just finished reading Salinger, which is a fairly new book.
Therefore, I wanted to reread his famous book. I loved it!
I urge seniors to read this book. It was a chuckle.
You will find Caulfield a sweet young man. He has
a big heart. Which is more than you can say for Salinger.
However, Salinger was in the midst of the most fierce
fighting in WW2. He lived through enough to make him
maladjusted. Caulfield was a figment of Salinger's imagination.
This explains why a 17 year old boy appears to be embittered.
However, I found a sweetness in the character that was
completely lacking in the character's creator, interesting......
Reading Caulfield as a young person and reading him as a
senior is a whole new ballgame. Probably Salinger never meant
for someone with the wisdom of age to read Catcher.
Salinger regretted writing the book and refused to be
the idol young people tried to make him. This is a
wonderful book. Old or young it will touch your heart.
Really liked this read!

review_headline: Raises many questions about life and how we should live
review_body:
On one level this is a narration by a not very likeable adolescent about his experiences leaving school and spending a couple of days on his own in NYC. Readers with this view would not be greatly moved by the book.
On another level it is a coming of age novel about someone trying to come to grips with an absurd world full of people with herd mentality and trying to find an authentic place for himself in this world. Readers with this view and a concern for authenticity and individuality may ponder questions raised long after the last page is read. The book raises many questions about life and how we should live.
The narrator Holden finds most people insincere and most things depressing. When an inner authentic self-surfaces Holden comes off second best in a physical conflict with first his roommate and then a pimp.
There are however bright spots in his narration, Holden’s recollection of happy times with his sister and brothers, his concern for ex girl friend Jane, the authenticity of the nuns, his dreams of a trip west and his ambition to be The Catcher in the Rye from Robert Burns’ poem. The novel ends on a good note with Holden crying with happiness.

review_headline: got a used copy. love this book
review_body: I love this book. Read it in highschool and bought it again to read as an adult. I maybe shouldve bought the book new for my collection but figured a used one would suit me just fine.  It had someone's name written on the outer borders of the pages and some markings throughout the book. Overall, its a book and I can read it so not much to complain about.

review_headline: A Must for Every Well Read Person
review_body: The truth is that reading the Catcher in the Rye in your adolescence is important, because it is then when you can most identify with the protagonist, but even later in life the story still resonates with the reader and is not to be missed.

review_headline: My other obsession is good TV mainly PBS or movies both of which I ...
review_body:
I bought this book along with "The lord of the flies" so that I would have something to read when I got back my obsession of reading books. My other obsession is good TV mainly PBS or movies
both of which I can record unless my newest obsession takes over which is baseball. Just a little aside, I have been watching every game the Washington Nationals have played since 2000. I still am amazed at myself why this has happened but it has happened.

Re the Catcher. I'm so glad I read the one star reviews because they are so intelligently written
and they give me a brief idea of the story. I usually read the one stars since I've heard that it was a "classic" all my life which is a long one. I was a teenager when It came out. Even then it would not have been on the must read list because I went to a Catholic high school.

I don't have anything to add to these reviews except that I put it down the last time because it didn't have a paragraph break until the third page. I confess, When I didn't have a break in the first page it looked burdensome. Fortunetly I purchased it for a cheap used paperback. I've used this quote before by Dorothy Parker: "Don't set this book down lightly; throw it with all your might." but it describes best what you courageous one starers have said about it.

It was time to broaden the mind and read an American Classic. So, I borrowed a copy from a friend. If they’re all like this, I’ve missed nothing!

In today’s world of Indie’s, e-readers and critiques, I don’t think it would have caused a mild ripple in any circles. It’s that poorly written

The best I can tell why this is such a controversial book, isn’t the story line as much as the use of G$#D$#n. It must have been as controversial as Clark Gable saying da#n in “Gone with the Wind.”

The paragraph structure is absolutely horrendous. Missing words and misspelled words were all too frequent. Send the word Good-by to an editor today and see what they say. They’ll rip you a new one.

The book is written in first person but for the life of me I could care less for this sniveling, whiny rich kid, Holden Caulfield. Everything he wants is giving to him on a silver platter and by choice, he continually self-destructs the options. How are we to feel empathy for a person who continually sabotages his own life? I can’t think of one.

Now, if Mr. Caulfield was the recipient of being bullied or beaten up by no accord of his own, that’s different. Not the case here. He ruins what few relations he has by being, for a better term, a spoiled little brat and then whines about it. How sad. Too bad. You cry wolf one too many times and no one cares. He is a master at that.

The only saving grace of this rubbish is the final two sentences. If you can find a copy or even better, go to the local library and read those lines, it will save you a lot unwanted rambling.

Two star push

i liked the book when i read it as a teen. here was a gift for a nephew living some 100 miles away, entering high school who in 6 months has never read the first chapter. he's never met his dad...busy game playing, texting, face booking and possibility becoming more of the next generation less civilized and dare I say, less interesting...well, we all would like to decide for ourselves how we will reflect about ourselves our role in the world. all I can say is read and decide for yourself...

Yes, I know this is a "classic" and required reading on most English teachers reading lists.  BUT.  Maybe after so much hoopla, by the time I actually sat down and read it, the thrill was gone before the first chapter was finished.  It's an entertaining story, no doubt about that, and I wasn't bored reading it or anything.  Protaganist, Holden Caulfield, narrates his life in vividly colorful and (for the time) rather obscenely descriptive prose.  I'm sure the book banners had a field day when this novel first showed up on school library shelves.  That's so dumb; it just makes people (especially kids) want to read it all the more.  Plus, it's distinctly unconstitutional to ban books!!  Anyway, happy reading.

I was a voracious reader throughout my childhood and teen years, and majored in English Literature in college, so it's astounding that I didn't get around to reading "The Catcher in the Rye" until I was well into my forties. In fact, for years I assumed that it was a book about baseball. There's not much I can say about it that hasn't already been said - along with "Moby-Dick," "The Great Gatsby," and "Huckleberry Finn," it's a contender for The Great American Novel, which puts it in the running for The Greatest Novel in the World, going head to head with works by Tolstoy, Dostoyevsky, Austen, and other classics. But in addition to its secure status as "a classic," it's also, reportedly, the Favorite Novel Ever of every thoughtful teenager born from 1935 to the present. Yet strangely, I don't recall any of my friends discussing it when I was growing up - it was always adults who mentioned it. Is it possible that "The Catcher in the Rye" was NEVER the favorite book of any teenager, but instead, the book that older people simply assumed would appeal to teenagers? That despite the condemnation of Holden as a "bad influence," in fact, he didn't influence anyone - adults only thought that he did. Given the author's notorious reclusiveness and his slender output, a mythology grew up around the book all out of proportion to its objective quality - like Darwin's "The Origin of Species," a book more a catalyst for argument than a work of literature that people actually read.

That being said, it wouldn't have turned into a cultural icon if a lot of people hadn't read it and been moved and inspired by it. But reading it for the first time as an adult is different - Holden wasn't my contemporary; he was someone I had moved past a long time ago.

I wouldn't have cared for Holden, and he wouldn't have liked me at all. Far from seeing everyone as a "phony," I ascribed far too much authenticity to everyone at that age. I took everything everyone said very seriously, even if I disagreed with them. Not to say that I was a serious person - far from it. I was known as a clown and a joker. But everyone else seemed to be clear on what they wanted and who they were - they were all confident, secure, and in control, whether they were a jock, a brain, a tortured artist, or just an ordinary slob, content with whatever life allotted them. If only I had understood how frightened and confused everyone else was - at least, some of them. But I was too easily influenced by everyone around me, unlike Holden, who doesn't seem to be truly influenced by anyone. And the only reason for this is absolute, complete, total arrogance - he may be the most arrogant and conceited character in all literature, at least in proportion to his relative unimportance in the larger society he inhabits.

"The Catcher in the Rye" is, above all, the portrait of a single individual, and not a commentary on mid-century American society, as "Huckleberry Finn" is on the American society of a hundred years earlier. And it is certainly not a general commentary on the human condition, as "The Great Gatsby" is. And it doesn't explore human relationships in the depth Austen does, or have the historical and religious weight of the Russian masters. But it does what all great literature must do - it forces the reader to engage, to come to grips with something, to either agree or ask themselves why they do not agree - and for that reason, despite its limitations and the danger of its being overwhelmed by the hype surrounding it, it is, in fact, an important work that anyone who considers themselves a cultured or thoughtful person should be familiar with.city to everyone at that age. But everyone else seemed to be clear on what they wanted and who they were - they were all confident, secure, and in control, whether they were a jock, a brain, a tortured artist, or just an ordinary slob, content with whatever life allotted them. If only I had understood how frightened and confused everyone else was - at least, some of them. But I was too easily influenced by everyone around me, unlike Holden, who doesn't seem to be truly influenced by anyone. And the only reason for this is absolute, complete, total arrogance - he may be the most arrogant and conceited character in all literature, at least in proportion to his relative unimportance in the larger society he inhabits.

"The Catcher in the Rye" is, above all, the portrait of a single individual, and not a commentary on mid-century American society, as "Huckleberry Finn" is on the American society of a hundred years earlier. And it is certainly not a general commentary on the human condition, as "The Great Gatsby" is. And it doesn't explore human relationships in the depth Austen does, or have the historical and religious weight of the Russian masters. But it does what all great literature must do - it forces the reader to engage, to come to grips with something, to either agree or ask themselves why they do not agree - and for that reason, despite its limitations and the danger of its being overwhelmed by the hype surrounding it, it is, in fact, an important work that anyone who considers themselves a cultured or thoughtful person should be familiar with.

I was expecting the book a little bit biggger but it's just fine (: it's a good book i loved it

Catcher in The Rye- Holden juggles his emotions between the sarcastic child and a cynical teen. He is funny,but his youth and sarcasm work as blinders. He is oblivious of the goodness around him. His focus is through the wider end of the tunnel, but his mind's eye only sees out the narrow end. He is the typical pubescent who thinks he knows everything but in reality, he knows nothing as far as the scope of the world goes.
He wears his humor as a mask that he may hide himself from a world he feels he doesn't belong.
Holden does find happiness with his sister. He wishes he could forever freeze her in time. He wishes he could freeze in time with her. Why grow up and leave the rare moments of true happiness.
He is a boy on the verge of becoming a man. Emotionally he isn't ready. Will he ever be happy again.- Renee Robinson

How this book ever got to be one of the best books to read I'll never know.  The language is terrible, the story is awful. and it is not the least bit entertaining.  I wanted to quit reading it, but thought well it is suppose to be such a good book it just has to ge t better - and it didn't.  It is the most NOTHING book I have ever read.  I was in college when all of this came about.  I guess I just missed it because I don't like this type of literature.  It is Not literature it is trash!

I had heard what a controversial book this was; I think it was banned when I went to High school. It was a bible for such people as Hinkley and Chapman, so I finally decided to find out what the hype was about. The machinations of a poorly wired adolescent mind, selfish and poorly thought our where all I saw. Mr. Salinger, I think, was only trying to remember his own callow youth, and how it felt back then. The only people who would really relate to it are about 13 years old. Spare me!
On my 5th read! Each time I perceive it to convey something other than I did the previous read! A timeless classic!

Every time the main character makes a statement he follows it with "No really I mean it", it is extremely annoying. The fact that this book is considered a "classic" absolutely baffles me. Do yourself a favor and don't waste your time reading this.
What can I say but either you love or hate this book.  Still do not understand all the controversy that surrounds it but a good read anyway.

I don't really care if you like this review or not. Not going to try anything phony to persuade you one way or the other, and all that. Just really loved this book. I really did. People who gave it 1 lousy star are probably a bunch of phonies so who cares what they think. They're probably doing something phony right now, morons. Anybody seen my hat? Anyway, If you want to read a good book this one will do. If not.....then you can go pound sand for all I care. The thought of not reading this book is making me feel depressed, It really is. review_headline: Only got around to reading this recently - after years of hype.  And its - OKAY
review_body: Theres really nothing much that happens.  And I get it - its not that kind of book.  But, when I closed the book, I didn't feel fulfilled the way a book should make one feel fulfilled.  It basically just randomly ended.  The character did not grow from the beginning of the book to the end of the book.  There was really no plot or storyline.  And in my mind, not much depth either. Still, I read it.  It kept me turning the pages - but Im not sure if it was because it held 'some' of my interest, or if I just wanted to see if it got better.

review_headline: A Classic that deserves its recognition
review_body: Not every classic novel is for everyone, obviously but this is a brilliant piece of work. I really did enjoy the biased and unlikeable protagonist. I feel like we all know or knew a Holden. Best parts are indeed the dialogue and the no holds barred narration.
Not a cleverly written book as I had hoped.Didnt leave me wanting more. I expected more from a classic work.
Great, I should have read this in my teenage years. Now it pretty calm considering teens now days. er if it is still on the reading list for college.

I really like the jargon and sarcasm, especially when holden sometimes refers to people by saying "well aren't you a prince?" Anyways this isn't one of those professional ratings, but I like it because it really reflects some of the failures I've had as a teen. This is my favorite book so far

I remember first reading this book a year ago and for me, personally, from the the first page on I was struck by the authentic and frank voice of Holden Caulfield as he trods through New York City for a weekend. Some people love Holden's voice and others deem it one of a spoiled brat who is lazy and causes his own problems. I though view his voice one that is rooted in the 1950s and '60s counterculture movement, which caused young people like Holden to be lonely and longing for a voice to listen to in what they saw as a bland, uniform society that was prosperous, but too ridged for people like Holden. Anyways, I do really do recommend it, especially for high school students.

i didn't have this kind of feeling as a kid, i was confident and confidently wrong at times.  and since 'diary of a wimpy kid' type crap came from this book in spirit,i have been sure not to encourage this kind of insecurity in the nieces and nephews i have.
I knew I had a copy of it 'somewhere,' but when I looked for a couple of days and couldn't find it, I ordered one.  It was great reading it again all these years later.

Not my style of book. Did not like the character or the style of writing on this occasion.

Would not recommend it.
