There were two books I never read considered a "must read" I wanted to read before I die: "the Catcher in the Rye" and "The Good Earth." Now I've read both and I am 82 and enjoyed them very much!

Thank You

review_headline: Read it again as an adult
review_body: I first read The Catcher in the Rye in high school. Reading it again 50 years later makes me wonder why it was considered so racy in the early 60s.

This is a classic book.  If you do not enjoy this book then I feel bad for the "phonies".  It was not until the second reading that I understood it was a character profile with a story.  I was always used to a story being told.  Anyways you are going to love or hate this book.  No shame if you do not enjoy it, it is not for everyone.

review_headline: Read It Again and Again and Again
review_body: I read The Catcher in the Rye every five or six years and my last copy fell apart, literally, fell apart and onto the floor!  I had no choice but to buy again.  This is a bucket-list book everyone should read; if for no other reason but to appreciate being pulled into another life and time. J.D. Salinger, in my opinion, is a master.  Check out his biography (on Netflix) if you want more insight to the man and the erra.

review_headline: From a reading span of fifty years!
review_body:
"The Catcher in the Rye" was one of my most memorable readings when I was a freshman in college. It really had a lasting impact on me, especially the main character, Holden Caulfield. I remember identifying with many of his confused and mix-up feelings.
Now, fifty years later, I reread the book for my book club's choice. It was a quick read as before and I enjoyed it as a real grown-up and could appreciate the angst and suffering that Holden endured. This process of growing up continues throughout our lives.
Yes! It's a must read and reread!

review_headline: I don't know why we can't just use a star ...
review_body: I don't know why we can't just use a star rating and have to type out some sort of explanation?

review_headline: It was okay but not for me
review_body:
To be honest, I wasn't sure what this book was about when I picked it up. It was in the clearance section of my local used book store, and I've heard of it, so I thought I'd give it a try. Well, I didn't dislike it, but I didn't really like it either. When I first started the book, I was pretty interested in it. But as it went on, I found myself getting bored, and I had trouble finishing the last couple pages. It wasn't a bad book by any means; it just wasn't great. I thought Holden seemed like a pretty typical teenager, not really happy with anything, bored with life, sick of school and friends. There wasn't anything special about him to me.

This is a pretty short review, but I don't have a lot to say. I didn't love it and found myself getting bored with the story.

Pagesofcomfort.blogspot.com

review_headline: THE WORST BOOK I HAVE EVER READ
review_body:
noting meaningful to say and repeating the same to reinforce the nothingness
would to recommend to the village idiot so they could feel better about themselves

One of my most favorite books and would like it in large print. Cannot get it in digital format!
Does anyone out there know of where I can get a large print edition? Thanks for the help!

It seems people either love or hate this book.  Thought it was great.  While many analyze this book in regards to teen angst, do not feel it need be over-analyzed.  It is a wonderful, colorful story of a young man's descent into mental illness.  I felt Holden Caulfield was once a somewhat popular young man who drifted away from conventional society.  As with many who are mentally ill, he had little awareness of this. He struggles with his relationships, hoping to remain an innocent.  Very well written.  Truly deserves to be a classic. Probably will reread someday and am sure there will be new things to be revealed.

Had to read this masterfully written book again after several years....can't wait for his unpublished writings to be released beginning in 2015-2020.

How did Salinger get into Holden Caulfield's mind like he was able to?

Yes indeed, a work of genius.  I think it also explains Salinger's reclusiveness in a way different than the main-stream opinion that he suffered from PTSD.  Rather, as the book clearly says (the actors in the play on Broadway for example) repeatedly, public adulation is fatal to genuine creativity.  Hence, my opinion is that Salinger became reclusive not because of PTSD, but straightforwardly for reasons he covers in Catcher...i.e., to protect himself from the mindless adulation of people, adulation that surely would destroy any genuine creativity he had.

review_headline: Think of it as a character study
review_body:
I find a book like this becomes examined from a skewed perspective merely because of its status. Don't think of it in terms of a classic book, but just another book. Reading it then becomes more about the story itself instead of an evaluation of its classic status and whether or not it's deserved.

A major criticism I have heard about this book is that it doesn't go anywhere. It is essentially the ramblings of a 16 y/o about the weekend he left school after he knew he was going to be kicked out. He makes a lot of digressions along the way getting off topic before getting back on. For many people, a story should go somewhere. A person should have accomplished something along the way, or transform by the end. Holden pretty much ends up the same as he started (the end suggests that he's on the road to growth but we don't see any of it throughout the pages). But rather than this being a plot-driven or character-driven novel, I'd call this a character study.

Another criticism is that Holden Caulfield isn't a likable character. For most people, he probably won't be. But I don't think it's a requirement that characters always be likable so much as it's important for them to be relatable. I can relate to the level of angst he has even if I don't relate to how he reacts to it. Like for all his disgust with the phoniness of adults, he's complicit and phony just as well. My favorite example is when he's talking about him and a Navy officer telling each other how \\"it's nice to have met you\\" a social nicety with virtually no weight to it the majority of the time it's being said.

The content can feel repetitive at times, but I was always curious to see how things progressed. It's worth reading.

I read this book in AP English and honestly didn't expect to love it as much as I did. I ordered 3 copies of this, one for my, one for my boyfriend, and one for the English department. Definitely a must-read. Holden is one of my favorite characters.

What really knocks me out is a book that, when you're all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it. That doesn't happen much, though.

review_headline: Reasons I was pleased with the Catcher in the Rye purchase.
review_body: My daughter needed it for her lit class in high school. We received it in a timely manner, it was very inexpensive and in good shape.  I read the book in high school.  I didn't like it much, perhaps if i was a boy I would have liked it better, but I like other DJ Salinger works very much.

review_headline: I failed to find anything profound in this boring book.
review_body: I've heard about this book my entire life, and it was banned from my public school system.  They didn't need to bother banning it because I would have found it incredibly dull then just as I do now.  I cannot understand why this book has classic status or that it is actually used in classrooms around the country.  Holden is a loser with a capital L.  He's a spoiled rich kid in NYC and throws all of his advantages away.  I'm sure glad it was a short read, but I can assure you, the fact that I hadn't read it until recently, didn't affect my life in a negative way at all.
In pretty decent shape for the age of the book. Was as described. I would use this source again when possible.

review_headline: Salinger was the Stephine Meyers of his time.
review_body:
Really, this book is as poorly written as Twilight.

It's about a brat named Holden who spends the entire book whining. The whole thing could've been fixed if his parents had just spanked his bratty butt and sent him to military school.

Why it's a "classic" I don't know because it's an awful book. Go read a true classic like Sherlock Holmes, Dracula, The Phantom Of The Opera, or The Hunchback Of Notre Dame instead.

review_headline: It's a classic, but hard to understand why
review_body:
I believe, after having read this book and checked the publishing date (1945) that it's "classic" standing came from the boldness of writing for 1945, not to mention the perhaps first real look at the difference between teenagers and children.

I did not like it because it didn't feel like a story or even a statement to me.

The main character came across to me as a pimply faced teenage boy who is rich and spoiled and one who believes everyone but himself is a "moron". This gets tiring as it is repeated over and over in the text regardless of who the main character interacts with...except for a dead brother and a live kid sister.

Perhaps due to the era in which it was written there wasn't a feeling of "what a loser!" in the eyes of readers back then.

For now, in 2014, and for me, I found it disgusting. The spelling is often incorrect, but at least consistent.

There is foul language in it, which I believe is far more likely the reason this book was banned from my high school around 30 years ago, rather than some secret message that is powerful or dangerous.

I'm only glad I read it because now I know what it is. I found it very disappointing, but perhaps it is my lack of understanding of what it was like to read a book that "gritty" in 1945.Not a classic in my own personal opinion.

review_headline: This book epitomizes the Self Important Teenage Boy
review_body:
While I moderately enjoyed reading the book, as it had some good parts, I think the only reason people may not like it is because it points out how much we are self important. Everything Holden did was for himself, or by his own thinking. He doesn't seem to understand what he is doing wrong, but keeps doing the same thing.
His tendency to the words phony, or fake also make him seem even more above his own laws. He hates everything he believes to be phony, but is actually the biggest liar in the book. He has a really terrible way of covering for it, too,"I swear I'm a madman sometimes." He's a madman all the time and doesn't even realize it.
He also has a terrible way of dealing with stress, or bad situations. He either assumes the absolute worst, or that everything is okay. He assumed his teacher was going to rape him after he had given him advice, and decided to pet his head, which is really just a form of care. His teacher had just given him some very serious advice in a very serious situation. But before that he is telling Phoebe that his parents won't kill him, even though he just got kicked out of ANOTHER school.
He also cannot seem to believe how bad people can be. The entire time Maurice is scamming him for an extra 5 dollars, he cares more about being right than his safety. He then expects someone he exclaims as dumb, to be smart enough to run away with him even though he does not want her to. He doesn't even understand himself.
But honestly he does seem to have a certain charm about him. He has so many bad things about him that anyone can pick up the book and at least relate to him in some way. It was brilliantly written to make as many people as possible pick it up and keep reading. And that is exactly what it does. I would recommend this book only if you like to feel bad occasionally.

review_headline: If you love being bored, this book is for you.
review_body:
The entire time I read this book, all I could ever think about was how boring it was. The story was so lame, and they characters half cocked ideas. I entirely regret ever participating in the class project involving this book. I absolutely hate it and would much rather have spent my time with a book more entertaining. I just can't enjoy a book completely about the boring, sad, unimportant life of some spoiled rich kid who thinks he has it rough.
The only time I could relate to this book was when his brother died and when the kid killed himself. I had a brother that died, and the entire time I was reading this book I wanted to kill myself. I felt like so much of my time was wasted. If you like a book that has no real point, gets you nowhere and just rambles mindlessly about a rich kid, then this may be for you. Most definitely not a book I would read again.
I wish I could rate it with less than a full star. I feel like a whole star is too much for a book lacking any major moral or lesson to learn. The book doesn't even really tell a story. It just tells about a kid and what he does. This "novel" if you could call it that would be better taken as a journal or a diary of an idiot kid.
I wish I could say that was all that was bad about this book. Alas, there is more to tell to this "story". The old language is sometimes hard to understand and requires almost deep thought just to get through some paragraphs. The plot is too mixed up around what all is going on and sometimes you can't even keep up because he is in a memory and then he is back in the present with no transition. I feel as if the author thought he was writing something good, but was sadly confused.
I suppose that there may be someone out there who loves being bored out of their mind. I'm sure this person also loves burning up useful time and getting nothing accomplished. If this person is you, this book is the perfect choice. If not, you may want to read anything else except for this "novel".

I actually truly enjoyed this book. The thing I liked most was J.D. Salinger's writing style. It made the novel a much faster read. I also enjoyed the main character, Holden Caulfied, outlook on life. At times he was sort of depressed and unhappy, but he also realizes that the simple things in life may be the best things. Some people may think this book is a bit crude, but it is just so real and relatable that it is not only an American classic, but a great read. Using Holden's words, this book ain't no phony!

I would recommend this group to teens, because it relates to some of the feelings and struggles that teenagers go through. I would also recommend it to people who have more of a dry sense of humor. People who enjoy classics or books in older time periods would like this book. And finally, readers who like fast paced stories with truth and meaning.
The author apparently writes the very way he speaks which really sucks. It's just my narrow minded opinion but I simply could not like it no matter how much I tried.
Narcissistic. Fast read. Enjoyed. Was not totally engrossed however. A bit young. Would read Salinger again. Would not necessarily recommend.

The Catcher in the Rye is a book about teenage adolescence, alienation, growing up, and the phoniness of the adult world. It's a great book that focuses on a seventeen year old school drop out named Holden Caulfield as he wanders around New York trying to get somebody to listen to him but he ends up just feeling more and more alone. I believe that anybody who is at least seventeen can easily relate to Holden and find a bit of him in them. That's why this book is so popular with people today. This is a book about the problems that haunt all adolescents as they mature into adulthood.
For a while as I read this book I didn't like it that much only because I didn't get it at all. You can't just read any book without thinking deeply about what every little thing means. Once I took the time to think about this book I began to like it more and more. For example the outlandish red hunting hat that holden constantly wears shows that Holden wants to be different from the people around him at the same time he is very self conscious about it. The hat sort of mirrors the main conflict of the book which is Holden's need for isolation versus his need for companionship.
I also didn't like the book as much because I thought it lacked a plot and a good ending. But I couldn't have been more wrong. It has a great plot and an even greater ending. As I continued thinking about this book I started thinking about the two different Holdens in this book. There is the Holden that the story is about and the Holden that is telling the story. If you only think about the Holden that the story is about then it's extremely depressing and the ending is a little unsatisfying.
The whole book he's basically trying to find somebody to listen to him and he's hardly ever successful. But when I think about the Holden writing the story I get hopeful. He's writing the book a year after the events in the story and the best part about this entire book is that he's finally getting what he's wanted throughout the whole novel and that's a person to listen to him and feel empathy for him. And that person is you, the reader. Once I realized this it made the book ten times better for me. In my opinion that's definitely the best part about this book.
The catcher in the Rye is a fantastic book and I think it deserves all of the attention it has received. It is truly an American classic and I don't think this book will ever lose its relevance to society. People will always be able to feel empathy for Holden and find him to be a relatable character. This is the type of book you can read time and time again and find more and more reasons to love it and discover J.D. Salinger's genius. This book is a masterpiece and because of it it deserves five stars.
The whole story was basically pointless, I read it because it was rated as a classic-not. Not sure if it would be of interest to anyone.

review_headline: The Catcher in the Rye Book Critic Assignment
review_body: The Catcher in the Rye is a very good book. Even though it was slightly confusing due to all the paradoxical situations and characters, it was still a wonderful story. Even though the paradoxes were confusing at times, they also made the novel very intriguing. The plot to this story isn't very clear, so it's really based on the interpretations of the reader, which I think is really cool. I believe this book is based on coming of age. Kids, just like the main character Holden Caulfield, lose their way from time to time, then as they learn and grow older, realize what truly matters in their lives. This book really has me thinking about life and discovering its true meaning. Will my life be like Holden's? Will I, one rainy day finally realize where I'm supposed to be in life? I hope so. In conclusion, The Cather in the Rye is a very good book, and I would recommend it to anyone above the age of 16 (due to language and some explicit material).

review_headline: A must have for your collection
review_body:
Everybody knows this book, for many years it has been talked about. Everybody with their own interpretation. To be honest, I found it tough to read. Not really a page turner, and maybe not intended for that either. Nevertheless, Im happy to have read it. At some point even enjoyed reading it. My expectations were a bit high I guess. So for anyone who wants to buy it because it's so good and so much talked about...beware. That's why I rate it three stars...not because of low quality...it's the tough reading. Most kids in school must read it because of its importance for literature. So before anyone starts commenting on my review....don't ...just don't.
Actually my review goes out to all you youngsters...struggling in life, trying to find your way. Being forced to read books which you don't like. Basically thats what this book is all about.
Good, read, a classic, lots of quotable lines, maybe wish I had read it when in my teens and twenties since it is quintessentially adolescent.

Since I transitioned from student life to adult life and began working, I have taken to catching up on "the classics" that I somehow never had to read in high school or college. Before reading, I had no idea what Catcher in the Rye was even about. After reading, I had no idea what Catcher in the Rye was even about. I started reading some reviews and the common themes that kept popping up were "coming of age" and "teenage angst." So many of the reviewers talked about relating to Holden. I found Holden to be the single hardest to relate to character I have ever encountered in a work of fiction. With rare exceptions, Holden pretty much hates everything. It is troubling to me that people find this type of anger and bitterness so easy to relate to. This is not just my 27 year old self speaking; I have never felt this angry and empty at any point during my high school or early college years, or any other point in my life for that matter.

The literary merits of this book, both positive and negative, have been covered ad nauseum in other reviews, and I don't feel like I have anything compelling to add to either side. What I will say is that this book offers me none of what I look for in a work of fiction. If I am curious to learn more about the mind of a teenager, I'll go read a psychology journal or watch a documentary, or take a class on adolescent psychology. If I am reading a novel or watching a movie, I want to be entertained. I want to know what happens next. I want to be so captivated by the story that I'm practically skipping over words to see what happens next. Therein lies my biggest problem. Essentially, nothing happened in this book. There were a few funny spots, but on the whole, it wasn't funny. It wasn't dramatic. It wasn't action packed. There weren't twists or turns. The only suspense was the belief I held that something interesting was eventually going to happen. It didn't. I could not relate to Holden at all. In the end, I don't know why anyone would want to read this book. I really don't.

I did read the review of others it was like a 50-50 thing. But I got anyways and for me it wAs pretty much okay, especially if you're doing It for high school or college. They only thing I find a little wrong is the ending. The ending  is okay but I think it needs something to make the readers be satisfy with a happier ending.
Wanted to see what the hubbub was all about. Didn't like the story or the writing. If that is great then I will write a book

review_headline: The absolute worst book ever written in the history of man.
review_body: The absolute worst book ever written in the history of man. Why is this considered a classic? Don't waste a dime on this drivel.
Always loved this booked since I read it in HS. I it for my brother, hoping he will enjoy it as much as I did before.

review_headline: A Troubled Young Man Tells His Story and Touches Everyone He Meets
review_body: If I had died before reading Salinger, I wouldn't have known, but I would have missed something special.  Don't know what took me so long to get around to reading this iconic book.  It is an on-going first person revelation of a privileged, sixteen year old Holden Caulfield, a troubled young man, who leaves his prep school, at their request, and hides out in his hometown of New York City for three days, awaiting the day he is actually expected home by his family for Christmas vacation.  His insights of school, classmates and teachers is what you might expect but told so engagingly, in Holden's unique vernacular, you want to keep turning the pages.  He is, at turns, immature, old beyond measure, kind, distracted, and a proficient liar.  No one seems to know how to help Holden with his failures, but we hope, at the end, and suspect, he will figure everything out on his own.  Quite an unusual book.

His is the worst book ive ever read, only buy it if you like to get lost, read goddamn every other word, him say, \\"I mean it, I really do\\" all the time, and read that everything amd everyone in the entire world is a phony! DO NOT BUY!!!!!

review_headline: Catcher in the Rye paper back
review_body: It is a classic, which somehow I had never read.  I am enjoying it and happy to be filling in a gap in my literary learnings.
This was a gift to my son. He was extremely pleased with the condition of the book; it was as described

How disappointing to think you are getting a full size book, and then to receive a miniature copy with print so small I cannot read it.  The description I noted was that this was a book in good condition, and I'll grant you it is, but if you cannot see the words what good is it ....not just me by the way, my fifteen year old granddaughter said she'd need a magnifying glass to get through this book ....I feel cheated on this one ...

I really recommend it,the shipment was very quickly,the quality of the book is very good,the only thing was that the cover was completely different from the one that they showed,but it`s fine.The book is brand new!

I first read this in college fifty years ago and just recently read it again.  Loved it both times.  No, it doesn't have 'action figure' photos or 'thrill-a-minute' dialogue.....just a sensitive and accurate portrayal of a mid-teen going through life's 'changes'.  for those of you who hated the book and didn't identify with it in any way, my condolences.
Excellent example of first-person narrative.  See the PBS movie about J.D. Salinger's life, how he wrote Catcher in between battles during WWII.

I watched a documentary about J.D. Salinger and liked it.  So, had to read Catcher.  I honesty do not get what all the hype is about.  It is a good book and I liked it.  But not sure why so many people thought the book was so great.

review_headline: My Memories of my College days
review_body:
I am very pleased with my purchase of "the catcher and the rye". All the adult members of my family are looking forward to their turn to read this great book. For me it brings back memories of my days in college as I had read this in my freshman year. Thank you Amazon.

Frank Giorgio

review_headline: The reason why this book is a classic
review_body:
“Catcher in the Rye” is a classic and required reading in many schools. It not a classic because it is a simple tale of three days in the life of a sixteen year old adolescent struggling, as most adolescents do, with how they can and should relate to the world and their feelings that much that they see and hear is phony. Nor does is reveal why more than three disturbed individuals claimed that the book shows why they killed or tried to kill people – at best we can say that these sociopaths scanned the book superficially and supposed that it expressed their alienation from the world. Nor is the book significant because it describes J. D. Salinger's opinion about the world, his social criticisms, and why he, Salinger, secluded himself from the world. It is more than these things. The book is a classic because it is filled with symbols that can reveal insights: a careful reading discloses that everyone of Holden’s ranting, every event, and every person in the book has significant meaning.

Salinger gave the book a strange title. Therefore it is important to note that Holden does not remember the correct wording of the poem “Gin (meaning, if or should) a body meet a body comin’ thro’ the rye.” He substitutes “catch” instead of “meet.” The poem, composed in 1782 by Robert Burns, was filled with sexual imagery. But Holden tells readers that he pictures children playing in a field of rye grain dangerously near a cliff, and he stands near the end of the field to “catch” them when they start to fall over the cliff.

Holden may be seeing himself as a savior of young people like himself who are disillusioned with society. Yet, he doesn’t reveal how he will save them and he is unable to save himself from being disillusioned. Additionally, while he deletes the word “meet,” he is able to meet people and engage with them in a friendly fashion, but his meetings miss something important, and we need to decide what these items mean.

The imagery of “catching” is emphasized by the repeated mention of Holden’s brother’s catcher’s mitt that is so important to Holden that he takes it with him to school. Again, Salinger wisely leaves it to his readers to think and decide the meaning of this mitt and its connection to Holden’s view of himself as a catching savior of children.

Salinger also leaves it to readers to analyze what is bothering Holden, what is the significance of each of his three day experiences, such as his inability to have sex, is this a metaphor and if so what is it saying? Why doesn’t Holden fight when he is hit twice in the novel? What does his red hat signify; is it important that the color red is the color of his dead brother’s hair, a brother he loved so much? Is Holden intelligent, why despite his ability to write compositions his teachers praised he does not want to study, why was he kicked out of several schools? Why does he react well with people even though he thinks they are phony What is his true views about religion even though he mocks it, what does his reactions to two nuns reveal about religion? Should we be appalled by his obscenities, why does he use them, what are the sophisticated ideas in his ramblings? What is the significance of Holden's brothers and sister, his father and mother, his girlfriends Jane and Sally, the schools he attended and his teachers, and why is the novel set in New York, and why in the winter.

Is he deteriorating into a mental breakdown, will he fully or partially recover from it; will he always be alienated from society? Salinger left this last significant point vague. Should we say that Salinger is suggesting that Holden could never become reconciled to society just as Salinger apparently never did and secluded himself? Why couldn’t Holden and Salinger adapt to society? What do all these and other things in the novel tell us about Holden, about Salinger, about people and society, and about ourselves?

In short, this book is a classic because it has so much in it and causes readers to ask and seek answers to many questions. The Argentinean novelist Jorge Borges wrote that great literature contains obscurities and ambiguities so that two people can write the book, the writer and the reader. This is why “Catcher in the Rye” is a very good book.lassic because it has so much in it and causes readers to ask and seek answers to many questions. The Argentinean novelist Jorge Borges wrote that great literature contains obscurities and ambiguities so that two people can write the book, the writer and the reader. This is why “Catcher in the Rye” is a very good book.
This book is an automatic five stars. I must've read it over 20 times. It's pretty damn good. Trust me.
I really did not know what to expect from this old classic but it was interesting and of course makes me wonder what happened to this fellow eventually.
Got this for my girlfriend .....she enjoyed reading it....?she really got into it n read it in a weeks time

I recently read this book for the second time. The first time was in high school, so I couldn't remember much about it except that I enjoyed reading it. This book is a great little read. Much better the second time around.
Very good. Strange young man and painfully lonesome. I'm only half way through so this is not a very good interpretation.

review_headline: Have always loved it--this purchase was for re-reading
review_body: Have always loved it--this purchase was for re-reading. It's a classic, doesn't need a good review from me, although it obviously deserves it.  Has led me into other books about Salinger the person. What an odd bird he was!
I have lined this guy out a couple times and now have bought it for the third time. I leafed late that you don't loan books, but give them. I'll have to call Phoebe and tell her all about it.

review_headline: I didn't like it. I really did(not)!
review_body: I thought this book was prurient. I really did! I actually did enjoy the prose (but not the content). I really did! I also read "a perfect day for banana fish". I really did! It wasn't that good either.  I really mean it!

I recently finished reading The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger. As weird as it sounds, I decided to read this book because it was Charlie’s favourite book in The Perks of Being a Wallflower. This made me want to see if The Catcher in the Rye was really that good. After reading it, I can say that it is.

At first, this novel reminded me of The Perks of Being a Wallflower in that it told the story of someone’s seemingly mundane life. For example, this person was just going to school instead of fighting mythical creatures as most novels today portray. Don’t get me wrong though, the story was interesting and captivated my attention throughout with a storyline that was always moving.

I would recommend this novel to any teenager looking for a relatable story. Google states themes of this novel as “teenage angst and alienation” something that most teens have to deal with at one point or another. This novel helps teens know that they are not alone and know that other people are going through the same thing.

review_headline: my thoughts about "The Catcher in the Rye", by J.D. Salinger
review_body: For me, this book is a great read, and a great re-read, because I continue to draw new interpretations and analogies. The book is an absolute classic, dealing with issues of individual identity, angst, alienation, skepticism, etc. One of my favorite quotes from the book: "“It's funny. All you have to do is say something nobody understands and they'll do practically anything you want them to.”
I read this many years ago and wanted to catch up with Mr. Salinger again.  Was a little disappointed but worth reading again.
I received a copy of Catcher in the Rye that had a different cover than what was described as being sold.  The copy I received was all red, not the one that was shown as being sold.

I have always wanted to read this since I know it is a favorite for many. And, I can honestly say it has been added to my collection of books. The way Salinger wrote is what captured my interest the most. The story only spans over a couple days, but so much happens and it was just so interesting I read it in 2 days time. I absolutely love the characters. Holden really knows how to tell a story and I enjoyed his thoughts and opinions on everything around him. I would definitely recommend it and will probably end up reading it again myself.
I had read this book a long time ago and, after seeing a TV special on J.D. Salinger, I was interested in reading it again.  I found it just as gripping as it was when I read it the first time.

Salinger writes a 'first person' way to connect with the insecurity of expectations.
Living in the mind of a youth making decisions for which there can be real world consequences and having to experience them, AGAIN, is a gut wrench. Humorous, yes. But, only when you realize it is his experience. Not yours!

I have not read this since trying to hide it while reading it in 8th grade as it was banned back then. I was brought back to its great pages and quick machine-gun type prose once more after reading a new book on Amazon: Upper Class Porn. The referenced book refers to The Catcher in the Rye in its description and indeed there is a connection with that pure edgy inquisitive innocence of Holden Caulfield in the world he lives in only moved into the future. 'Where do the ducks go in the winter?' is one question that I have always kept with me and bring out with a laugh when I realize that I am taking things for granted and as it turns out there is a place where the ducks are taken. I had forgotten about the purity of thought in this great book and the frustration with masked reality, I had forgotten the youthful world that I had come from as I moved into adulthood with all of the things that one bumps into in the dark. The other book that I mentioned made me remember and want to read The Catcher in the Rye again and I am glad that I did. I got to go home again and live again with my thinking as a pre-teen and in some ways it was eye-opening if not cathartic.

The Catcher In The Rye, written by old Salinger sometime back in the middle ages, is one of those classic works of literature that everyone can get a bang out of, I really mean that. It's not just another phony novel although it may seem phony since it's been on the bestseller list for hundreds of years or so. I really get a kick out of old Holden Caulfield, and his red hunting cap and all, even though he's the most terrific liar you ever saw. He's a real prince, no kidding, although he says things like \\"sleep tight, ya morons!\\" It kills me when someone says something like that. Old Holden has many girls on the brain which he hangs out with during the course of the novel just for laughs though they give him a pain in the ass. Holden is swanky for his age even though 17 is kind of old when you think about it. He smokes cigarettes, gets oiled up on martinis, hits on broads in Greenwich Village bars and even pays a hooker for a throw. He's really kind of fiend that way. During his brief Christmas adventure in New York City, he pays his old English teacher Mr. Antolini a visit. Mr. Antolini tells him that he can very clearly see him dying nobly for some highly unworthy cause, but Holden is too tired to contemplate getting an education that fits his head and all. Holden doesn't want to be a phony lawyer like his dad because even if a lawyer defends the innocent, he may be doing it for phony reasons like getting accolades. He'd rather be a catcher in the rye. Holden is really a fiend that way, a madman. This novel is a real kick.

I read this because we were going to have a discussion about the book, but after about four chapter's , I had to fight to finish it.  I didn't like all the repetitive speech.  I am glad I didn't have to read this in high school.
A good book of Salinger's work. I ordered it to renew the story I read in college when it was required. Now I can read it because I want to, not have to.

review_headline: No plot really, but still good
review_body: I do enjoy J.D Salingers writing but it kills me when there is no plot in the story. I did enjoy reading the book though.

No, I understand the story.  I just don't get what's so great about Holden Caulfield?  I don't see him as any kind of hero.  To me, Holden is more the kind of kid you met in school who just annoyed the H3LL out of you.  The kind of guy you wanted to avoid at all costs - obnoxious, self centered and thinking he's smarter than everyone else.  Yes, his three lost days in the New York City Underground are interesting and Holden may be cynical, but he's still a looser.
Still a great read!!!! Keeps me laughing I knew there was a reason I wanted to read this classic again

review_headline: Young man and story of his life in college and after he dropped out.
review_body: I had heard of this title and was curious to read it.  Way too many cuss words for me, but I plowed through it.  The story was interesting and interesting about his friends, teachers and family.

I have read tons of comments and references to this work, and about Salinger for so many years, I decided to get a copy of this book, and to be honest, I am very disappointed. I have read that teens and older people have been greatly influenced by this work and the protagonist to the point of committing violence based on alienation depicted. I have mulled this over for a couple of weeks since I read the book and still don't \\"get it\\". In my opinion, there is only enough content in this writing to make a decent short story, which would still not rank near something by Saul Bellow or a dozen or more others. Maybe I'm just too old \\"and all\\", but I can remember my teen years, and I think that if I read this book then, I would not have been able to finish it because it was about such a profoundly stupid guy, privileged but brain-dead. I think the only thing that keeps a reader's attention is trying to get to the end and see if anything redeems the time spent getting that far. I wanted to like it, because I'm a New Englander, and affect anything Yankee, but...

I have continued to think about this book, and why it is so unsatisfactory to me. It's because it's written as a monologue by the protagonist/narrator, who is presented as the child of an upper-middle-class New York City family, but his vocabulary is not in character. To my ears, it sounds like he was written to sound like he did not, could not or would not use the language of his peers. Maybe we are to assume he is mentally retarded, or in modern parlance \\"intellectually challenged\\". Since the other characters he interacts with read as normal, that may be the answer to my complaint.

Whatever the answer, I'm sorry I read the book. Then I could continue to think it and its author were special and excellent, instead of being disappointed.

Prose rattles on about a young college student with a mixed-up personality. Used as an historical analogy of a famous writer's work in many high school English classes. I didn't find the story very interesting and the author's writing abilityoverwhelming.
Looked brand new and came in quickly. Was very happy with the purchase. It seemed to come in within a week of ordering.

So, this rant of run-on sentences that seems to be using some sort of half-bleep, stream-of-consciousness style is considered a harbinger of profound literature?
Me thinks these critics of the so-called literary world shoot up way too much Morpheus and blow way too many snowy lines of sugar.
Capote, Steinbeck, Hemingway, Twain...et al. Now those were literary greats.

Originally posted on The Canon! {[...]}    I first read The Catcher in the Rye during my senior AP English class in high school. To be honest, I didn't quite understand what all the fuss was about; as I saw it, Holden was a bit of a liar and, to me at the time, a showoff. I picked up this book at the local library sale a few years back with every intention of reading it the moment I returned home to see if I had been right at eighteen years, but, well, shiny new books grabbed my attention. I'm glad I finally had the chance to sit down and read The Catcher in the Rye again. It seems I missed a few things the first time around.    THE CHARACTERS  Meet Holden Caulfield, our esteemed narrator. To be honest, Holden isn't the most likable fellow: he stretches the truth right to the point of lying, but rarely beyond; he is overtly critical of others but blind to his own faults and he doesn't mind being sneaky. What I loved about Holden was his love for his younger sister Phoebe and his unerring honesty, something that juxtaposes with his own tendency to exaggerate quite a bit. And when I say honesty, I mean his honesty with his emotions. Holden doesn't try to pretend he is happy when he's not - this same kind of simplicity in emotions is reminiscent of a child.    The strangest thing about Holden for me was his envy of his siblings. His older brother has found his place in the world as a writer in Hollywood, and his younger sister, Phoebe, is enjoying her childhood. I don't think he quite wants what his brother has, but he envies what he sees as his brother's status. In Phoebe, he envies the simplicity and innocence of childhood. The momentous \\"catcher in the rye\\" scene explains Holden's mindset: he wants the responsibility but still the youthfulness.    THE PLOT  On the surface, the plot is strangely simple: a young boy, kicked out of another preparatory school, goes back to New York to live in a hotel for a few days before returning home for winter break so his parents don't know he has been expelled again. Holden is trying to live it up: he tries to order Scotch and sodas (to his dismay, this rarely works), be a ladies' man (the scene in the Lavender Room is hilarious), and live on the wild side.    Under this layer, the themes run rampant. When Holden's brother Allie died, it changed Holden irrecoverably. For me, his memories of Allie and his yearning to return to childhood all tie into the effects of grief, especially upon a younger person. Although we don't know about most of the family beyond Phoebe, it seems that the rest of the family has moved on from Allie's death...all except Holden.    Holding onto the grief from Allie's death puts Holden in a unusual place, mentally and emotionally. Throughout the plot, his emotions and deep desires war with the thoughts in his mind, making for not only an interesting plot, but a quirky narration.    THE WRITING  Speaking of narration, meet one of literature's most unreliable narrators. I mentioned above that Holden has a tendency to exaggerate (greatly) and to lie (occasionally blatantly). He is the epitome of one of my favorite literary techniques - the unreliable narrator. Since Holden himself admits that he is \\"a madman\\" and a liar, we can't take his narration of the story verbatim. The vast amount of exaggeration in the beginning pages made me start thinking about his authenticity, but once we really got into the plot, there was no doubt. Personally, I loved his own admission that everything might not be exactly how he relates it.    THE VERDICT  I forgot how intricate this book is, especially for so few pages. It was fascinating to read these particular themes from such an unreliable perspective. Salinger's work is a bit of a slog until you catch the rhythm, but once you do, it's hard to put Holden's story down.
We enjoyed debating the (flight of ideas) of the main character-- the more you review the text the more the reader can extract from the storyline. Good read.

I am totally engrossed in J.D. Salinger's writing style!  He was way ahead of his time.  I love it so!

This was a really ratty copy and the kinfpd of book that should not be sold, just a cheap paperback but old and beaten up, rips in cover, pages, creases, paper yucky.
I had to re-read this classic by Salinger! Had read it years ago. It's so well written and funny, a true jewel of literature.
Great book, received quickly.  But we all knew that.  Now if I just talk myself into finishing the book.  But that's my problem, isn't it.

Even when read 60+ years after the publication of the book, people of all ages can relate to Holden Caulfield whether you like him or not. And that is the beauty of this book, we are all phonies in some way or another.

If I had been a teenager when I read this book I would feel differently about what I read. I am sure that when I read
"Catcher in The Rye" years ago I thought it was a great book but, as I am now over 60, I just think Holden Caufield is a punk with a lot of growing up to do and more to learn then he knows. He is just as phony as the people he kept calling phony.

Grant

I had never read The Catcher In The Rye for no reason. After watching a documentary on Salinger (PBS) I decided to order the famous novel. I enjoyed that story very much, allowing me to revisit through that reading the New York City I had seen in 1963 being on Christmas vacation. It's funny, serious, poetic... and we get so attached to the main character. A must!
Why is this book called a classic. Boring, boring,boring. Why do they make people read it in high school. What rubbish.

I cannot understand the "Hoopla" around this trashy book!!!
Maybe I'm old fashioned. I found it vulgar and a huge waste of time.

Vonne Anne Heninger
Fast shipping, excellent copy of a great book. Very good reproduction. Great price for this item and it's quality. A keeper for your collection.

Interesting, since when it came out, the book was a best seller.  I felt the protagonist was a "looser" all the time, since all he could use is poor language and blame everything on everyone else.  I read it out of curiosity.

The Catcher in the Rye is an amazing American classic from the perspective of a rebellious teenager during the 1950's. Holden Caulfield is a high school dropout and decides to go spend time in New York on his own. He does many things on his adventures, but the one thing he finds himself believing is that he just doesn't fit into the world, and because of that, he hates the world.

This book does teach a few bad morals and has a reoccurring theme of vulgar language, but I highly recommend the book. It is a very well written and influential book.
Great product , just what was needed it is for my gran daughter suggested reading for her finals in school .

review_headline: Still a wonderful insight into the adolescent mind!
review_body: In the sixties, I had the opportunity to use this novel with secondary English students.  It was the first novel that gave them an opportunity to have a character really speak to them.  Though they were southerners and/or south westerners and not familiar with a northern urban setting, they still found much to feel in common with Holden, especially, the males.  After 50+ years as an educator and social worker, I think that he still speaks to them.  I definitely will pass this on to a young person soon.
right up there with one of the most boring books I've ever read. i didn't get it at all and would not reccomend

An amazing coming of age and realistic book of a sensitive but confused teen who is headed for a breakdown. A Classic and a masterpiece. I found it very hard to lay the book down. I would recommend this book to anyone above the age of fourteen.

review_headline: Good in sight to young people, if not a bit depressing
review_body: Easy read, and simple story, I don't think it's nearly as good as people say it is, but just my opinion.

Read this one in high school and decided to read it again....

JD Salinger creates such a fluid dialogue between the reader and the young man protagonist, one Holden Caulfield, a 17 year old that you will come to know as though he were a dear friend, which you will want to visit every 10 years or so to see how he is doing.

As the story unfolds, you will eagerly want to find out what happens next...and what happens next will almost always surprise you.

There need not be any academic agenda to motivate you to read this one! It's a fun book by a great writer!

Five stars!

Growing up can be incredibly difficult for those like Holden Caulfield. On the verge of adulthood, he stares wide-eyed at a world of impostors, fakers, and phonies, unable to speak their language or to understand anything they do. How can he join them? How can he resist? What hope is there in this world, when to become a man is to become an actor in a bad movie? He sees himself as good and bad, hot and cold, incapable of being a part of a society he loathes, yet feeling quite lonely in his exile. His brothers and sister are his only touchstones. His parents are non-entities. School is prison, and life is some maniacal thing, stretching out in front of him. An abyss. Holden claws and grasps to hold on to innocence, to truth, at least the familiar truth of childhood. Holden instinctively knows that part of him is dying. He knows that something is going to replace him. Something he despises. He must grow up. THE CATCHER IN THE RYE is the best example of TRUE teen angst in literature. The words, the symbols, the atmosphere of dread and despair, all point to a bewildered boy becoming a man. Some do just fine, while those like Holden find it far more difficult to accept, because they feel that in order to become an adult, they must deny reality and put on a mask. There are many like him. This is their story...

I decided to buy this book since I had seen a special tv broadcast about the auther, J.D. Salinger.  When I was in school as a teenager, it was required reading (I am now 73 yrs old) but had not done the \\"required reading\\".  Now that I am retired and have time to spare, I decided to read this book and have also referred it to my adopted 16 year old who is more into electronics and Xbox games.  At any rate, the story is great and relates very well to a teenager's life.  I highly recommend this book.  The writing and imagery is fantastic. My son has been \\"sneaking\\" readings of the first chapter so far!  Hallelujah!

I always considered Thomas Wolf's "Look Homeward Angel" as the best; now I know "Catcher" has it hands up.  As a writer of fiction...E. Ted Gladue.....he has inspired me, for he is what Joyce was about ... there are no rules of writing, create art and use your voice to expand the limits set by others who just read it or teach it.  The English language is not about rules it is about freedom.  Salinger is to American what Proust is to France and Joyce to Ireland.
the book is a wonderful read and quite interesting it has lots of emotions and wonderful for school, i like it a lot.

I decided I had to read this book but am a little disappointed.  The main character is a whiny, lazy, privileged kid.  The dialogue is annoying and repetitive (so many phony people and I got sick of hearing how depressed he was).  I Googled \\"is Catcher in the Rye overrated\\" and found lots of comments that agree.  This book may have been good when it was published but its less than special today.
A second go round for me - still interesting, if a bit dated.  But it's worth the return for a second read.

A Waste of Time
After reading all the favorable reviews, felt it was time to pick one up. A descriptive wandering tale of a troubled mind.
Prefer novel by W E B Griffin.
Somehow I missed reading this book as a teenager and now I wonder what all the fuss was about. I finished it but would not read again.

quick reading, page turner. Everyone should read this book as least once in their lifetime!

Also good for teenagers too!
I thought it was very inmature.  I guess I just don't get it. I wouldn't recommend it.  It is boring, also.

Interesting story about a troubled young man. Sad in many ways. Had never read it before so was interested in learning what all the hype was/is about. The initial hype was, I think, due to the nature of the subject and the frequent use of profanity. In the early 40's, when it was written, that was not the norm and people were shocked. Now, it is used by some people to try to explain that there have always been such confused and upset young people and why they do what the do. For example, the persons who shot John Lennon and Ronald Reagan said they had read this book and saw themselves in the main character, hence, we should understand why they did these despicable acts.

People were raised differently in times passed. We did have disturbed individuals but not to the extent that we have now. Psychologists had not begun to tell people that they were not to blame for their feelings, thoughts or actions. It was someone elses fault, ie. your mother did not understand you, youf father was not around enough as he was too busy working (to make a living, actually) and so on and so forth.

Parents tended to side with the authority figures. Teachers and policemen were looked up to and kids got in trouble if they did not follow the rules. Now, teachers for example, have the parents of their students tell them how wrong they are and they their child is fine and should be catered to. I know this first hand as one of our grown children is a teacher. I NEVEr would have gotten away with some of the stuff his students get by with. I would have been in trouble at home if I did anything wrong at school..

To sum up, odddly enough, this book represents the past and the present. Therefore it was an interesting read.

review_headline: eXCEDED MY EXPECTATIONS AND DIFFERENT FROM WHAT i EXPECTED.
review_body: hEARD ABOUT THIS BOOK BUT NEVER READ IT IN EARLIER YEARS.  LIKED READING IT ON MY KINDLE AT CONVENIENT TIMES.

At 81 years of age I must be one of the last elderly Americans to have read this novel. Supposedly it has sold over 65 million copies! The last two pages said it all. The young man was a manic depressant aggravated by the death of his favorite younger brother and the pandering of his younger sister and others with whom he came in contact.

If we can believe the recent program on PBS the Author was describing most of his own life. Writing a well written biography.

Can you believe the book was never assigned to me in high school. Since I graduated in 1951, the date the book was published may have something to do with it?

Don't read this 'novel/biography' if your over 80 years of age!

Very appropriate for that age group. Especially
now that I'm 50 years beyond that angst. Very
nice. When I bought the book at 15, my father
took it away from me and wouldn't let me read
it, although it was approved reading by my 9th
grade English teacher. All because it had three
curse words on the first page. Damn, hell, and
goddamn. As if I hadn't heard him use all three.

This is a classic coming of age story. I am not a fan of profanity, but in this case the profanity fits the characters that use it and is appropriate for the outrages that occur in the story. (Today authors add profanities all over and anywhere whether or not vulgarity fits the story.)

This book was banned in some high schools because of the swearwords it contains. Today The Catcher in the Rye is read in many high schools and unfortunately still sparks controversy in some communities. I think most teens can handle this book. JD Salinger is a deep thinking, terrific author. No one should skip this read.

This book has been rated for years .  My rating will not add or subtract from its importance as a book which as a pacesetter and prelude to literary and social changes in the post war world will enlighten the young and stimulate the old to remember.

I suppose if you were a young impressionable kid instead of an adult you might see why this is supposed to be such a great book.
I eventually found myself skipping parts and was very relieved when I finished it.
I LOVE THIS BOOK. IT WAS VERY INEXPENSIVE AND A GREAT ADDITION TO THE LIBRARY. ALL SALINGER FANS SHOULD HAVE THIS.
Good

It exceeded my expectations. 1st time I have read this author. Look forward to reading more of his work. Great writer.

I've read this book twice.

The first time, I was disappointed and annoyed (Holden Caulfield is an exaggerated version of every cringe-worthy teenager you've ever met).

The second time, it didn't get that much better but maybe a bit funnier. Once I stopped judging Holden, I started empathizing with him. I still found him very annoying but I also felt sorry for him, in a motherly way.

All in all, I think this is a terrific book for teenagers, to help them become self-aware. But maybe I'm asking for miracles.

I was expecting to read an adult-type writer but instead could have been reading a very young girl's thoughts.  I was going to give it to my son to read at boarding school but there's too much foul language in it.  Now it's just collecting dust.

It was an interesting novel, but it did not catch my attention like many other novels. His plot was interesting, but it was not as mind catching as some of the other writers of his time, like Hemmingway or Steinbeck.
All-time classic. This was the gift for a young adult in the family, and she loved it. Gift of book, the best gift of all.
I enjoyed this book although it wasn't quite what I expected.  It gives you an insight into the many manifestations of mental illness.
Outstanding writing, J. D. Salinger both Holden right into your heart about seeing the world through a boy's outlook on life.
It was an easy read of a weekend in the life of a teenager. I have no idea why it was considered such a great work.

I haven't finished this novel but know that it will be all that is has been raved about....
Easy reading and one feels as though you are right there with the character in the book...
Salinger was, indeed, in a class all his own...

The story of 17-year-old Holden Caulfield stepping from a cloistered life into the real world one weekend is as strong a symbol for rebel-meets-reality as has even been written. The problems I have with the story and the same ones I have always had. Author J.D. Salinger pretty much wrote about himself as Holden -- angry, terse, brilliant, cynical -- in order to separate Holden from a naive run of the mill man newly come of age in this soft, lying, backstabbing universe his parents and their generation created. As I watched Salinger live out his own life until his death a few years ago, he struck me as playing out Holden's days with all of those attitudes. And of course, he never published another novel, retreated to a little traveled town, and rarely came out to play. What is interesting is that he wrote some manuscripts to be published after his death, so hopefully we will get to see the rest of Holden's life unfold -- including, I understand, heaven.

My final prayer is that, inasmuch as he has passed on, I hope a copywriter has the good sense to trim Salinger's three- and four-page paragraphs. They are giant walls of text that are the literary equivalent of the Berlin Wall.
I don't like reading about teenagers who are too lazy to work  Also, there are about 10 words repeated too many times and If at least half of which could be deleted, this would only be a short story.
Acclaimed novel I was re-reading years after my first read. I found it self indulgent and not  quite worthy of all the chit chat.

review_headline: Catcher is useful for starting a fire.
review_body: Delivery and price exceptional.  This was my first Salinger book and also checked out "Franny and Zooey", used "Catcher" to start a fire and returned "F&Z" to the library.

I read this book in high school. I was told by the instructor and by subsequent "authorities" that the book would "speak to me." Well if it was speaking to me it must have been in gibberish.

I found the book to be, at best, tedious and at worst boring.

I found the protagonist to be, at best, totally involved in a one on one relationship with his pathetic and overbearing id.

I am sure that there are people out there who found it to be absorbing, which says more about them than about the book.

I didn't care about the protagonist and I still don't. I think he needs to get over himself.

And yes, I did read the book, it was a waste of my time, a waste of paper and ink and I resent the loss of the time that could have been spent on better items, like Dickens or Plutarch or Tolstoy.
Haven't completed it, but so far it is all that I expected it to be.  A very enjoyable book, worth reading.

I think this book was a successful narrative for an
early 20th century novel.
If written today it would be, in my opinion, it would be some sort
of sophomoric analysis of a neurotic boys world.
Still beguiling after all these years.  Holden is something of a brat, but his adventures are powerful and his attitude toward life memorable.

I bought this book because it's considered a classic - but thought it was a heap of garbage. I don't see what all the hype is about; it's poorly written, the author bumbles through it, it doesn't make sense to me...make up your own mind, but frankly if I could have given it negative stars I would have. that's $5 and time I'll never get back.

review_headline: If only I could give it a lower rating
review_body:
Terrible Terrible book. Any criteria that dictates this book as a "classic" and a work of fiction was obviously invented by someone on a daily dose of LSD.
*Spoiler* this book is about a whiny young man that has no personality and runs away to New York City where he complains how much his life sucks but only ever ALMOST ever doing anything. After said situations he remarks how he "would have [done this] if he just had the chance" instead of seizing the chance when the opportunity arises.
If I save but one soul from reading this horribly, awful book then I consider myself completely a job well done. And I pride myself on being VERY open-minded and let people read what they may, this book is beyond that point.
If this book survives for 100 years the only true usefulness that it will ever produce is that it will keep a FIRE nice and warmer.

Please do not waste your time. There are so many great books out there, fascinating reads that keep you up all night; how this book is in the same category blows my mind. Never was it interesting, never was it controversial, and it just made me so upset I wasted my time, and even more upset I spent money on this book.

I never read this as a young adult so I figured I would see what I had missed. I couldn't wait for it to end. Maybe I
was expecting too much but it is awful. The main character is just a miserable kid. The story is thin at best. Just
a complete disappointment.

review_body: This book is pretty good I'm happy with this purchase !!!! Really helped me in my English class! Recommended to all
This is a cure for insomniacs. It is poorly written and extremely boring. Salinger is highly overrated. Not worth the time going to your local library to get it.
one of the staples of a high school curiculum, still a great read and teaches kids so much about growing up.
This book changed my life. It made me feel like I wasn't alone in this world. Please do yourself a favor and read this book.

I read this book in high school when it was forbidden to read in a catholic school so of course I immediately got a copy and read it , I laughed and throughly enjoyed it so when I oldest granddaughter asked for a copy I send it to her, of course today its no big deal but its still fun read.

This is a very real, organic novel. No mystical far-off kingdoms, no heroical protagonist in center stage.

It is about a very down-to-earth teenage boy experiencing usual, sometimes deviant thoughts and behaviors, the kinds of thoughts and behaviors some of us want to think or do if we did not care about the repercussions.

I think that fans of A Clockwork Orange would like this. Its plot is not as fictional, but I believe it substitutes some of A Clockwork Orange's dysfunction with melancholia, which is something more relatable to for most.
Book was purchased used but was in great condition.  Very happy with quality of the book.  Bought it as required reading.

review_headline: Apparently me and classics don't mix
review_body:
I thought it was the biggest waste of time.
Following the recent death of JD Salinger, I realized I had never read this classic. I had often heard it referred to, especially in circles of child behavioral disability and learning disabilities, so having raised one of those boys, I thought I would take a peek.

I think the argument in favor was that it was different for it's time. A "coming of age" story, and was resonated with due to the theme of teenage angst. Published in 1945, I can only imagine the uproar it caused due to the rawness of the material (tame by today's standards, so actually boring). If I consider the climate of 1945 and how teens were supposed to be behaving and perceived, this would have been one of those books that caused such a stink that people would buy it and read it just to see what the stink was about. Controversy sells. Sort of like The Last Temptation of Christ. Nothing makes me want to read or see something quite like people saying "don't do it...it is horrible".

I'm going to step into the character of Holden and tell you how he would tell you about this book:

"I can't believe all the goddamn phonies who say this is such a hot book and all, I really can't. I mean, what I mean is, it's just a book of random thoughts for chrissake. The entire book takes place in like 3 or 4 days of my lousy life after finding out I had been kicked out of yet one more fancy-pants school my parents wanted me to go to, and what I did during those days, and the junk I thought about. Seemed more like a million years that four or so days. It would depress the hell out of you if you read it, it really would, if you wanna know the truth. I don't see the goddamn point. Literary people are just a bunch of phonies who think something is good and tell people its good when it really isn't. They kill me, they really do."

That's it to me! Those types of phrases are throughout the entire book. I've got no problem with swearing, but it was about every other sentence, so got monotonous. I could care less about the moral objections to the book. By today's standards, it's no big deal. A kid who gets access to alcohol, goes to bars, swears, drops out of school and contemplates hooking up with chicks. No big deal.

Mostly, I was BORED. The book was not a compelling read. And I kept waiting for it to GO somewhere.

From a mental health professional standpoint, I think all the buzz about Holden representing a kid with mental illness and or learning disabilities is a bit of a stretch. It could be ANY kid. He could go through those phases in his rebellion of finding himself as separate from his affluent background. On the other hand, I could clearly see the signs of extreme anxiety, mood swings, obsessive compulsive thought/behavior, and repeated school failure despite demonstrating high intelligence...so it could or it couldn't be indicative...worthy of seeing a counselor for sure. Seems like he was invisible to his parents unless he was in trouble.

He was a sensitive guy who clearly loved his siblings, but had zero tolerance for what he perceived as "phonies" and an inordinately adept skill for seeing hipocracy everywhere. He had no ability to see the gray...all was black and white, good or bad, love or hate and he couldn't make up his mind which way he swung on any moment. He appeared to long to be understood, heard and assisted but all anyone could do was show him his failures, not assist him with a path he could be successful with. And there was HUMOR. I laughed a few times. There was raw honesty and I could see some of my feelings as a teen portrayed in him.

So I guess I understand the potential value, but thought it was the most boring book on the planet...I really did...a godddam bore for chrissake...with a bunch of "emperor's new clothes" critics pushing it to stardom. I think also, the fact that J.D. Salinger stayed in seclusion and did not seek or want or welcome fame, made him a mysterious figure that people became interested in and his very avoidance of fame pushed him unwillingly toward it.

I don't think it should be banned from schools, and I have no real problem with teens reading it (I don't think it seems a good idea for grade or Jr high schools), but I'm not sure where the real value of reading it is...is it assumed because of the questionable subject matter kids will want to read it and it is a way to get "the medicine to go down"? I guess with the right group, the very discussion of "why in the world did this get to be a classic?" is a good discussion place. So I have no moral objection, I just fail to see the value in it.

It is a "classic" so I know there must be a lot of fans of it out there. Tell me why you loved or hated it, or if you fall somewhere in between. I'm glad I can say I read it, so I can be one of those phonies who at least knows what it's about rather than always wondering. Yet I also feel like it is a few hours of my life lost that I'll never get back and could have spent on something better.nger stayed in seclusion and did not seek or want or welcome fame, made him a mysterious figure that people became interested in and his very avoidance of fame pushed him unwillingly toward it.

I don't think it should be banned from schools, and I have no real problem with teens reading it (I don't think it seems a good idea for grade or Jr high schools), but I'm not sure where the real value of reading it is...is it assumed because of the questionable subject matter kids will want to read it and it is a way to get "the medicine to go down"? I guess with the right group, the very discussion of "why in the world did this get to be a classic?" is a good discussion place. So I have no moral objection, I just fail to see the value in it.

It is a "classic" so I know there must be a lot of fans of it out there. Tell me why you loved or hated it, or if you fall somewhere in between. I'm glad I can say I read it, so I can be one of those phonies who at least knows what it's about rather than always wondering. Yet I also feel like it is a few hours of my life lost that I'll never get back and could have spent on something better.

review_headline: An entitled teen runs away from adulthood.
review_body:
I'm going to play the devils advocate here and take the opposite stance that this was one of the most disappointing books I have ever read, maybe not as bad as The Great Gatsby.
The title enters the story when Holden (a high school junior recently expelled from an expensive east coast private boarding school for being delinquent) hears a young child walking along a sidewalk in New York reciting a poem but has the words messed up. This morphs into him internalizing the poem and recognizing that he thinks of being a savior of children unknowingly running through a field of Rye (Wheat) catching them (from death) as they nearly run off an unseen cliff. Whatever.
This story is written in 1940's speak. There are terms to look-up like Grippe and Flitty which are not used today. (I think they mean 'influenza' and 'perverse') Anyone Holden refers to is always prefaced with the title 'old.' There is lots of pointless swearing and smoking references. All of this gets tedious before the 4th chapter.
This is the story of an entitled immature wealthy tall teenage boy, kicked out of an east coast boys boarding school, just before Christmas. He would be due home on Wednesday but makes it home days early instead after a series of bar visits, cab rides, hotel stays, profuse smoking, alcohol abuse, impulse control issues, immature personality problems leading to one bad situation after another. He sits in judgement on about everyone he knows or has laid eyes upon, labeling most of humanity as being phony. He battles with substance abuse problems, a near complete lack of self confidence, an inability to form meaningful relationships, depression, emotionally labile personality, and probably an un-diagnosed case of bipolar disorder. The story reaches no climax, makes no point, only offers about a week long glimpse into the life of a messed-up teenager that is honestly not worth reading. I've read much more relevant books with characters like this elsewhere.

Who wants to read about a whiny, depressed guy that likes no one and finds fault with everyone and everything.  I'm glad some find it interesting. I just don't understand why.

I was also reminded of this book cuz of the PBS show. Those PBS guys are phonies and all, aren't they? Remember a few years ago when their top execs were smoozing up to some phony Muslim Brotherhood guys, trying to get some money from them and everything? That was funny when they got fired.
There are alot of phonies out there. I hate phonies. They put on airs and think they're really smart and special and all. If you ever went lookin for phonies, and I don't know why you would, but if you did just go to Hollywood and Manhattan and the Ivy League schools. They all hang out together and they think exactly the same things cause they're so intellectual and all. Then these guys can write a book that's really hardly about anything at all and everyone says its so deep and so true and everything. But then there really doesn't need to be anything worth a hoot in the book but when everyone says its just so deep and profound and then everyone else agrees. Phonies!
Then you can get to be thought of as even smarter and even more brilliant if you ignore the other eggheads & don't write a bunch of books and you become a recluse. That proves that you're even more brilliant, except you really aren't. The more you snub everyone the more brilliant you get & then you can write a few things that don't say nothin but they're probably just too deep for some of ya to understand. It's like when that guy put a picture of Jesus in a jar of urine and then everyone looked at it and said that he was really brilliant to do that. I don't think that's so brilliant and all. And I don't think this book was either. But that's just me. HC
