review_headline: Why Holden's voice is so important.
review_body:
Catcher in the Rye has been a controversial book since it was first published in 1951. It is important to note that at the time of its publishing the intended audience of Catcher was a more adult audience, but it quickly became popular with teenagers. The voice of J.D. Salinger’s Holden Caulfield captures much of the frustration and cynicism of teenagers and many students claim that Catcher in the Rye is one of the first books that they related to. Unfortunately this book is being banned in some schools, and students are being deprived of the opportunity to engage with this great piece of literature with an experienced teacher who can guide them through all that the book has to offer and place Holden’s words in context.
Critics of Catcher claim that the vulgar language and sexual references are justifications for not teaching the book to high school students, but one of the most important things to recognize with any book is not just what is being said, but why. What does what is said tell you about the narrator, and possibly, the author. Critical thinking is a skill globally recognized as integral to student success in not only school, but in a diverse, global world. The way that Holden speaks is, whether we like it or not, similar to how many young adults speak. Not reading Catcher will not change this, but by reading and discussing why Holden uses that language, how he uses cursing to hide deeper feelings or sexual innuendo to discuss things he is uncomfortable with thinking about, students may come to reflect on how they use language and why.
One of the reasons why Catcher was at one point the most banned and most taught books in U.S. high schools is that it forces students, teachers, and even parents to have these difficult conversations. But it is through recognizing the teenage identity, why Catcher resonates so much with students, staring it the face, that we can make progress on helping teens think about themselves and the world more positively. Yet if this book were not so strikingly real, it could not comment on the “phonies” without being hypocritical and thus, ineffective. Students can spot a prepackaged moral in literature a mile away, and it turns many of them off from learning that lesson because they feel as if they are being talked at instead of talked to. But Catcher in the Rye speaks to students from a teenage level which appeals to many students. The novel makes many students feel that they are not alone in how they look at the world, and this could not be accomplished without the book reflecting our world, with both its flaws and capacity for love.
SPOILER below!
As we come to find out at the end of the novel, the “phoniness” of society and the stress of expectation as a teenager push Holden to his mental limits. No matter how you feel about specific passages in this book, no one wants their child or loved one to feel alone or become depressed and overwhelmed by their world. When we are able to acknowledge that Holden’s while exact story or language use may not be our own, but studying the Catcher in the Rye serves as a gateway to great, generative conversations with our youth about how to address the complex issues of teenage life we will come to see that Catcher in the Rye is an essential high school text not because of the words on the page, but how those words can generate greater awareness and self-knowledge in teens. And maybe, just maybe, get them excited about reading.

review_headline: When a Body Meet a Body
review_body: This was my 3rd reading of the \\"Catcher.\\"  Last read it about 20 yrs ago.  I was influenced to read it again following a recent documentary of J.D. Salinger on PBS.  The Catcher in the Rye reminds me some of Huck Finn.  Both books were narrated by two American youngsters who called things as they saw them.  However, Huck was fighting for his life and for personal freedom, Old Holden was fighting personal madness and inner demons.  Perhaps manic-depression, I don't know for sure.  The thing that I liked most about \\"Catcher\\" is that it is a tale being told by a young 16-17 yr old who has already gone thru the nervous breakdown and angst that he has survived and described in the book.  As the book ends he is getting the help he needed.  Perhaps he will get his demons under control.  Holden advised his sister that if he could have any job he wanted it would be to watch over playing children, he'd be a catcher in the rye.  He would make sure children at play did not fall off a nearby cliff adjacent to a rye field.  Perhaps Holden could someday translate his love and concern for children by getting a job as a teacher or something?  (Perhaps that book is coming from the writings left behind by the deceased Salinger?)  I also believe that Holden Caulfield is J.D. Salinger.  There are so many examples of personal facts that are shared by Holden and Salinger.  One example is that old Sally Hayes is Oono O'Neill.  When I first read the book at age 20 or so I could not relate to Holden.  I saw a whining 16 yr old prep school city boy from a well-to-do NYC family who griped about everyone and everything.  Why care about him and I did not. Today I cut Holden some slack.  The book was published in 1951 and I think it still works today.  Good writing and descriptions.  211 pages of excellent prose.  It took a 3rd reading for me to appreciate the book.  PS: Old J.D. Salinger was a different kind of guy.  As an adult he was infatuated with teenagers and young girls.  Hung out with them.  Borderline pedophile.  Strange dude.em.  Borderline pedophile.  Strange dude.

review_headline: My point of view about this book
review_body:
I think that one of the most intriguing points in Holden's character, related to his prolonged inability to communicate, is Holden's intention to become a deaf-mute
So repulsed is he by the phoniness around him that he wishes not to communicate with anyone, and in a passage filled with personal insight he contemplates a retreat within himself.....

A 'coming of age' narrative widely assigned to high school students, I suspect it will give way to something with more contemporary cultural resonances.  Nonetheless, good to know a USA "classic".

This book remains one of my favorites! It is the quintessential story of fitting into society and growing up at the same time. The episodic nature of this story leaves nothing to be desired. The protagonist leaps from one character to another, all the time struggling with his emerging identity as becoming an adult.

I would recommend this product along with Sirens of Morning Light by Benjamin Anderson, a quest for a man in Iowa to regain his identity, which becomes entangled with people who claim to have known him when he discovers he is a scientific experiment. Make sure not to miss either book.

I read 'The Catcher' in my English grammar school when I was 16, the same age as HC. It was 1962 and I lived in a provincial city  not far from London. I can't remember whether it was set reading or merely advisory, but our teacher spoke highly of it and there was certainly classroom discussion about it. (Interestingly, nothing at all was said about the bad language, slang or the sex. I think I borrowed it from the school library.) What I recall strongly was my complete incredulity at the mode of life of the hero. Here is a guy who (aged 16!!) is leaping in and out of Manhattan cabs and inviting the drivers to have a 'cocktail' with him; flitting in and out of uptown hotels, visiting nightclubs, calling up girls for a 'date' (we didn't have a phone & nor did any girl I knew) and ordering up a tart for a short time. I was amazed, especially as I understood this was a hero who was supposed to be speaking for youths such as me. I had never even been in a cab, let alone by myself; I knew vaguely what a cocktail was but of course had never had one; etc. Frankly, I couldn't understand what species of being Holden was or what the hell he had to do with my life - I found his 'angst' (as we later learned to say) incomprehensible. Now 'Saturday Night and Sunday Morning' - there was a hero I could understand in a place I recognised! I read 'Catcher' again for the first time since 1962 and I STILL can't make sense of these aspects, but in addition it now seems terribly dated.

I'm not sure why this is considered a classic and a literary masterpiece. Throughout the entire book, curse words were used. And I do mean the ENTIRE book! I wrote this review earlier, but it was rejected due to my language choice, although other reviews contain the same words I used. The publishers should take this book off the market. There is no point and the story doesn't move forward. This book has no meaning! Anyway, the main character is sixteen years old, so this is meant for young adults. Please, please, don't let your child or teenager read this book. If you're the teacher who suggested our teenage daughter read this, while she was in high school...shame on you! No teacher should suggest this book to a child! If you want to read this book to say that you've read a 'classic', there are plenty of other great choices available. This was a waste of my time. I only finished it to say that I did and it allows me to give my opinion. And, to my understanding, after reading this trash, is that now...I'm considered a phony.

Please, don't criticize my review, because of my opinion. I've already received a mean comment, just long enough for the comment to be sent to my email, then the originator of the comment removed it from Amazon, before anyone else could read it (I still have the email, for proof). It's called a book review. My review and my opinion. If you liked/loved this book, that's great! I, however, did not. People have different opinions and I respect them, so please, respect mine.

review_headline: A must read for any teenager
review_body:
This is already my second time reading this book since I found it earlier this year. Once I read it the first time from the library, I decided it was one that needed a spot on my bookshelf. Definitely a book on my favorites list, and it will probably remain there because it is so timeless.

I don’t think this will be a book review so much as a recommendation. READ THIS BOOK.

First, I’ll give you a little history. It was written in 1951 and continued throughout the years to earn a spot on the most banned book lists. Not only is it one of the most challenged books, it also made a place for itself as one of the most read books in schools due to its themes that are so prevalent in adolescents.

The Catcher in the Rye is a novel about a cynical teenager who has been kicked out of boarding school yet again and decides to skip out on his last few days and spend them in New York City. Holden, the main character, is just a normal teenage boy who goes on adventures in underground New York. The reader sees the world through Holden’s eyes and feels the impact of each event he goes through. The reader really gets to be inside of his head. It isn’t a book about action and suspense; it’s a book about alienation and the emotions that rage through every teenager.

The book doesn’t focus on what happens to Holden. It focuses on how he takes the events. Sometimes, people get sad for no reason. Sometimes, you feel lonely and just need to talk to somebody. These themes speak to adolescents and adults everywhere because they are still true today. People have always and probably will always have thoughts of alienation and doubts and wondering if they belong. It’s human natures, and J.D. Salinger weaves these issues flawlessly into a brilliant book filled with humor.

I love this book. I have little pieces of paper stuck into the pages where there are passages I reread over and over again. Some of them are just hilarious, andsome of them just ring the truth. All the phrases Holden uses amuse me also. For instance, he says things like “I got a bang out of that” and “that killed me.” Everything about this novel feels so real and so contemporary. I especially love reading it out loud (minus all the cursing) because you can practically hear someone saying those exact words. It has a unique conversationalist writing style.

READ READ READ THIS BOOK!! Trust me, you won’t regret it. Don’t let the age turn you off from it. I procrastinated reading it for a while because I figured it would be a grueling classic with proper language and a difficult plot to follow. Instead, I got one of my favorite books ever. If you look past the 50′s setting, it could have been written yesterday.

Even though The Catcher in the Rye is a literary masterpiece, it is not a very good story.  It is Salinger’s writing style that makes this book a literary masterpiece. The way that Salinger puts the reader in the mind of a sixteen year old kid, Holden Caulfield, to grow up and mature with him is amazing.  The problem with the story however, is the nature of Holden, his whining really starts to get on your nerves.  The reader is overjoyed when Stradlater punches him in the face, and that is not very far into the book.  From a literary standpoint, Holden is a good character. He is somebody that readers can relate to a little, someone that they can aspire to be or not to be.  Holden is a character that everyone is or has been.  Holden leaves no questions unanswered because you are Holden.  That is what makes it a literary masterpiece, but that is also the book’s downfall.  I did not care to read a story about a whiny kid.

A classic piece that was worth a re-read as an adult.

Do yo remember the 'ol distressed red cover too?

I really don't understand why this novel has endured. I understand Holden didn't have his own "catcher in the rye," that society sort of failed him, but it was a lot of slogging to get to that point. Perhaps it was my difficulty with the language. Not for me.

The Catcher in the Rye is a stylistic tour de force, a first-person narrative that is pitch-perfect in its language and in the way that language matches the protagonist, 16-year-old malcontent Holden Caulfield. Holden's narration, with its mixture of insecurity, belligerence and alienation, all delivered in a totally realistic yet unique blend of slang, cadence and verbal stylings, grips the reader from beginning to end. It's like listening to a fascinating character going on and on about his life in incredibly vivid language. You don't want him to ever stop.

This is a fairly rare gift. I can't think of too many books in which it is simply the language of the first person narrator, rather than the story, that is so fascinating that you just want him/her to keep going. Humbert Humbert in Lolita is one of the rare examples. Raymond Chandler's Phillip Marlowe is another.

Anyway, Catcher's author, JD Salinger, had already demonstrated a flair for constructing narratives built around his facility for realistic yet gripping dialogue in a series of short stories published in various magazines over the decade previous to Catcher's publication. An excellent example is the story \\"Pretty Mouth and Green My Eyes,\\" published coincidentally in the New Yorker almost at the exact same time Catcher was hitting bookstore shelves. Prominent earlier examples include \\"Uncle Wiggly in Connecticut\\" and the acclaimed \\"A Perfect Day for Bananafish.\\" Each of these stories shows Salinger revealing character almost exclusively through dialogue and Catcher is his attempt to extend that approach to novel length and revealing a character strictly through his own words over an extended narrative. Done and done brilliantly!

The best comparison I can make to this ability of Salinger's is Ernest Hemingway, whose own early short stories showed the same kind of facility at building drama through dialogue. It was something he also used to great effect in early novels like The Sun Also Rises and A Farewell to Arms, but he then petered out (the utterly embarrassing Across the River and Through the Trees, published about a year before Catcher, shows just how far he descended).

Salinger, of course, didn't share the same fate as Hemingway because he more or less stopped writing (or at least publishing) with a few exceptions (Franny and Zooey, etc.) after the success of Catcher. That's a damn shame but all the better reason to savor what he did produce, especially The Catcher in the Rye.
Arrived in time and in perfect condition.  It looked like this book had never been open.  It's one of my husband's favorites, and a lovely addition to our collection.

review_headline: It has aged well for a novel that probably shouldn't have
review_body:
I missed reading Catcher in the Rye back in high school by a mere choice. My English teacher offered this or Lord of the Flies, and I chose the latter. So now, nearly 20 years later, I can say I finally got around to it.

The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger is not what I expected, but I appreciate its brilliance and enjoyed reading it just the same. I surmise I would have loved it more had I read it as a teenager, confused as I was then about my place in the world, but as an adult I think I better understand its legacy.

review_headline: This is one of those books you just have to read
review_body:
Don't question it, not even halfway through when you realize there is no plot. Just let it go and persevere.

Late one night when you finally reach the last tantalizing word and this strange literary journey draws to an end, you will sit for a while, scratching your head. You will wonder what people see in something so strange, so twisted, so infantile and selfish.

Yes, it is selfish to fill a book with so many self-centered words about a journey with no purpose and a life that has no meaning but to exist, and then call it art.

Then something will happen. A niggling reminder of a word, a phrase, or a scene will creep into your mind as you try to put the exasperating experience behind you. That memory will endure, repeating in your brain as you try to make sense of the insensible. If you are lucky you will have that "aha!" moment when you finally get what all the fuss is about. Perhaps it will sneak up on you, or it may be with you from the first sentence of the first page of this book.

Be patient. It will come and you will finally understand why this maddening novel of nothing is considered great.

I know this is supposed to be one of the best american novels and I would agree that I really did like it. However, I think it was even more of a facsinating read from the standpoint that it does a great job of giving you a glimpse back into your adolescence. The emotional, frustrated angst, and great bliss that you experienced fully and boldy while you were young, seems to have leveled out in most of us. Now this is not a bad thing as it allows us to all make sound decisions and live life a little bit more peacefully, but this book reminds you of the beauty of that stage in your life.

Recently re-read this to see if I'd missed something as a teen. No, it's still one of the crappiest books from one of the worst authors I've ever encountered. How could Salinger not go into hermit mode after getting such unwarranted attention for this bag of crap?

Holden Caufield is a rich dumb kid.  He gets kicked out of school and then spends his father's money on a bunch of misadventures.  It's possible to think that his impressions are somehow intellectually profound.  They are not.  Caufield has momentary flights of fancy that never develop into anything.  To use his words, he's a "phony".

Who doesn't love Catcher in the Rye? I love this book, starts with a bang and never let up. an old book, a classic, well worth reading. I went to an old english boarding school and could easily identify with the main character in many instances.
I missed the Literature classes that had you read alot of classics. This was supposed to be one, but I sure was confused as to what made it so good.

review_headline: The worst book I have ever read
review_body: The book made mo sense I gave it to a friend to read and she did not get past the first three pages.  She disliked it even more than did I.
To me it was the same as when I read it in High School.  I was greatful that the students I work with liked and read it.

review_headline: This is the crappiest book I have ever read in my life
review_body:
I read this book today only because there was a documentary about J.D. Salinger on Netflix which I watched. What in the hell classifies this as a masterpiece???? It was nothing but boring drivel, about a pompous obnoxious spoiled little rich kid who hates school and everyone in his life but his little sister, his writer-brother and his dead brother. I kept reading to find anything interesting on the pages, it was just monotonous...Obviously, Salinger thought his IQ was too high for anyone else around him, yet, there was no plot, no suspense, no activity really, just his malingering thoughts about everything and everyone. It was a complete WASTE OF MY TIME!!! I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone, unless you want to be bored out of your mind....which I certainly was....
Kelly Cyr
Author of "Supreme Love: A Battered Woman's True Story"
This arrived before I expected it, and was in excellent condition. Obviously, not a book for everyone, but it is a classic. You have to remember it's a 16 y/o boy telling the story.

This classic has been a favorite as it depicts a coming-of-age young man which I would suggest has been the experience of most of us at some time in our maturity.  Sleverly written, it is a very clever account by an accomplished author.
I haven't read this for many, many years and forget the content totally. Maybe if I were 14-16, I would have liked it.  But I had to make myself finish it.  Guess I was expecting a lot more.
Very interesting book.  Thought provoking.  I had read this story in high school and had to pick it up. ,
The book got here very quickly & it is a very good piece of literature. It was a good pick.
We need a new copy and the price was right. If you haven't read it in awhile pick it up. Great read.

This is a gift for daughter and I know she will appreciate it.  Its cover is in great condition and it is a lovely book to hold.  In todays digital norms its nice to have an old school book.  Packaged nicely shipped fast

I read this book when I was in high school and it blew me away. As a matter of fact, this book and TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD are the only two books I remember from high school. Then I read it again this week ( I'm in my sixties) and there was nothing there. I kept skipping whole sections because they were very dated and boring. But I won't be hard on Salinger as some people are, because this book is about a time and place and a youth that are no more. I had rather remember it the way it was when I read it the first time,fresh and daring and heart-breaking. Salinger had one thing to say and he said it in this book, and he said it once and he said it better than anyone else. So I give it five stars and hope that other teenagers will be moved the way I was long long ago.

review_headline: great read with one of the great moments in literature...
review_body:
A very good read - Holden Caulfield is surely among the great characters of American fiction. The story of this teenager's angst driven adventure as he is kicked out of boarding school and returns home is a great view into the teenage soul and mind. Its stream of consciousness narration makes for a lively romp, in my view.
Its probably easier to relate to Holden's musings when reading this as a teenager. Reading this as an adult gives a different perspective, but doesn't diminish the read too much. Its a little easier to be critical of Holden and his propensity for youthful high handedness (I wonder how many times the word "phony" is used in this book...mostly to describe adults). Still, the part where Holden describes what he wants to do in life and we understand what exactly is a "Catcher in the Rye" is priceless. That part is a truly magnificent moment in literature....
Great and excellent.. I'm very confortable with this and it works in an excellent way; perfect stuff and just awesome!

Excellent story. Holden's voice is clearly a complex one, as he sifts through various problems in an effort to make sense of the world. It's truly a classic, and Salinger has done a masterful job. The author understood the realities of life, and he paints them clearly in this book. Loved the book and characters.

review_headline: Nothing to write home about - just a one-time time-waster ...
review_body: Nothing to write home about - just a one-time time-waster to exercise your mental muscle. The main character is humorous enough, but your life won't be incomplete if you never read this book.

J.D. Salinger’s the Catcher in the Rye was a very intriguing read for me. This fictional novel that takes place in the 1950’s is quite relatable for any teenager. The book deeply describes the thoughts of one teenage boy, Holden Caulfield, and his struggles with growing up. The theme that the world is full of phony individuals is conveyed throughout this coming of age novel.
Holden Caulfield is a troubled rich boy living in a world full of people whom he does not understand. He goes from one prep school to the next, never receiving his parents acceptance. With a pessimistic view of the world, Holden takes a journey in order to find himself. A person of any age is able to take a trip into the mind of an American teenager by reading the Catcher in the Rye. The text is full of slang from the point of view of a pubescent boy.
Although the book was well thought out and I agreed with many of the writing strategies, one thing that I did not understand was the introduction of the character Jane. Jane serves as Holden’s special girl and love interest. Despite the fact that Holden mentions Jane throughout the book, the girl is never physically presented in the story. Readers want to know what happened to this girl that is always on Holden’s mind.
The book appealed to me on an emotional level. I could relate to many of the things that the boy in the story was going through and thinking. Holden overthinks many things that go on in the world. Each person he meets is highly judged. Admitting it is hard to do, but everyone judges others, and teenagers especially. The book makes it clear that there are people in the world that are genuinely good people with a huge mind and heart, and that there are also people in this world that are simply what they appear to be, fake and phony. The book constantly focuses on this theme.
I am not a big reader. I read when I have to. I must admit that this is one of the few books that I enjoyed greatly. After picking this book up, it was hard to set it back down. I read it in any free time that I was availed. It was nice to get a glimpse of what life may have been like in the 50’s and take a trip into a teenager’s mind of that time. From the book I came to the realization that teenagers of all generations are quite similar. Most see the world through skeptical eyes and only have the slightest clue of what the world will bring to them.
I love this book! I read it when I was 20, but it would be good for anyone between 14-25. If you want a more modern version of this story, read \\"Perks of Being a Wallflower.\\"

I consider \\"Catcher In the Rye\\" to be THE great American novel and have re-read it every 10 years or so since its publication.
How many of you know that J. D. Salinger was one of the Americans who was in D-Day AND that he carried the first 6 chapters of \\"Catcher\\" with him?
This is a book everyone should read.  Such a good story and Holden is an amazing character. I love it.

The Cather in the Rye

Amusing, thoughtful and well written.

Regrettable waste of a bright adolescent wandering through his teenage years.

4 more words are required

review_headline: J.D. Salinger truly shine's. Find yourself in a 12 year old's crazy escape into NYC.
review_body: The Catcher in the Rye is unlike any other book I've ever read. It is truly a deep read. You join Holden on his adventure in New York City, where he discovers the harsh reality of the world. The book is very relatable, and it presents a problem we all face in our lives. If you are double guessing this amazing book don't! This book is a book everyone should read at least once in their lifetime.

review_headline: Catcher in the rye is one of the few required readings in high school that is worth a crap.
review_body: Great classic book. Short sweat and easy for teenagers to relate to. It was the first book I read in high school that I thought was worth a crap
The book is small and light and hard to hold in one hand while reading.  Story is excellent and a must read!

I read a review recently which criticized this classic work simply on the basis that the language was that of the Forties, and times have changed. If a reader is unable to get over this point, and the book was first published in 1951 with sections from earlier years, then it is unlikely that they will be capable of appreciating the main thread of the entire work. Salinger has written from the perspective of a young man, beset by many troubles, who is unable to come to terms with his own life, with society, with the education system which, he seems to feel, has failed him in many ways. It is, from the main character's point of view, a very one-sided, lamenting tale filled with worries, with missed expectations, with mental anguish and hopelessness.

It is a work which is still very relevant in our times, if the reader is able to understand everything that has been packed into the text.

We are confronted with a young man who has failed in college and faces the prospect of returning to his home, his family, with little hope for the future. He has failed before, and we gain the impression very quickly that he knows he will fail again. He has no real interest in society, in the world around him, but has an inner vision of what he wishes to do, where he wishes to be, but not how he can achieve it.

He is a young man lost in memories of better times, of possibilities, of grand ideas. His mind constantly wanders, digressions within the story as he recalls people and places, events which have impressed him, mainly from his childhood and formative years. He is comfortable around younger children and avoids, with few exceptions, conversation with his peers who are, to his way of thinking, boring, shallow or arrogant. We gain the impression that he hates much of society, or the society he has been forced to grow up in, to spend his college years with, and would love to return to an ideal which, perhaps, has never existed.

We follow the wandering thoughts and memories of a man on the brink, overwhelmed by events he cannot understand, surrounded by people who cannot help him, by people who see the chance of taking advantage of his problems for their own ends. We see a man who other people do not want to understand, who cannot see that he has mental problems and that he is completely out of his depth in society. And it makes no difference whether the language used is from the Forties or from our own times: the story is as fresh today as it was over fifty years ago.

That The Catcher in the Rye is one of the most banned books in the United States is understandable: it has been objected to, removed from bookshelves by those who cannot read beyond the words on a page, who cannot see the anguish, the pain, the complete lack of hope a young man feels. People who cannot understand that a seemingly normal young man from a good family, attending a good college, can have problems far beyond those they have experienced themselves. It is a work well worth reading just to delve into the mind of someone faced with insurmountable mental problems, with depression, with hyper-activity who cannot keep his ideas running along one straight track but has to digress, explore, worry and justify.

The more astute reader will understand long before the final passages exactly what this character is talking about as he relates his life and memories, but the closing lines are still an eye-opener, and a warning to society. In modern times it could almost be suggested that this man is one who is working towards a complete breakdown which, with the right tools, could cost the lives of countless others through an act of violent hopelessness.wandering thoughts and memories of a man on the brink, overwhelmed by events he cannot understand, surrounded by people who cannot help him, by people who see the chance of taking advantage of his problems for their own ends. We see a man who other people do not want to understand, who cannot see that he has mental problems and that he is completely out of his depth in society. And it makes no difference whether the language used is from the Forties or from our own times: the story is as fresh today as it was over fifty years ago.

That The Catcher in the Rye is one of the most banned books in the United States is understandable: it has been objected to, removed from bookshelves by those who cannot read beyond the words on a page, who cannot see the anguish, the pain, the complete lack of hope a young man feels. People who cannot understand that a seemingly normal young man from a good family, attending a good college, can have problems far beyond those they have experienced themselves. It is a work well worth reading just to delve into the mind of someone faced with insurmountable mental problems, with depression, with hyper-activity who cannot keep his ideas running along one straight track but has to digress, explore, worry and justify.

The more astute reader will understand long before the final passages exactly what this character is talking about as he relates his life and memories, but the closing lines are still an eye-opener, and a warning to society. In modern times it could almost be suggested that this man is one who is working towards a complete breakdown which, with the right tools, could cost the lives of countless others through an act of violent hopelessness.

review_headline: Is it crazy to be upset about this phony world?
review_body: Holden Caulfield has changed a lot in fifty years, or perhaps this writer has.  As a 19 year-old college freshman I could totally relate to Holden's anguish  with the \\"BS\\" he saw in both the adult world and in the soon-to-be adults he lived with in his boarding school. It is reported that when a prospective editor remarked to Salinger, \\"This kid is crazy,\\" Salinger wept.  True, Holden's negative diatribes about nearly everyone he meets, and his reaction to many seemingly neutral events as well, are familiar symptoms of either depression or bi-polar disorder in today's world. But how many adults didn't experience similar feelings when the onslaught of pubescent hormones were combined with an awakening to some of the  phoniness in the real world? The beauty of this book is the ray of hope in the end as Holden focuses on two things he considered points of light in the otherwise dark world: his little sister and some nice nuns he met in a diner. The reader is left feeling that maybe he's going to be okay, after all.

review_headline: Holden would be known in today's verbiage as a "Hater"
review_body: This book is on many must read lists. Every since I was younger, I heard about this book but never had the opportunity or interest in reading it. At the age 30, I picked this book up and was motivated to read it with an open mind. After reading it, I did not understand why this book is so treasured and revered by so many. My honest take on this book is that the main character was a spoiled, privileged immature child who hated everyone and everything. He was self-centered, negative, and did not really have any redeeming qualities. It was not a coming of age story as some have said because I don't believe his attitude or behavior changed or adjusted throughout the story. Much of his story telling and references appeared as gibberish and I felt at times it had no relevance to what was actually occurring in the book. I guess I just couldn't connect or relate to the main character or the story line. I don't see how relevant it is in today's day and age. Teenagers will always have rebellion and could be self-centered, however, I don’t think all could relate to those that have the opportunity to go to private/boarding schools or the many privileges that the main character had. It also bothered me on how negative his attitude was towards everyone and everything. It today’s verbiage, Holden is a “hater”. And while I certainly did not enjoy this book, I am not a “hater” of this book, and would recommend it for anyone to at least read and judge for themselves whether it’s really a classic.

review_headline: Okay Book - Lots of Swearing & Depression
review_body:
I watched the J.D. Salinger documentary about 3 months ago and everyone in the documentary raved about this book. I am an avid reader so I was pretty excited to get it and I had really high hopes for it, but honestly, it just didn't deliver for me. It was an okay book once you got pass all the swearing and depression. I could not relate to this book, in fact, it almost made me pretty sad reading it. I am not sure why so many people are raving about this book, I really wish that I could relate and understand. A movie is coming out about this book next year (2014), so I will give that a try, although the books are always better than the movies.

I would not recommend this book to anyone that is emotionally sensitive as it seriously might drive someone off the deep end. I also would not suggest this book to anyone who isn't mature enough to handle all the cussing and sexual nature the book disposes.

I first read this book in the summer of 1962, when I was almost as old as Holden Caulfield, the principal character, who is 16. It was one of the first \\"adult\\" books that I had read; a peek into what might await me when I left my safe suburban cocoon. Among other matters that I recall, I realized at the time that although Caulfield was only one year older that I chronologically, he was light years ahead... which could perhaps be quantified as five years... in terms of life experiences, as well as attitude towards authority, and adults in general. Just to be able to rent a hotel room... and in New York City of all places... on one's own was unfathomable, not to mention being able to go into a bar and order a drink. Of course a big reason for that was my lack of money, still scraping by delivering newspapers and mowing lawns, something our \\"guest workers\\" do today. But intertwined with that was the lack of \\"attitude\\" to pull it off. So, over 50 years later, decided to give it a re-read, to see if I or the book aged better over time.

This is J.D. Salinger's most famous work; it was first published in 1951, when he was 31. On the re-read, I was immediately struck by the almost pitch-perfect ear for the slang dialogue of the time. Salinger tells the story as though it were written by a very \\"hip\\" 16-year old. For example, in referencing someone much younger than I today, Caulfield says: \\"You take somebody old as hell, like old Spencer, and they can get a big bang out of buying a blanket.\\"

Caulfield has just been expelled from Pencey boarding school, and will not be returning for the winter term. It is not for lack of intelligence, he just can't see the point of his classes, a theme that has been repeated endlessly through the ages, certainly by, at the time, Paul Goodman, and captured in a lyric from a Simon and Garfunkel song: \\"...When I look back on all the crap I learned in high school, It's a wonder I can think at all...\\" The \\"trap\\" of that attitude is to descend into mindless \\"nihilism,\\" or become a cult follower of some ideology, or just someone else with \\"the answer.\\"

For Caulfield, most everyone is a \\"phony,\\" from his fellow students to his teachers and Headmasters, and Salinger does work in some telling examples. On the first read, and perhaps even today, I'm still more willing to accept people at face-value. Not so Caulfield, who more properly saw through facades, and understood the underlying motives of people. After being expelled, and yes, with some money, before going home to \\"face the music\\" with dear old dad, involving his latest failure, he is on \\"the lam\\" in NYC for a few days, and that is the core of the novel. Of course women are involved... the ones of his own age that he has been \\"hustling,\\" and the others, of the bars, and even a \\"professional.\\" There are the details involving the young women of school, for example Jane Gallagher who \\"...keeps all her kings in the back row...\\" (referring to checkers, and maybe a bit more). And there is the simply dealing with adults, be they cab drivers, doormen, or bartenders. In terms of the dialogue of the time, and I certainly do not recall this, homosexuals were referred to as \\"flits.\\"

Based on the almost 3,500 reviews at Amazon (with over 350 being 1-stars), the novel is still read today, all too often in that \\"dreaded category\\" of being a school assignment. Many of the 1-stars are simply because it was a \\"school assignment,\\" but some of the more thoughtful ones involve the fact that Caulfield is not a very likeable character: spoiled, irrational and irresponsible. All too true, but I've never considered this a reason to \\"rap\\" a book. The real question should be: Is the portrait of an unlikable character authentic? And I think Salinger hits on all cylinders using this criteria. It was a rewarding trip down memory lane, at a time I am no longer \\"carded\\" when asking for a drink, and I AM the adult that the \\"kids\\" in high schoolhave to be skeptical of. 5-stars.have to be skeptical of. 5-stars.

review_headline: A GREAT BOOK FOR ITS TIME, BUT "LIFE AIN'T KIND" IS A FAR BETTER READ TODAY
review_body:
I read \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" in 1975 during my freshman year in college. It's a very easy book to read and just the right length; any longer would have made it annoying. It's a book that, for some reason, has been extremely important to loners & social misfits such as the man who murdered John Lennon. It is what you'd call a Cult Classic in juvenile literature.

Holden Caulfield is clearly a very disturbed young man who feels like he doesn't belong to the real world. Even if Holden could create a world of his own, he still wouldn't be happy. Holden is sincere and wants to be loved by others, but his personality is too flawed for him to accomplish this task. He feels sorry for himself & lives in a world that is detached from reality. The harder he tries, the more disappointed he becomes until he finally ends up as a patient at a TB hospital. Many readers believe that he's actually at a mental hospital, but that's not true. He tells us that at the end of the 1st chapter. However, while at the TB hospital, he is talked to by a psychiatrist who encourages him to write this book.

I was reading this book & Albert Camus' \\"The Stranger\\" at the same time and felt that I could write a book that was as good as both of them combined. It took me about 35 years before I got around to it, but my new novel is now on its way to the publisher. It is about a young violinist/pianist who goes through some very bad times. The title is \\"LIFE AIN'T KIND\\" and you can learn more about it at:

[...]

It's a much more sophisticated version of \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" and not quite a corny. A lot to chew on, including what I call \\"threads of Mahler.\\" Soon to be on Amazon & other sites-- Check it out!
Must be something "over my head".  I don't get the popularity of this over the years.  Must be a guy thing.
OK, but fail to see what the hype is about. Interesting reading of a seemingly biographical plot. Ok as a general read or part of a english lit. program

review_headline: not what it used to be for me
review_body: I owned this addition and read it in high school.  Doesn't excite me as much as it did then.  Book was in reasonable condition but had the old book smell

I am not finished with this book yet but so far I LOVE IT!!! Its in great condition and arrived in two days time. I cant put the book down but i had to force myself to so i could run errands haha! And also i dont want to finish it too fast- must enjoy it ;]

I guess I'm too old to understand this gibberish of a spoiled child.  What nonsense.  To think this supposedly influenced an entire generation is sickening.  I read it years ago and thought the same thing, but I recently saw the movie "Salinger" and really liked the movie, so I decided to reread Catcher........it was worse than I remembered it.  Shallowness to it's most shallow depth.
An amazing classic book, for any reader. In great condition as well. I am very satisfied with this purchase. I will keep it for years to come.

review_headline: Wrapped in the 50's of New York...
review_body: What was all the fuss about? Too New York/back East, too 50's. Not relevant. Too much swearing. Today's young people have a different disconnect, doubt they would identify with the main character...
Book arrived on  time in new condition.  It had  the original  cover version which is one of the reasons I bought it .
Classic book for my book club. Came as ordered and in good shape. Still a good read after all these years.
This book sux.  Sounds like it's written by a reject from the Archie comics and really goes nowhere.  I understand that a lot of people really related to the writer's voice, I did not!

review_headline: relatable for teens, and a lesson for adults
review_body: I think that The Catcher in the Rye is a book that should be read by every high school student. Although many argue that this novel is boring and contains virtually no plot, I think when read thoroughly it can teach teenagers a lot. Most importantly, that they are not alone in what they are feeling. The struggle of dealing with being torn between growing up and staying a kid is something that every teen goes through, and this book weighs out the pros and cons of both sides. Salinger also managed to find a way to relate to almost every type of teenager - Caulfield is the perfect example of a mixture of many high school stereotypes, making this book comforting to many. Not only this, but Salinger also created a setting that can still be related to more than sixty years later. Even though many years have passed since this novel was published, Salinger wrote in a way that managed to capture unchanging human characteristics much more than the constantly changing surroundings. Salinger uses a myriad of tricks to keep teens interested in his book - witty humor, talk of sex and alcohol, and a general \\"you're not better than me\\" attitude from Caulfield directed at his elders. However, high school students are not the only people who could benefit from reading this book. While most adults will probably at first view Caulfield's character as a typical disrespectful teenager, The Catcher in the Rye provides glimpses inside his head that show he may not intentionally be causing harm. I think Salinger hoped to show adults what is really going on in the mind of teenagers when they talk back and act irrationally, that many are just going through their own problems and aren't sure of any reasonable solutions. For example, the death of Caulfield's brother and his flunking out of school numerous times had a serious effect on his sanity and caused him to act how he did. Overall, I think everyone should give this book a chance. If you don't like it the first time, take a break, channelyour inner teenage angst, and try again.

This is my fourth time reading this phenomenal book written by J.D.Salinger and I know for a fact it wont be the last. This book will always be an all time favorite for me for a myriad of reasons, it contains so many unique aspects that continue to draw me back in to reading it time after time. One of the main reasons I enjoy reading this book is for my long love of New York City.As Caulfield ventures through the concrete jungle in search for his true self Salinger does a damn well job of describing the ins and outs of what its like to stroll down the sidewalk with no idea where to go next. Being a New York City native for the early years of my life (0-7), if I'm ever searching for a nostalgic feeling of the adolescent years of my life I know I can always give this book a read. Another reason I find myself always coming back to this book is, I find Salinger's colloquial direct address to the reader style of writing almost relaxing in some sort of way. When Holden presents a direct address to the reader I cant help but feel the need to generate my own opinion on what hes contemplating over. I have a weakness for books that present the thoughts of the main character as they progress along the storyline because I feel as if I'm reading the characters personal journal as oppose to wondering what the characters thinking at all times and have to generate my own thoughts for them, if that makes sense? All in all some may say that The Catcher in The Rye is just a poorly written plotless story about some degenerate who wastes his days wandering the congested city streets hiding from life but I completely disagree I believe that the novel is the the most unique book written in the 20th century, with its exclusive style of writing and on the ball feel of what its like to be in the city.
Read this because of the news of Salinger's death, even though I am a woman my 70's.  It was a very different "slice of life" for me, but held my interest.  I liked it.

The Catcher in the Rye is a great book but is certainly not for the feint of heart. It deals with real world issues and the alienation of the a 16 year old kid..
Despite being written in 1951 It has many topics teenagers would be able to relate too. It is a modern classic of the coming of building romans . I find the main character, 16-year-old Holden Caulfield, very intriguing and as I read the book, it was fascinating to get inside the head of the strange, rebellious teenager.
The book begins with Holden directly addressing the reader, and he begins to retell the events over a three day period from last December. His story starts at Pencey Prep, a prestigious boarding school filled with \\"phonies\\", as Holden likes to call them.
What I find the to be the most interesting part is how from the beginning of the book where Holden is being characterized as insolent, lazy and , completely clueless about his future and what to do in the present.
Almost all of the story is one long flashback of this three day escapade with the occasional references to the present. One thing that sets The Catcher in the Rye apart from other similar novels, is the fairly frequent use of profanity. There is not a page in the book where there is not at least one highly profane sentence uttered by young Holden. This is effective in making the reader relate to the characters better and make the characters seem realistic, but on the other hand, if you're under fourteen, I would certainly not recommend the novel to you! It isn't only the language used that makes The Catcher in the Rye unsuitable for younger readers, but also the sexual innuendos that are through out the whole book. This also adds to the development of the holden showing that he is still a teenage boy at heart and has the sexual desire. The ever present theme of not wanting to grow up is what drives Holden to madness by the end of the story.
J.D. Salinger's novel is a wake-up call to all teenagers and in a sense, is an inspiring read because it sends out the message that we should all remain hopeful and true to ourselves. Teenagers can relate to it because of its complex themes of rebellion, identity and independence but I would recommend you read it before you're an adult otherwise you may have the urge to slap Holden for his actions when reading the book!
No one before or since has captured the American adolescent mentality as skillfully and as movingly Salinger. A true American classsic which will probably be read forever.

The main character, 17-year-old Holden Caulfield, is full of contradictions and wants you, his listener, to believe that he is riding on top of the world. That he has no issues.  This `Jive' narrative continues as you begin to realize that his world is collapsing from under his feet.  He also wants to be there to protect those that he feels are helpless but he has no clue on how to help himself.  Thee brilliance of the book, in my opinion, is that there is a strong undercurrent going on below the Jive of the speaker and yet not a single word of this is spoken in the book.  Brilliant!  The beauty of this book is that he is ultimately saved by someone he felt needed his protection.
This book has to be one of the greatest books I've ever read in high school. Such a great book to read. It's now in my collection of books.

review_headline: What do this book and the song "American Pie" have in common?
review_body: The meaning of both is, "It means never having to work again."  That is Don McLean's quote, talking about the song, not Catcher in the Rye.  I don't think Salinger was set for life, maybe he was, I'm not sure how much this made in his lifetime.  Franny & Zooey is another one of his very few published works, and it gets read about as often as everything otehr than "Lord of the Flies" that William Golding wrote.  Ok, that's my random reveiw of Catcher in the Rye.  I hope no one really needs to read an Amazon review on this book.

review_headline: Slight "catch" in "The Catcher in the Rye"
review_body: Got this paperback edition due to my aroused re-interest in Salinger's work, from the film just released about him (2013.) Didn't realize that this publication is relatively small in size and thus makes it slightly harder to read. Have seen better quality publications of this book in the past.
I love this book and have probably read it 7 times in 4 years. Salinger writes a great story. I like his writing style and it's one of the best "novels they make you read in school."
Bought for son -- great novel!  The high school reads this book in 10th grade, but had him read it in 9th.

review_headline: The book's greater impact and relevance has long passed
review_body: I still believe this book should be required reading for all High School freshman classes.Item was delivered fast and in good condition- all pages clean. Warning: type or font is small.

review_headline: Did not like it at all.
review_body: I do not understand why this is a classic and if a child of mine had this book for required reading I would not allow it.
Came in perfect condition,and it's sort of small but whatever, Great great great book. Really happy with my purchase :)

I'm not really quite sure what all the fuss is about this book...
I certainly found the narrative engaging, and I really enjoyed the authenticity with which Holden seemed to speak and express himself, but, while I identified with much of the way he felt and (re)acted, and the internal monologues were simply dead-on perfect, I never really connected with anything until I was nearly 90% finished. Perhaps had I read this when I was younger it would have affected me more, but now, as I try to find or create a connection, I'm just left... Well. I'm just left.

It was Mr. Antolini's note to Holden that finally grabbed my attention.
\\"It is the mark of an immature man that he wants to die nobly for a cause, while it is the mark of a mature man that he wants to live humbly for one.\\"

I was told I was too immature recently, and it just killed me. \\"Boy, it really did.\\"
I tried to figure it out and tried to understand how I gave that off. Without truly knowing what I was doing, I think I realized that I had given up on the option of living humbly (or living at all) for any cause at all long ago. Whether it be something, someone, or just myself. At some point I was finally able to see something in front of me and felt like I understood what it was to live for something. Not just, as I've often thought in the past, to be the catcher in the rye for anyone who strayed too close to the edge but to be the catcher for a specific reason... and to equally allow the possibility that I also, at times, might need a catcher myself. I wish I had the gift of speech and introspection such that I could have so succinctly put my thoughts, feelings, and actions into words.

This epiphany... or at least the motivation for it... evaporated quite quickly, and I, missing the point, fell back into searching for something for which I could nobly die.

To see Holden cry for and over his little sister for whom he obviously held a great respect and had the utmost love, come to the conclusion that he should not tell anyone anything was quite rather depressing. I waver, but is it worse to live in fear of missing someone and, therefore, remain isolated or is it worse to allow yourself to catch and be caught and, inevitably, miss those who caught you and are now gone? Did he \\"really like\\" people who were dead precisely because the only thing left to do was miss them? Knowing there was no hope of actually being open with those that he'd lost and, therefore, no risk in missing them more seems like the perfect depressing escape. One with which, in the past, I likely would have agreed completely. I still struggle with that question today, and I honestly don't know the answer, but I am glad this book turned out the way it did giving me another pretty clear perspective into one potential answer to one of life's most important questions.

For Holden to have kept Mr. Antolini's paper (especially in a way that seemed meaningful to him) and still arrive at his final conclusion was a bit jarring. Especially in light of the final scenes when he *should* have been able to see the cause right in front of his face, even if he couldn't realize that he himself was cause enough.

Sooo... I had to try pretty hard to pull something out of this that seemed to really matter to me, but I think I got it. Or at least I got something. Overall, enjoyable, but nothing particularly amazing. At least I can now say that I've read it.t and had the utmost love, come to the conclusion that he should not tell anyone anything was quite rather depressing. Sooo... I had to try pretty hard to pull something out of this that seemed to really matter to me, but I think I got it. Or at least I got something. Overall, enjoyable, but nothing particularly amazing. At least I can now say that I've read it.

The book came quickly and was of good quality. My child needed it for a project and I needed an inexpensive version that could get to me quickly. Bingo!

review_headline: Not a book that I can recommend
review_body: I think, had I read this book as a teenager, I may have enjoyed it. As it is, I think that Holden just served to show, in a timeless way, what nasty little buggars teenagers are. It was easy to imagine this in a current setting rather than 60-70 years ago. The writing had a nice flow to it, very easy to read. But this was a book that I just couldn't seem to like. This may be in part due to the fact that I read \\"Looking for Alaska\\" at the same time. The books were very similar, but because I liked the other so much, I think that may have made me like this one that much less. I am almost ashamed to admit that it took me just about 3 weeks to read this barely 200 page book. But I suppose that's just a testament to how bad I thought it was.
I just fail to realize the literary wonder that this turd with covers became. It is as exciting as watching a tree grow or paint drying.

I haven't read it since high school and look forwarding to it again now, 25 years later.

Cant beat the price for a new book either.
What we would normally think and don't say is all in this book.  Excellent read after all these years since published.
Reading this book made me REALIZE why there were so many serial killers, child rapists and the like in the 60s, 70s & 80s. I must admit the book was funny at times but overall depressing.
the book is full of foul language and inappropriate themes. Should not be considered adolescent literature. very upset that our school district is teaching this book

review_headline: excellent trader but book was rubbish to read
review_body: Over the years I've heard so much about this \\"classic\\" that I decided at last to read it.  What a load of rubbish. About some teenager that appears to have no aim in life and seems unable to do even the simplest tasks

review_headline: Wished somebody would have stopped me from going over the edge
review_body: To paraphrase Hunter S. Thompson, \\"Only those who have gone over the edge know where it is.\\" That's true for many things in life, but perhaps it is especially applicable towards crossing that threshold between childhood and the grinding stark realities of adult life in the crazy wow, zing, zam of the American day show. This book illustrates beautifully the refusal to cross too quickly that threshold from which there is no return. Holden views children and childhood as holy, and finds some solace in escapades engaged in while flitting about New York City in a semi-vortex between childhood and finally growing up. This is a classic coming of age story, very well known to High School students, but it is a timeless tale that can stick with a reader well into adulthood.

Depressing.
Read it with my sons sophomore English. Good lesson to compare for social studies classes...good discussion for high schoolers....too much cussing...the guy is a looser...why is this book famous??? DEPRESSING!!!!!
Just OK, thought it was a hardback but was difficult to discern from advertisement. So just, OK, nothing more for now.
A most boring book. My Daughter had to read it over the summer for her honors english class. Ho hum.
Salinger was a mystery. Or at least he tried to think he was. But his stories are genius.  This story, read and different ages in life, is almost like a new read.

This is a classic book and everyone should read it. Most people relate to the main character, but there is a character for everyone. Great style of writing too so it's super easy to read. I promise you'll love it.
DEcided to try this after (not) reading it in H.S.  It was easy enought to read, but I found it marginally entertaining.

review_headline: Don't Judge a Book by it's Cover
review_body: Most of the books I've bought used from Amazon are in good condition, and hardly look used. This one, however, has A LOT of tape on the binding/cover. The important part is that the inside is intact, legible, and pretty much like new (it's the same story on the inside). If you care about the outside, I would suggest buying it new.

What can one say about the "Catcher in the Rye", that hasn't been said before. Written in 1951 in a world very different from that of today and voiced by Holden Caulfield a teenager speaking to adults it became a big hit with adolescents at the time. Even today it resonates as a testament to teenage rebellion. It sells very well every year or so I read and this is because of its ongoing relevance with younger people. J. D. Salinger was a quite complex man and he has recently been newsworthy as some stories which he wrote but would never have published are now to see the light of day. Salinger was in his early thirties at the time of writing and had just gone through WW2 and he captures the mood of the immediate post war period with his first person narrative style as Holden grapples with his identity, his belonging, connecting and his alienation from the older generation. I have read "Catcher in the Rye" as a younger person and now later in life and find it a challenging but rewarding book. It is disjointed and episodic and Holden is a bit of a whiny character but he crystalises a period in time which was unique in its circumstances, but very recognisable in its humanness.
Worth the effort.
So glad I got what I wanted, totally brand new copy of the book I was looking for. Thanx again yall the shiz-nit dude...

It's strange, but I agree with the tagline of this novel for once. Usually it's just there for dramatic effect. \\"You'll never forget this story, this story will haunt you for life....,etc\\", but this one actually has proven true. I read this months ago and now that I'm adding the reviews to the blog from Goodreads and my mental reservoir, I have to say that this book truly has never left me. I think of it at least once every two weeks. I have no idea why really, but I think there's such a total genuineness about it that it really gets inside you.

The book isn't perfect because of the bizarre writing style, which would turn some off. I know some don't even keep going. You should push through any awkward growing pains, though, as it did prove to be so rewarding. The main character of Holden Caulfield is hard to get into at first, since he initially seems to be a smart-alek, dirty-mouthed, negative kid who doesn't care about much. It becomes clear after awhile he's troubled, lonely, compassionate, and actually a sweetheart.

You end up feeling for him, caring about what happens, and trying to figure out how he can turn himself around, or if he even wants to and has reason enough to try. He is certainly not the typical character to read about, and this type of character is another reason I feel reading fiction encourages the growth of empathy in people so much.

The scene that really stands out to me is the sadness of the hotel room scenario between Holden, the girl, and her pimp. How tragic and I felt for him as his youth really came through.

It's a completely character-orientated novel. There's a strange opening to the book where not much is going on, and little ever happens action-wise. It's mainly an introverted thinking novel. You don't get the sense that the boy is troubled until a few chapters in, other than he's failing out of school. I would have liked a longer ending also, to see his parents reactions and more details of what happened next.

Overall this is a worthy classic - I felt for the character and thought it held interesting insight. Language is pretty graphic so some parents may not want their kids reading it if too young. There's no sex or anything violent, although their are several adult implications. For the life of me I can't understand some of the blame from criminals on this book - the person is troubled, fragile, and lonely, but they are not violent, twisted, or evil.

I rated this four stars after I read it because of some of the overly long paragraphs and ramblings got a bit much sometimes, and I would have enjoyed a little more action and thought editing slightly would have helped. However, if I rated it now from memory alone would have went for the big 5-star label. It's just one of those books that truly stays with you.of what happened next.

Salinger has created a unique voice in literature that makes you feel like he's talking just to you. He rebels  against 'phoniness' with such vulnerability and knows you're right there with him feeling  the hyporacy too. He uses words like  'swell', lousy' and ' stuff like that'  and you feel so damn close with him like you're his confidante. I love old Holden! I really do!
