I heard that 4 people shot other people and blamed it on this book. Im only half way in but I don't see what all the fuss is about.
My son loved the book and had to read it for his summer assignment this year. I was surprised by house quickly he was hooked.

review_headline: If a body meets a  body...
review_body: Holden Caulfield has lost one brother and is separated from another. This is only part of what has distracted him and helped to get him expelled again from prep school.  He is disillusioned by what are supposed to be his role models.  He is disturbed by the unfamiliarity and ambivalence of his own sexual feelings.  He hates acquaintances mistreating his other classmates and dorm mates.  He hates his own friends and then loves them shortly after.  His touchstone turns out to be in his own family.  I taught  many of  the Holden Caulfields in my school district in Michigan.  Most would get confused, sad, angry, heartbroken only to shake it off and amaze me with their spontaneity and insight.  Be there for them, but in the background if possible.  May all adolescents  have their day as  the \\"bigger kid\\" that \\"catches\\"  the littler ones running in the rye and about to fall off the cliff.  I loved Catcher in the Rye.  I bought it from Amazon and will soon buy SALINGER when on DVD.  LEB
The book is so nice~I like it~Thanks~It came so fast, and it is really light. Convenient to carry~I am really appreciate that~ Thanks again.

review_headline: Plot - 2, Characters - 4, Theme - 3, Voice - 4, Setting - 4, Overall - 4
review_body:
1) Plot (2 stars) - A boy gets kicked out of his prep school and wanders around New York for a few days before going home. That's about all there was for a macro-plot, and there wasn't a whole lot of micro-tension in the individual scenes either.

2) Characters (4 stars) - Holden Caulfield is the bright but immature lead. He sees things, \\"phony\\" things, in the world around him, but doesn't know how to react to them or to the emotions they generate within him. He's a fun guy to go on a midnight search for adventure with; especially after he reveals little bits about his past which provide clues as to why he acts in the way he acts. The other characters were very minor, but all felt real as Holden bounced into them and moved on.

3) Theme (3 stars) - The main character obviously doesn't like the \\"phoniness\\" of the world around him. But neither he nor the author really explores the nature of phoniness. The other theme was around not fitting into society, and what your choices are when that happens. This theme was explored in a little more detail, but still no answer or deep perspective was offered.

4) Voice (4 stars) - The tale was told as a stream of conscious narrative from the main character. And Salinger does a marvelous job of using idioms, repetitions, and tangential thoughts to create an unusual mood and perspective.

5) Setting (4 stars) - The story takes place in New York City, and I certainly felt transported to the taxi cabs, bars, and everyday strangers you meet. But also the story takes place in Holden's head--in his emotions, wandering thoughts, and spontaneous bursts of responses--and when I put the book down, something magical happened: I started viewing the world as if I was still in Holden's head.

6) Overall (4 stars) - The book doesn't have much of a plot. But if you can get through that, and just sort of let the prose settle you into the head of the main character, I think it's a ride worth taking. Holden's not amazingly wise or kind or anything, but he is very unusual, and for that I'd recommend the book.
Hope to see the movie too...It's called Salinger.  I hope it sheds some light on the author's life and challenges.

Reviewing books can be tough b/c everyone has their perspective. Here is mine

If you are unfamiliar with the premise, this story revolves around the main character's few days of exploration between leaving school and going home for the holidays. I won't spoil anything for you, so I'll just say that the character goes through several explanations of the people he knows and how he interprets their worth. As I read, I felt that he traveled farther in his head than he did physically, but he wished the fantasy could match the reality. The title of the book is explained but I feel that many folks may not fully understand the symbolic nature of the meaning. Perhaps you will
I was very borderline about the book. i don't hate it and it's nothing like Shakespeare but I don't like it either.
Catcher in the rye as always been a great read even though everyone wants to be againist it.  Everyone should read it

review_headline: Not a coming of age story
review_body:
I disagree that this is a coming of age story. It's a tragic story on so many levels. Holden is obviously depressed and delusional. Still reeling from his brother's death. Kicked out of school and afraid to go home and face his parents. Why? His sister shows at the end by hiding her face under the pillow that she's afraid of them too. So much so, that they are barely even written about or told to us by Holden himself.

There's a mention briefly about possible sexual abuse that appears to be glossed over by the author. Add all of this up, and you have the makings of a \\"madman\\" which is mentioned countless times throughout the novel. Holden is made to be likeable with his constant contradictions and ironic behavior. He hates everyone and yet he wants to be with them. The only one he truly doesn't hate is his younger sister. Why is that? She has no power over him. A tedious read and it goes against what writer are taught to write, because the protagonist does not change through his journey. He didn't have to chose a path to take.

review_headline: The CATHER IN THE RYE - SHOOT ME IN THE EYE!
review_body: Uggghhh. Need I say more? If you weren't depressed or disturbed before you read this book, you will be SOON afterward. I had a difficult time growing up all on my own and have NO desire to relieve any of it - especially to this degree of angst.
another  high school book JD  had  a way of  capturing  teen angst,  and  i was  one in full throttle, a mis fit  in limbo

review_headline: Must-Read's are sometimes a hit & miss
review_body:
I read this book because I was never compelled to as required reading in school and because every list of modern classics had it as a \\"must-read\\".
I may be alone in this but I did not enjoy this book...in fact I forced myself to finish it. I believe had I read this book in my formative years I may have had another conclusion as the plot does not follow the formulaic nature of so many works of fiction. However, this was not my first venture into nontraditional plot lines so it did not have the same impact.
I did enjoy the period nature of the story and the fact that one must appreciate that some of the defiant acts of Holden Caulfield were quite defiant for the day. Still, it was the overall brooding, pessimistic attitude of the plot that served as a turnoff for me. I suppose life is filled with enough to be pessimistic about that I didn't enjoy it as the premise of a book.
In any case, I am glad that I read it, if only to say I read it however, I wouldn't anticipate placing it on my re-read list of books any time soon.

I thought that the catcher in the rye was written by a social drop-out who was negative toward everything. He must have tried hard to include the words "God Damn" at least a few times in every page.The only congregation of trash in a bigger pile is the Kardashian family of TV and Media fame.

Frank
When I was younger this book was banned in schools & libraries. So now I figured would be a good time to read it.
This is the smallest paperback I have ever seen.  I expected this to be the same size as a similar book I just ordered.  The book is too small and the print too tiny to read and enjoy.
Just never knew to think the dude was gay...that's what someone told me. I always thought the guy had problems with people and relationships in general.

review_headline: Teenage Depression and the Catcher in the Rye
review_body:
65 million copies in print since 1951 and we are still divided into one of two camps. We either glorify Holden Caulfield as a teen sounding the anthem of rebellion for generations of our youth or we vilify his disregard for normalcy along with his x-rated coming of age and attempt to shield our children from the stark reality of the real world. 65 million copies in print yet it still holds records as the most censored text in American history. It's an enigma. I will not attempt to understand the irony of such numbers or dissect what many believe to be the perfect novel, alongside one or two others, Huckleberry Finn and Gatsby of particular note. Legions of academics have come before and attempted to pull forth the inner meaning of the scenes in his dorm, the stories of his friends and family, in particular the death of his brother and relationship with his younger sister. Even more poignant would be the potential deflowering of Jane Gallagher, the girl next door, which seems perilously close to the first published incidence of date rape, for which Caulfield gets a bloody mouth trying to rise in her defense, but for which J.D. Salinger, never takes the opportunity to investigate fully. What a missed opportunity for what would surely be a fantastic prescience of a modern scourge.

Beyond Salinger's description of what it might like to be \\"Down and Out in Paris and London\\", ala Orwell, we never quite arrive. When Kerouac paints the seedy underbelly of America in, \\"On the Road\\" Caulfield can't quite go those places, after all he's only 16. And beyond \\"Gatsby\\", F. Scott's descent into alcoholism, in \\"the Beautiful and the Damned\\", we don't see much change from being on the streets in New York a generation later. The streets are still no less unforgiving of character.

In modern times, perhaps Haruki Murakami comes the closest to being on the street, as a teenager, but for him it's in Tokyo, and with him \\"After Dark\\" touches something that Salinger has brilliantly described, but has left unnamed. Murakami doesn't shy away from depression and suicide. Salinger ran through the door, yet left it all unnamed. I haven't done a comprehensive search for other's of the 65 million readers who think that Salinger accurately depicts teenage depression, but to me, this is his real genius. Without a doubt, Salinger had first hand experience with depression, whether it's his own or someone close to him...what he has brought to us, since most schools seem to include it as required reading, should be the open conversation we have with our kids about depression. This should be the conversation from \\"Catcher\\", not one of being rebellious or being sexual or homosexual or dropping out of school or having a plan for our lives or the sage advice of Wilhelm Stekel. Depression should be our first stop, those other topics, are heavily treated elsewhere in modern society. Depression and in particular teenage depression still remains stigmatized and taboo.

I'm going to give this book 5-Stars and society's reaction to the book 2.5-Stars (50/50 for those who worship it and those who censor it) even if for the wrong reasons. I'm also going to give my teenage daughter 5-Stars for forcing me to read it, so she could talk to me about it's deeper meaning--a meaning that she has referred to as beautiful. But just to clarify, the beauty for her is contained in the message that a \\"Catcher\\" is someone trying to ward off the corruption of innocence as we come of age...not my introduction of depression into the greater conversation...but that conversation will happen as well. In the end a catcher could well be defined as someone who combats the cliff of teenage depression and the scourge of teenage suicide as well as delaying the end of innocence...intentional or not. For me, J.D. Salinger hit the ball out of the park on the subject of depression, and that was over 60 years ago.inger has brilliantly described, but has left unnamed. Murakami doesn't shy away from depression and suicide. Salinger ran through the door, yet left it all unnamed. I haven't done a comprehensive search for other's of the 65 million readers who think that Salinger accurately depicts teenage depression, but to me, this is his real genius. Without a doubt, Salinger had first hand experience with depression, whether it's his own or someone close to him...what he has brought to us, since most schools seem to include it as required reading, should be the open conversation we have with our kids about depression. This should be the conversation from \\"Catcher\\", not one of being rebellious or being sexual or homosexual or dropping out of school or having a plan for our lives or the sage advice of Wilhelm Stekel. Depression should be our first stop, those other topics, are heavily treated elsewhere in modern society. Depression and in particular teenage depression still remains stigmatized and taboo.

I'm going to give this book 5-Stars and society's reaction to the book 2.5-Stars (50/50 for those who worship it and those who censor it) even if for the wrong reasons. I'm also going to give my teenage daughter 5-Stars for forcing me to read it, so she could talk to me about it's deeper meaning--a meaning that she has referred to as beautiful. But just to clarify, the beauty for her is contained in the message that a \\"Catcher\\" is someone trying to ward off the corruption of innocence as we come of age...not my introduction of depression into the greater conversation...but that conversation will happen as well. In the end a catcher could well be defined as someone who combats the cliff of teenage depression and the scourge of teenage suicide as well as delaying the end of innocence...intentional or not. For me, J.D. Salinger hit the ball out of the park on the subject of depression, and that was over 60 years ago.

review_headline: Glad I Read It as an Adult
review_body:
In some horrific failing of the American public school system, I managed to escape the assigned reading of J.D. Salinger's quintessential classic The Catcher in the Rye. And not just me but, for all I know, every single student graduating (or not graduating) out of my little podunk hometown in Eastern Oregon, missed out on this reigning member of literary canon. I ought to write a letter to President Obama: Mr. President, just how is my generation going to change the future of America for the better if our high school English curriculum doesn't even include The Catcher in the Rye on its collective syllabus? Well, we can't. We're all just a bunch of goddamn phonies. I really mean it. This copy was even owned by some high school freshman named Cheryl. Even 14-year-old Cheryl isn't as phony as me. (Good thing, too, she went and used a blue highlighter on every single name in the goddamn book, other wise I'd never have made it through to the multiple choice exam at the end.)

Read the rest of this goddamn review here:

[...]
For a used book it served its purpose and was exactly what we needed and we received it very quick which was excellent!

Just finished reading [[ASIN:0991816137 The Pool Theory]] by Alexa Nazzaro and it made me want to read this book again. The angst felt by Holden Caulfield is timeless and still hasn't lost its edge. As to the commenters who didn't enjoy the novel: if all you read for is plot, I'm afraid that you're destined to reread the same stories over and over again. On another topic, imagine a 16 year-old taking a train across state lines and booking a hotel room for himself in NYC. Today's helicopter parents would have a couple of hemorrhages.

review_headline: I was, as one might imagine, shocked to discover that Grease had a love child with Gertrude Stein.
review_body: As I read the last sentences, I had this terrible feeling wash over me as if I just realized, after the fact, I paid someone $10 to cough on me for three hours. \\"Don't tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody\\" is not, and never will be, the conclusion to anything worthy of being called an American classic. It does, however, stand a much better chance at becoming the facebook status of a plastered sorority girl.
Amazing condition, brand new with no marks or anything. It came on time with no problems that arose. Overall really good !

I read this while out of town for my wife's grandmother's funeral.
It was a sad trip. She was a beautiful person.
I was in the proper mood for this book.
At first I thought it was going to be a comedy; everyone has told me how funny it is and it started off that way.
Then, a short way in and after having to laugh out loud several times, I learned something about the main character, Holden Caulfield, that made me pity him and made me try to understand him.
The book is written as though he, a foul-mouthed, jaded and insightful teenager, is telling you a story.
Holden is a damaged kid.
What he's wrong about tells half the story and when he's right, it's funny, heartbreaking and poignant.
You shouldn't diminish someone's abilities by saying they have \\"the right build\\" for what they're good at, you shouldn't drink Tom Collinses in December and you should cry for those who want to be the catcher in the rye.

review_headline: A great book to encourage reading
review_body: There is probably nothing that hasn't been said about this iconic book. I would like to add, from an educational point of view, that this could be the book that will change the reluctant reader's view of reading for pleasure. A must for adolescents and adults alike.
I have heard so much about this book and just had to read the story for myself.  It is amazing!
Its been a good read for him this summer, as with all youth who read it and a lifelong memory of the story

I am so late to this book, that it's embarrassing. I'm 59 years old and just read it for the first time last week. Somehow, no one had ever told me that I HAD to read this book. That's the only reason I can think of as to how I missed it.

But, what a joy it was to find this at any age. You don't have to be a teenager to identify with Holden, as long as you've been one at one time!

The one thing I'd like to add, after reading the first couple hundred reviews here, is, I think his brother's death had a lot more impact on him than people mention.

I love Holden Caulfield, I hope he had a good life.

number one I do not see what was so exceptionally touted over 50 years. I have not read any of his other works so I have no
book to compare. the colorful prose with which he overkilled in this book was not even dated to the fifties. I grew up in the
fifties and I didn't ever hear anyone converse in this style. example----using the word flit to describe a homosexual.

Such a good book. One of my favorites. It's a must-read in my opinion. Get this if you are into a refreshing, whimsical yet somewhat tumultuous storyline. It may be written in very simple english but reflects enormous depth.
I'm a junior in high school and I had to read it as a summer reading book. I actually enjoyed reading it.
I got it for my son it was a read for him for summer for his class next year.. He has said that he really likes it and I plan on reading it also..

review_headline: I first read Catcher about 50 years ago.
review_body: I have wondered why the novel has remained on reading lists.  As I reread the novel became aware of the underlying messages.  Holden represents an antihero who struggles with his failures.  His redeeming attachment to his fourth-grade sister provides a glimmer of  hope he will mature and gain insight into his narcissism.
this is for my sons book report this summer. He has not read it yet. i appreciate your help. thanks
I needed this book for my English Summer Reading, and got just what I wanted. The cover was different than the picture but still in great condition.

I read this book out of sheer curiosity due to its fame. It is about an expelled teenager's aimless search for pleasure and excitement in NYC before he goes home to face his parents. Commentators often describe it as being about teenage \\"angst\\". I think this is inaccurate. As an evangelical Christian, I regard this story as an example of a person who does not have a real and personal relationship with God. This person's life is spiritually empty and aimless, morally bankrupt, enslaved to stupid and perverse interests, unable to feel any pure love for anyone else, not understanding or caring why he exists, driven to find meaningless excitements, and continually hating and finding negative things to think about others. I forced myself to finish it. It is a worthless book that contributes to the moral ugliness of our world. The ignoble author is now dead. Unfortunately his book remains.

J.D. Salinger really captures the mindset of a teenager so perfectly, that teenagers of all generations would love this book. He is real and straight to the point in this book. A great American classic

I must have missed something.  Here is a book that has Cliff's Notes on it, yet I didn't get the point.  Maybe I should have read Cliff's instead.  Maybe my mistake was in looking for a plot.  That's more in keeping with my interests.  I have known a lot of teenagers, many of them labelled \\"delinquent\\" or \\"emotionally disturbed.\\"  That could explain Holden's familiarity to me.  Looked forward to reading this one for about 50 years, but was disappointed.
Exactly what I expected, perfect condition. Beautiful cover design. I was very excited to get this book as it is my all-time favorite book. Highly recommend.
THE ATTITUDE OF A TYPICAL TEENAGER WHO LIKES THE WORLD AND DOES NOT MIND WHAT THE FUTURE HOLDS EVEN IF KICKED OUT OF SCHOOL.
I am 64 and decided to reread this after 40 some years. Still fascinating, I gave it to my 14 year old grandson, it's hard to believe that this book was written before I was born.

review_headline: The only saving grace is the fact the book is roughly only 200 pages
review_body:
This book consist of about 190 pages of poorly written drivel and 20 pages of content. I read the book as it often receives high praise, however I recommend steering clear if possible. If you do have to read it or decide you have to give it a go, you're in luck that it's only about 200 pages.

I recommend something more entertaining and enlightening like a Hermann Hesse novel.

review_headline: If you really want to know the truth (Catcher in the Rye)
review_body: Brilliant! Loved it. \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" was \\"banned\\" from all the schools I attended. I had been warned about the language so I stayed away. Big mistake. Now, after 40 years of resisting, I read the book. I immediately \\"got\\" Holden Caulfield. That's the way teenagers back then talked. It's realism. As a published author myself, I will be forever changed because I read the phenomenal novel, \\"The Catcher in the Rye.\\"
Very pleased with the condition of the book. It was brand new with no marks in it or on it and was packaged well.

review_headline: lost some of its meaning today
review_body: I imagine when this first came out in the 50's it really spoke to a generation of young disenchanted teenagers, but I think it has lost some of its meaning today. I can't relate but then I'm in the rural Midwest.

This book was also purchased as a gift for a young man.  I too read this book in my teens, and found it to be quite meaningful.  Therefore, I purchased to keep this piece of literary genius moving within my family tree.  Thank You!!!!!
Just re-read this recently, and with the Salinger documentary coming out, I've been eager to put up reviews wherever I can.

This book was a good story to read. It describes a troubled teen on his way to New york to explore the nightlife before christmas break is over. Despite some parts that made the book interesting, it wasn't a book that I would say ''amazing'' to it. But overall, it's a good book to pass time.
Thought-provoking, well written, carefully crafted, funny, but deeply respectful and serious portrait of an adolescent boy's experience. New York City.

\\"What really knocks me out is a book that, when you're all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it. That doesn't happen much, though.\\"

This quotation summarizes my feelings after finishing Jerome D. Salinger's popular American classic The Catcher in the Rye. It is the story of 17-year old Holden Caulfield, the protagonist and first-person narrator of this novel. Holden is a teenager who finds himself somewhere in between childhood and adulthood and therefore suffers from depression and mental illness. Because of his personal issues, he performs poorly and repeatedly flunks out of school. Salinger managed to create a protagonist to which every reader can somehow relate their own transition to adulthood including all its highs and lows.

At the beginning of the novel, Holden is expelled from Pencey prep school. He travels to New York earlier than planned to spend some time there before his parents find out about his expulsion. He spends some time in the Big Apple in various bars and other places to clear his mind from the people at his school. Throughout the story, he reveals how much he hates phony (superficial) people - a term that he applies to almost all adults mentioned in the novel - and the movies, which, according to Holden, are the phoniest of all. As the story progresses, Holden reveals more details about his personal state of mind.
Holden describes his experience in a funny way with a good sense of humor. On the one hand, he observes society around him very maturely, but on the other hand he still finds himself in the position of a child who wants to run away and start a new life somewhere else. Although he swears, smokes and drinks all the time, Holden is a likeable character because many things he tells the reader are a valid criticism of society.

Although many of Salinger's slang terms and references appear a little odd to readers in the 21st century, the main theme of the book still relates to the issues of our contemporary society, which have not changed in about 60 years. Depression, suicidal thoughts and a lack of self-esteem among young adults are as widespread today as at the time of the first publication in 1951. Salinger was ahead of his time when he addressed these issues at a time they were still considered taboos. It is therefore not surprising that the book was at that time banned in many American schools. Nevertheless, The Catcher in the Rye is an outstanding piece of literature that everyone should read.

review_headline: Great book, but very small line space
review_body: It's a great pocket book, however the line spacing is quite poor, sometimes it seems like lines "jump on each other"...

bought because it was on the top 20 list of books everyone should read once. this book was okay, it has alot of foul language in it which is weird because most schools make children read it in high school.

No one lets me know if they appreciate the gifts I do send out so I wouldn't know if the recipient of this book liked it or not. I personally believe it is the best coming of age book for all young males to read. Unfortunately I am told children at least my grandchild does not enjoy reading and so doesn't do it.
I've always wondered why teachers make students read this.  I guess I now know.  It was certainly a surprise for me..

I decided to reread this book, because my son did a novel study on it this past year. He absolutely loved it and wanted me to reread it. I really liked it the second time around. I remember reading it when I was younger and needing my parents permission to read it. It is fun how after all this time it still seems controversial, but one of the greatest coming of age novels ever

review_headline: Wish JDS had written more books.
review_body: I should have read it in High School but then it was a tough read so I faked it with Cliff Notes. Now later in life I am more able to roll with it and understand the angst from a father's viewpoint.

review_headline: Book was fine for the age of it.
review_body: Book arrived in a timely manner and in good condition.  Pages were yellowed but it was in great shape for the age of the book. Thanks!

I needed this book for my childs summer reading. thank you for sending it as soon as you did.
this will give him more time to read it.

review_headline: It's just not he same the second time through
review_body: Read this in high school, thought I would pick it up again. The only thing I remembered of the first reading was the characters name, Holden Caulfield. Perhaps reading it again at 50 I just can't connect with that teenage angst.
The book cover in the picture was way different than what i received and the only reason i gave it two stars because it was cheap and arrived on time

I have very mixed feelings about this book people my age are supposed to love. I definitely think the style is good and it captures the feeling of teenage angst, making a character that's both relatable and somewhat unsympathetic. However, my main issue is that nothing much is done with the set up. Others might like it better than I did, but it left me with a feeling of unsatisfaction.

I give The Catcher in the Rye a five star rating. The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger, is a book in first person of a 17 year old telling his story of two days in New York City. I absolutely loved reading this book. For me it was a perfect time in my life to read it as a boy in high school. It was easy to compare and contrast my thoughts with his and also connect things in the book to today's society. It was serious, however sometimes funny because of the sarcastic this that he is thinking. The book takes place over two days, which may seem boring, but it is not. The book keeps the reader entertained with its profanity, slang, and explicit topics. It is very random as you will find that he is a very random person. The two days of the book really seems like a week or so, which he also mentions in the book that it has felt really long these past days. I would recommend The Catcher in the Rye to the teenage crowd because Holden is a teenager and the book talks about things that most teens might be experiencing. I would not recommend it to anyone who doesn't like swearing and slang in literature. It is the best \\"classic\\" novel I have ever read.
worth every cent it does take you  to a care free , some times turbulent  world of adolescence.  love every word of it

review_headline: A classic that deserves rereading late in life.
review_body: Catcher meant a lot to us when we were Holden's age but it was interesting reading years later too.  The slang is dated but the angst is not.  I loved it even more in the rereading.

review_headline: One of my all time favorites...
review_body:
Books don't get much better than this. But I must say, I think you have to be a certain type of person to get this one. Holden is a very complex character in his simplicity. It takes perhaps a more right-brained person to understand him and his story, perhaps? To fill in the gaps and think for oneself, maybe.

I don't know. I just know I liked this book when I was young and didn't read much. It was one of the few books I read over and over again. And now that I'm older and read relentlessly I've only grown to love it more and more. But in saying that, I know it isn't for everyone. And that's a good thing.
This was a free download, and I still love this book with all my heart! I loved it when I was younger and love it still now!

The Catcher In The Rye, by J.D. Salinger, is a great example of 20th Century American literature. In the novel, Salinger tells the story of a troubled seventeen your old boy, Holden Caufield. The writing is an excellent example of American literature from that period. The sentences are short and direct. Despite the uncomplicated writing, Salinger gives a detailed, in depth account of Caufield as the boy struggles in school and in life in general.

Salinger makes you feel like you are inside Holden Caufield's head, with his simple yet rich and descriptive sentences. Salinger makes sure that you know every detail about Holden's life. For example, when he describes Holden's hat: \\"It was this red hunting hat, with one of those very, very long peaks.\\" That sentence is typical of the simple yet descriptive writing in the book.

Salinger tells Holden's story by illustrating past experiences in Holden's life. Salinger describes these experiences through the thoughts about those experiences in Caulfield's head. The reader always knows what Caufield is thinking. That style makes the reader feel as if he is part of the dialogue. By putting the reader inside Caufield's head, Salinger is able to describe Caufield's struggles from Caufield's point of view. For example, when Caufield is in New York and is anxious about his date with Sally, an old friend, Salinger writes: \\"I didn't feel much like going. I'd made that damn date with Sally, though.\\" By using this style, the reader feels Caufield's anxiety and indecision.

Catcher In The Rye is a must read. No matter how many times you read it, you will always be intrigued by the rich, simple and descriptive sentences. It is the best novel that I have ever read. I love the way that Salinger puts you inside Caufield's head. I am confident that you will feel the same way after you read this fantastic piece of American literature.

I think everybody knows a Holden Caulfield. He seems confident. He has plenty of charms. He likes to pull your leg all the time. The more you get to know him the more you realize he doesn't have his stuff together and probably never will. Holden Caulfield in J.D. Salinger's The Catcher in the Rye is only 16, but you can imagine in a few years he'll be jumping from job to job because he just couldn't grow up. This novel is required reading in most high school curricula, and I think the reason for that is to serve as a warning to teenagers preparing to move into the next phase of their life: know the difference between healthy and unhealthy values.

At the start of the story, we learn that Holden Caulfield has been kicked out of Pencey Prep because he failed most of his classes. Holden makes all kinds of excuses. The one that seems to stick is that the whole place is full of phonies. In Holden Caulfield's world there are phonies everywhere. And the mere existence of these so-called phonies is enough to drive Holden to indifference. He grows annoyed when his history teacher, who seems to care about Holden, begins lecturing him about making an effort in life. Holden makes an excuse and gets out of there. In fact, to avoid further humiliation he leaves Pencey that very night, though he still has four days left before the end of the term.

The novel seems made up of random occurrences, what with a run-in with a prostitute and her pimp, visits to bars and clubs, meetings with various friends, but these things happen at the whim of Holden Caulfield. He makes a decision, often unwisely, and then these things happen. Holden does things without purpose. Even the decision to invite the prostitute to his hotel room was not well thought out since he had no intention of sleeping with her. Much of the novel finds him wandering around aimlessly, as though he can't decide what to do, where to go.

His paralysis in making a healthy decision for himself seems to lie in a hypersensitive sense of injustice. Even the tiniest injustice is enough to paralyze him with indecision and inaction. The fact that the world is full of phonies is enough to convince him not to pursue any meaningful activity. He has an ideal of himself as a savior of sorts, but the way he envisions this is as a fantasy rather than a realistic goal. He describes his ideal future as a person who catches lost children as they wander towards the edge of a cliff. Humanity needs him, he seems to believe, to protect them from the error of their ways. But this vision only serves to highlight his inability to make a concrete decision about the direction he wants to take his life. Holden doesn't even realize he's one of those children veering towards the edge of the cliff. If the ending is any indication, he never will.ems to lie in a hypersensitive sense of injustice. Even the tiniest injustice is enough to paralyze him with indecision and inaction. The fact that the world is full of phonies is enough to convince him not to pursue any meaningful activity. He has an ideal of himself as a savior of sorts, but the way he envisions this is as a fantasy rather than a realistic goal. He describes his ideal future as a person who catches lost children as they wander towards the edge of a cliff. Humanity needs him, he seems to believe, to protect them from the error of their ways. But this vision only serves to highlight his inability to make a concrete decision about the direction he wants to take his life. Holden doesn't even realize he's one of those children veering towards the edge of the cliff. If the ending is any indication, he never will.

review_headline: ** THE MOST OVERRATED BOOK OF ALL TIME **
review_body: As you may have already read is some other reviews, this kid is as whiny as can get. He hated phonies which is understandable, but he was just as phony as the people he critisized. Other than that, there is no way I can relate to this kid. The boy was confused as a lot of adolescents are, trying to make sense of his loneliness & desperately trying to articulate what he really wanted to do in life which were far outside of his parents' expectations - which is good. But there was never any moments of self-reflection or realizations of faults in the mirror. \\"Someone robbed me of $5!\\" Boo-fkn-hoo, kid. Ask mommy for some more. The only people who think this is a classic are rich trouser stains who complain about the silver spoon being too lumpy. This isnt the worst book Ive ever read, but this is by far the absolute most over-rated book I've read thus far. If the expectations werent up so high, I may have enjoyed it more. I feel like I was tricked. If you want something real, read Bukowski.

review_headline: A Letter to Holden from an Empathizer
review_body:
***This letter may contain spoilers.***

Dear Holden:

Do you mind if I call you Holden? Manners dictate that I should address you as \\"Mr. Caulfield\\" since I don't know you personally. But after reading your absorbing account about your experiences since you got expelled from Pencey Preparatory School in \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" (CITR from now on), I feel as if I know you like an acquaintance, if not a friend. Besides, calling you \\"Mr. Caulfield\\" sounds so stuffy and formal. Well, anyway, whether you like it or not, I'm calling you Holden.

Believe me, I'm not the first person to comment that you are quite a complex and contradictory individual. You can be both witty and blunt, cynical and naïve, tenderly caring and harshly intolerant. I'm also not the first person to comment that you can be what you accuse practically the whole world of being - deceptive, insincere, hypocritical, and yeah, your favorite word - phony. Maybe it's a self-defense mechanism on your part against all the other phonies that upset you. Maybe you're sarcastically trying to wake others up to the fact that you're not fooled by them and trying to make them see the foolish errors of their behavior. Whatever.

Holden, you, I, the entire world can often be phony and dishonest. Why? I think it's because we are all afraid, afraid of being ignored, being hurt, being alone, or of something else. I'm not excusing it, just trying to understand it as part of the imperfect human condition, and even forgiving it when I can. You might want to try to do the same. It's not easy, but it might make you feel better. Also, consider this: I heard somewhere that if people were always truthful and open with each other, they would eventually destroy each other. I think that's quite possibly true.

No, you don't exactly have a \\"David Copperfield\\" existence, or any other Dickens novel existence. In fact, you seem to come from a family of high-class prestige and accomplishment which a lot of us would envy. A corporate lawyer dad, a Hollywood writer older brother, a grandmother who gives you cash four times a year. But, it seems to me that it's a source of shame for you, instead. Did your \\"phony\\" outlook start with how you think about your family? I got that impression from CITR, especially your description about how you first met Jane Gallagher indirectly through your mom getting upset that Jane's mother's Doberman Pinscher pooped on your lawn. Oh, and later how your mom chewed out your little sister Phoebe when she took the blame for you for smoking while you were hiding in the closet. Yeah, your Mom sounds neurotic and snobby. Is your Dad like that, too? Is he more fond of being a big shot than in saving innocent lives in court? Anyway, it sounds like your family is at least a little concerned with keeping up appearances. I can understand somebody rebelling against that and wanting to find out what's real and really good about life.

However, Holden, \\"good\\" does not necessarily mean perfect. Nobody's perfect. Yet, time and again, it seems you're looking for the perfect person, you think you find that perfect person, then that person does something that disappoints you, and you cynically reject that person. Take Jane Gallager again, for instance. I guess you liked her because she wasn't pretentious and overly competitive, even with checkers. But then when you found out that your ex-Pencey roommate Stradlater had a date with her in a car, you lost it and tried to fight him. Did you think Jane was tainted from now on? Is that why you never followed through on calling her? Yeah, being noble and unblemished and protective and uncompromising is all well and good, but you can take it too far. James Castle did. Yeah, I guess it's admirable, in principle, to kill yourself rather than be forced to take back something you believe is true. But it's really stupid, too. You can stick to your guns and still stay alive.

Oh, I almost forgot, you also throw over a wise, concerned friend and mentor Mr. Antolini just because he touched your head??? Is HE a tainted bad guy from now on? Come on now, Holden. He's given you lots of sensible advice about continuing your education and increasing your knowledge and discovering what ideas are right for your head so that when you find ideas to make the world better, you can express them more eloquently and more humbly. That William Stekel quote: \\"The mark of the immature man is that he wants to die nobly for a cause , while the mark of the mature man is that he wants to live humbly for one.\\" Great quote. Remember that quote. Don't try to be Christ or Hamlet. Show others what you believe in by example, by the life you lead. I gotta keep remembering that myself.

It's nice that you believe in truth and decency, and being true to yourself (at least most of the time). Your \\"Catcher in the Rye\\" wish in protecting and caring about innocent youth is also praiseworthy But you can't practice those beliefs by playing Peter Pan or preventing change or shielding people from the big, bad world. Your late, beloved younger brother Allie showed that to you. Your younger sister Phoebe is still showing you that, by challenging to find things you like and believe in, and growing up and finding new interests, and even by being willing to follow you wherever you go. About that. I know you're desperate about changing your life, and not just bitching about it. But hitchhiking out west and living alone in a cabin and pumping gas? Holden, you can do better than that!

I suggest you grit your teeth and complete that final year of prep school. By then, you'll be eighteen and a legal adult (and able to drink your scotch and soda legally) and free to determine your own destiny. Then, decide what occupation would best help achieve your \\"Catcher in the Rye\\" goal. Perhaps you would like to be a kindergarten teacher or child counselor/tutor. Or a museum guide. Or a writer of children's books (without having to \\"sell out\\" to Hollywood, \\"mecca\\" of phonies, like, ahem, D.B.). You know you're no moron, in spite of what you say. Use your fine English skills to achieve your dream (by the way, I would have liked to read that composition you wrote for Stradlater about Allie's baseball glove covered with poems. Sounds like a good tribute. Too bad you threw it away. Yeah, Stradlater is an ignorant peasant.).

Holden, I'm no psychoanalyst - you're dealing with at least one already. I'm not pretending I have all the answers. I don't - nobody does. I also don't want anything from you, and I am not being paid to write this. Again, I guess I am being a little like Mr. Antolini by not wanting you to ride for a \\"terrible, terrible fall\\". I suppose I empathize with you and the social, sexual, and occupational challenges and frustrations you face. I'm certainly not alone in this. Will you listen to my advice? Maybe you won't and that's your business. But I wish you would. If you want to write back in a \\"pen pal\\" sort of way, you're welcome to do that, too. I care.

Sincerely,

John Panagopoulos

P.S.: I was thinking about that \\"duck\\" problem you posed. My notion is that they all migrate during the winter. There are probably too many ducks to round up and keep warm during the winter. However, here in Boston, we also have these huge white geese that stay near the Charles River all year long. We have these huge white swans, too, but they are kept in pens during the winter and are released into the Boston Garden pond during the summer. I wonder who has the answer?d still stay alive.

Oh, I almost forgot, you also throw over a wise, concerned friend and mentor Mr. Antolini just because he touched your head??? Is HE a tainted bad guy from now on? Come on now, Holden. He's given you lots of sensible advice about continuing your education and increasing your knowledge and discovering what ideas are right for your head so that when you find ideas to make the world better, you can express them more eloquently and more humbly. That William Stekel quote: \\"The mark of the immature man is that he wants to die nobly for a cause , while the mark of the mature man is that he wants to live humbly for one.\\" Great quote. Remember that quote. Don't try to be Christ or Hamlet. Show others what you believe in by example, by the life you lead. I gotta keep remembering that myself.

It's nice that you believe in truth and decency, and being true to yourself (at least most of the time). Your \\"Catcher in the Rye\\" wish in protecting and caring about innocent youth is also praiseworthy But you can't practice those beliefs by playing Peter Pan or preventing change or shielding people from the big, bad world. Your late, beloved younger brother Allie showed that to you. Your younger sister Phoebe is still showing you that, by challenging to find things you like and believe in, and growing up and finding new interests, and even by being willing to follow you wherever you go. About that. I know you're desperate about changing your life, and not just bitching about it. But hitchhiking out west and living alone in a cabin and pumping gas? Holden, you can do better than that!

I suggest you grit your teeth and complete that final year of prep school. By then, you'll be eighteen and a legal adult (and able to drink your scotch and soda legally) and free to determine your own destiny. Then, decide what occupation would best help achieve your \\"Catcher in the Rye\\" goal. Perhaps you would like to be a kindergarten teacher or child counselor/tutor. Or a museum guide. Or a writer of children's books (without having to \\"sell out\\" to Hollywood, \\"mecca\\" of phonies, like, ahem, D.B.). You know you're no moron, in spite of what you say. Use your fine English skills to achieve your dream (by the way, I would have liked to read that composition you wrote for Stradlater about Allie's baseball glove covered with poems. Sounds like a good tribute. Too bad you threw it away. Yeah, Stradlater is an ignorant peasant.).

Holden, I'm no psychoanalyst - you're dealing with at least one already. I'm not pretending I have all the answers. I don't - nobody does. I also don't want anything from you, and I am not being paid to write this. Again, I guess I am being a little like Mr. Antolini by not wanting you to ride for a \\"terrible, terrible fall\\". I suppose I empathize with you and the social, sexual, and occupational challenges and frustrations you face. I'm certainly not alone in this. Will you listen to my advice? Maybe you won't and that's your business. But I wish you would. If you want to write back in a \\"pen pal\\" sort of way, you're welcome to do that, too. I care.

Sincerely,

John Panagopoulos

P.S.: I was thinking about that \\"duck\\" problem you posed. My notion is that they all migrate during the winter. There are probably too many ducks to round up and keep warm during the winter. However, here in Boston, we also have these huge white geese that stay near the Charles River all year long. We have these huge white swans, too, but they are kept in pens during the winter and are released into the Boston Garden pond during the summer. I wonder who has the answer?

review_headline: Landmark approach in the frank portrayal of adolescence
review_body:
\\"Catcher in the Rye\\" has been a source of great controversy from the moment it was written. The book has been banned at various times and in various places. There has been more recent acceptance of the book, but the work still arouses passionate debate. Holden Caulfield is the anti-hero in the story. He has a lot of character flaws. He has trouble accepting the phoniness of adult institutions. He longs to find an identity and feels increasingly alienated from mainstream society.

Holden was kicked out of a fancy prep school. This was a pattern for him. The setting was the few days between when he was ousted to when he returned to his boyhood home. Salinger's use of inner dialogue was masterful. One could see the unique perspective of the troubled teen.

Holden was very interested in sex. He was a virgin, but knowledgeable in the ways of vice. He was a drinker and smoker. He knew about various types of perversity. Herein is the major controversy of the book. Caulfield is profane and can curse like a sailor. He discusses homosexuality, prostitution, and pedophilia at various points. These were especially taboo topics in the straight-laced 1950's.

The story was detailed, sometimes too much so. The inner dialogue was a bit boring in spots. Although there were tedious sections, the majority of the book was interesting. Holden was a desperate teen who was trying to recover from disappointments, immature blunders, and a loss of faith in authority figures. Holden did have good traits. He was very loving and committed to his little sister Phoebe. In the end, Holden did not run away because he loved her and had no realistic plan of survival on his own.

This was a valuable book in that it showed the inner conflicts common in adolescence. There is a desire to fit in and a desire to gain independence. Holden desires to find his way as an authentic person. He is most disturbed by the phoniness present in society. If one can get beyond the many crude and vulgar references, he or she can glean a lot of valuable insights about human nature and the angst of youth.many crude and vulgar references, he or she can glean a lot of valuable insights about human nature and the angst of youth.
A \\"must read\\", recommended for high school age on.  Read it - and then try to figure out why anyone would want this book \\"banned\\" ... are you kidding me? It's a great book!!

If you like the ratings of rich spoiled 16 or 17 year olds than this book is for you.  Don't bother getting it.  It was banned when I was  a kid and I was wondering what all of the fuss was about.  Now I know.  Nothing.

The storyline of \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" needs no introduction. Almost every young teenager in the US has read it, most of them probably as an assignment in school. Surprisingly, \\"The Catcher in the Rye\\" is also required reading in some Israeli high schools. The first time I read it, I was about 16, and I can recall it had a deep impact on me. I was curious whether reading it at the older age of twenty-eight would arouse the same feeling. In one word: no. The writing is still great, but I think that as an adult there is a lot less to relate to. If you still haven't read this great American novel, by all means read it. However, if you've already read it as a teenager, skip the experience and savor the good memories of it.

I finally got around to reading this book, which is considered by many, to be an American classic. Personally I was underwhelmed by it and finished it thinking just about any teenager with a modicum of wit could have written it.

review_headline: I Kind of Get it, But Don't At the Same Time
review_body:
If you take nothing else from this review, take this: Salinger did a great job capturing the confusing thoughts of a 16 year old boy.

However, in the greater scheme, I didn't really like this book all that much. It's interesting and it does deal with a 16 boy striking out on his own for a few days in New York. And I guess some guys would relate to the character a ton, but he really just came off as annoying to me. The thing I related to the most personally was the whole \\"everyone's a phony\\" thing. Definitely agreed with a lot of that sentiment in a big way. Other than that I was glad when the book was over.

Interestingly this is a \\"banned book\\" due to the overly sexual thoughts the boy routinely has. Why this is worth banning is beyond me because if you've talked for more than 15 seconds with a 16 year old boy, you'd see that the thoughts expressed here are extremely mild by comparison. Maybe it's a timely thing but for today, I just don't get it. Also the language is mild (though there are some \\"F bombs\\") compared to what I've heard come out of the mouths of teenagers today.
Really powerful book. Easily one of my favorites. Hopefully they'll make a movie out of it sometime. If not, it'll be a shame.

No clue why this became a classic....  Started out a book about an emo, whiny kid.  And then I completely lost interest.  Bleah. (and yes, I have read many, many books, including many of the "classics," and this is one of the worst.

I read The Catcher on the Rye for a school project; I actually really enjoyed the book. I really enjoyed the authors writing style. It made it really easy to read, so I actually finished the book. I really enjoyed how the main character told the story and just how he spoke throughout the story. The only things I didn't like about the story were how he just jumped from story to story, there weren't good transitions. Especially when he was in New York and he just kept going from event to event, it didn't flow well. Other than that I really enjoyed the book, it would recommend it to anyone because it is a classic book, it is really easy to read and it is interesting the whole time. I would rate it about a four out of five.
I haven't read it yet but I can't wait to here the tragic story of a outfielder standing alone in a field....

When I was given this book, I had no idea of the effect it would have on my semester. Some hated it. I on the other hand couldn't put it down. No matter how much you might dislike Holden or hate his actions, everyone in one way or another can relate to him. I have only ever had that happen to me once in my years of \\"active reading.\\" Now I do admit that Holden can be a lot to take in sometimes. In the times that I would put down the book, it was because I got sick of him and just didn't wanna continue for the night and had to wait for motivation to read it another time. Even then Holden didn't leave my mind. I would catch myself thinking about him when doing other things. Leaving Pencey and those many other schools just tells me that he gives up easily. Because somethings get difficult or people who he dislikes are brought up into his everyday life, he just gets lazy and stops trying. It's hard to grasp why Holden does what he does. We all know a person just like him. I could name a couple right off the top of my head. He always has the urge to lie. He lies when he can. Calling Holden a compulsive liar would be spot on. Holden's mood swings can get pretty bad and happen very quick also. He shows signs of being bipolar or depressed, something many teens, espcially now, seem to be diagnosed with. Throughout his adventure in the city, it's hard to remember that he is just a teen. With the drinking, hotel rooms, and sexual \\"experiences\\" he has, I always had to have tabs to remind me that he is still just a kid. But those are two things most all teenagers experiement with: alcohol and sex. It doesn't matter when you read this book. My grandfather read it in the 70's, my mother in the 90's and now I in 2013. This book, no matter what year, will never get too old or be outdated. This book honestly has the ability to change your life. It's not a drastic or crazy change, but it changes the way you think. I now understand why it is considered one of the greatest pieces or American literature.
I have heard about this book for many years.  I finally read it.  It was a good book and in many parts I could relate personally.

I bought this for recommended reading for my boy. He couldn't put it down. I read this in school also. I never forget the adventures in it. I hope he won't either. Can't say I disliked anything about this book. I would recommend it to all school children 17 and above.

This book is recognized as one of the best of all-time for good reason. It's funny, dark, and dramatic.

Holden Caulfield is a one-of-a-kind protagonist with a very distinct style and personality. His journey throughout this book is the epitome of the great American novel.

If you haven't read this already, do it now! It's an American classic.
I have wanted to read this book since I was a kid and just never got around to it. Great book. I'm glad that I finally made the time. A true classic!

This book is unequivocal trash. This is basically a Martin Scorsese \\"After-Hours\\"-like awfully mundane piece of garbage novel just told from the perspective of a pompous, self-entitled 16 year-old (trust me, this one is MARKEDLY pompous and self-entitled). Let me save you 10 bathroom breaks, 120 rolled eyes, 1000 moments of irritation at the sophomoric appraisal of people as \\"phonies\\", and the rush of rage you'll feel when this book reaches its (much needed) anticlimactic \\"ending\\". The ending, mind you, will be totally indiscernible from the beginning, or the middle, or the beginning-middle, or the middle-end (you get the picture) for that matter.Synopsis: Boy gets kicked out of school, wanders around New-York ad-infinitum, and goes to the hospital for tuberculosis (which he caught from wandering around town). There he meets a psychoanalyst who tells him to write about his 3 days of transitory homelessness in New York (that took place between him leaving school and getting sick). My advice? If you HAVE to read this, go to an assortment of websites and read the summaries and synthesize them. Then, look online for corresponding test given at a variety of colleges/highschools, study these test and their answers. Participate in class discussions half-heartedly and roll your eyes whenever the professor intimates that this book is worthy of anything outside of makeshift toilet paper during an impromptu camping trip that didn't afford proper packing. If you DON'T HAVE to read this book, don't!
Would not have purchased this if I didn't love it. Asking someone to rate purchases like this is kind of senseless . . . . 99% of others may not like anything I like . . . . .

I bought this solely because so many others have read it and I haven't. I wasn't too into it but it did hold my attention enough for me to finish it. I probably won't be reading it again, but it does deserve a once-over.
large print, paper and binding quality was rather poor but for a mass market paperback what do you really expect? shipped on time, and a good read regardless of structural issues.
Purchased for my husband.  He just finished it and really enjoyed it. He had read it years ago and wanted to read it again. It is like a classic.

I recently read this as a high school assignment, and while I usually enjoy whatever books they make us read, this has to be the one I've enjoyed the least. Maybe there's some deeper meaning I missed while reading the book, but in my opinion, deep meanings mean nothing when it's covered by a boring story. Holden is completely unlikable; cursing every other page and saying the same phrases over and over (Phonies, goddamn phonies I'm not kidding!). I don't mind cursing, but when \\"Goddamn\\" is the only adjective Holden knows of, it gets repetitive. Maybe I wasn't born in the right time to fully enjoy it, but when something is regarded as a \\"Classic\\", then I think it should be able to entertain readers regardless of age.

review_headline: A Story That Remains Relevant Today
review_body:
Many of us read The Catcher in The Rye in high school. After a recent reread, I find it as relevant now as I did in the 80s.

J.D. Salinger gives us a view of a sensitive, struggling teen, but what underlies the story is Holden Caulfield's deep compassion, e.g., for the ducks in Central Park, (Where do they go in winter?), Stradlater (his undersirable dorm neighbor to whom he gives his time and ear), for his sister Phoebe (her innocence touches him).

Holden's sensitivity and depth make him a hero for today, just as he was in the middle of the last century. And though Salinger is still considered a \\"minor\\" writer, his eye for detail and ability to create memorable, nuanced characters keep his pages alive still.

review_headline: Ugly look for a great book
review_body:
First of all I would like to say that I loved the book since I first read it some 20 years ago. But I think that this is the place where we should judge the book by its cover. I bought it for my daughter's 15th birthday. When I saw the book I wanted to burn it. Cheap, soft cover, and the color of the pages is gray, not white. I was expecting a hard cover (maybe I did not read the description carefully enough?) with a shiny white pages inside. I was embarassed giving it to my daughter, but luckily we had other gifts for her, so no big deal.
And what is with all those 5 stars reviews for this book? It's like rating a fast food restaurant 5 stars just because you met a girl of your dreams while eating there.
A really quality book, an overall good read I recommend it to everyone.  Book's physical quality was good as well, no big deficiencies.

Just finished reading this for the first time... I think I missed the point with this book. I'm sure it was very controversial and all when it was released in 1951, but I don't see how it can be consistently ranked on \\"best novels\\" lists with great literature like [[ASIN:B003XRELDY Brave New World]] and [[ASIN:B000FC0PDA The Great Gatsby]]. This is just some 17 year old complaining about his life.

I have had this book for awhile, but I never got around to reading it. To be honest I'm not really a big reader, but I had just finished The Great Gatsby for school and loved it, so I figured I'd give another classic a shot.

So anyways, I picked up the book yesterday, and finished it today. It was fantastic. I've never connected with a book so well. I would recommend this book to any teenager or someone who just wants a Great quick read.

This book is very interesting and it's not typical book, where you'll get questions and then you'll find the answers during the book. It gives an opportunity to come up with your own ideas. It doesn't even explain why does it have such an intersting title. Whole book mentions it once. It certainly isn't a book for people who like to read easy stuff. Other than that, it has very good ideas and a view of life.

review_headline: Dealing with Late Struggles of Youth
review_body:
One scene that has always stuck in my mind in \\"It's A Wonderful Life\\" is when George Bailey and his future wife were talking and George was taking his time on making his move to kiss her for the first time, when in the background an old man said \\"Well are you going to kiss her or not, ahh youth is wasted on the young.\\"
To my way of thinking many classic novels which we as in our youth had to read and study and be tested on in high school and later in college, were actually never really fully understood or appreciated. To me, I was told to read these books and later the teacher or the professor would lecture and have active discussions in detail of the nuances and literal and figurative interpretations on the intentions of the author and the real plot of what the author was trying to convey to the reader.
The better students would learn the triggers of success and mimic their instructor's persuasions and add \\"a little\\" of how the novel affected them in their young lives. But my take on many of these classics actually confused me and being the rebellious student that I was I usually didn't go with the program and in many instances took my rebellion in the force of protest and usually ended up with an old-fashioned hook a C. I did the same thing when I first read \\"Catcher in the Rye\\" in fact being very much like Holden Caulfield in my studies of this novel.
The fact remains that as one grows older one gains from life experiences and is able to appreciate life on a wider and more knowledgeable scale. I have spent most of my academic life reading and writing of history and life memoirs of things that have actually happened. My studies were based on things that have happened. However I find myself being brought back to the classics and with that added maturity, I have found out that I do indeed understand them better.
J. D. Salinger was really writing of his youth when he wrote this book. Holden Caulfield is a dysfunctional youth who in all reality hates the concept of growing up and following teacher or parental guidance or instruction. Being born to wealth and surrounded by siblings who all seemed to be normally adjusted youths, Holden held out to be the family \\"black sheep.\\" The traumatic effect of his younger brother's death had deeply disturbed Holden. In fact this event may have started the trigger that he would rather remain a child and not grow up in the \\"phony\\" lifestyle of being an adult.
The other key sibling that Holden held in very high regard was Phoebe who he regarded as not only as a sister but a person who personified the goodness in the essence of what youth is. Simple and loving!
The book is written in the first person by Holden Caulfield and it tells of his relationships with his classmates, teachers and his parents. It is written in the mind of a seventeen year old which is contradictory, whimsical, funny, mad, nonsensical and at times very funny. In fact it does represent the brain of a person who has not fully developed. To tell you the truth this writing in the vernacular of a teenager, represents the brilliance of Salinger's writing. Some youth can adapt to the adult world and move on; others like Holden have a very hard time in doing so.
My review intent is not to give away the meaning and plot of this classic book but to rather engage the reader to see that this book is indeed of deep meaning in which I never recognized 46 years ago. The meaning of the title makes sense as it never did before and as an added insertion to my discoveries I found this book to coincide greatly with the story of \\"Peter Pan.\\" If you have never read the book do so. If you read it as a young student, I daresay read it again, it will surprise you!!!!reality hates the concept of growing up and following teacher or parental guidance or instruction. The other key sibling that Holden held in very high regard was Phoebe who he regarded as not only as a sister but a person who personified the goodness in the essence of what youth is. Simple and loving!
